ANTH 429.description: Assist in recovering skeletal material prior to processing and final curation. Proper methods of scene documentation and recovery will be mastered.

ANTH 430.name: Fieldwork in Archaeology
ANTH 430.description: Practicum work in archaeological data recovery and analytical techniques.

ANTH 431.name: Isotope Ecology
ANTH 431.description: This new course will give graduate students and advanced undergraduates a thorough background in the principles and applications of stable isotope analysis in archaeology, ecology, and paleontology.

ANTH 432.name: Anthropology of Warfare, Violence, and Peace
ANTH 432.description: Origins and tactics of warfare; overview of cultural foundations and impacts of warfare and nonviolence; distinctions among aggression, conflict, violence, war; dynamics of militarization and peacebuilding.

ANTH 435.name: Historical Archaeology Laboratory
ANTH 435.description: Laboratory procedures for the processing, identification, and interpretation of artifacts from historical sites. Artifactual material from historic sites excavated by UT archaeologists will be used for class projects.

ANTH 436.name: Cities and Sanctuaries of the Greek and Roman World

ANTH 439.name: Forensic Center Experience and Research
ANTH 439.description: Assist in all phases of research and work at the Forensic Anthropology Center, with emphasis on professional development, independent research, and logistics.

ANTH 441.name: Topics in Cultural Method and Theory
ANTH 441.description: Variable topics focusing on contemporary issues in cultural anthropology method and theory.

ANTH 443.name: Archaeology and Art of Ancient Greece

ANTH 444.name: Archaeology and Art of Ancient Italy and Rome

ANTH 449.name: Big-data Social Sciences
ANTH 449.description: Big-data research is now a major part of the social sciences, including anthropology. This course combining lectures with practical tutorials in computational approaches using digital data on cultural change, from ancient to contemporary social media. Students are encouraged to bring a laptop, but no programming experience is required.

ANTH 450.name: Current Trends in Anthropology
ANTH 450.description: Analytical, integrative review of current directions of research and theory in anthropology.

ANTH 451.name: Hunter-Gatherers
ANTH 451.description: Examines current literature and thinking about hunter-gatherers worldwide, encompassing archaeological, biological anthropological, and cultural anthropological approaches. Humanity has followed a hunting-gathering way of life for much of its existence and understanding this way of life helps us to understand what it means to be human.

ANTH 452.name: Paleoindian Archaeology
ANTH 452.description: Examines the archaeological, bioanthropological, linguistic and paleoenvironmental evidence associated with the initial human settlement of the Americas during the Late Pleistocene. The initial human colonization of other parts of the world will also be briefly explored, as will theories and approaches to the study of human migration.

ANTH 453.name: Public Heritage and Community Archaeology
ANTH 453.description: This seminar-based course explores "who owns the past": how the "past" is constructed and presented by archaeologists; how these archaeological "pasts" differ from those experienced, perceived, and understood by other groups; and how archaeologists can collaborate with other groups and descendant communities to conduct archaeological research (from design to dissemination) that is responsive to the needs of various stakeholders and is relevant to various communities.

ANTH 454.name: Archaeology of the African Diaspora
ANTH 454.description: Historical archaeology of African, North American and Latin American sites relating to the transatlantic slave trade and the experiences of enslaved Africans in the New World from the 15th to the 19th centuries.

ANTH 455.name: Archaeological Foodways
ANTH 455.description: This seminar class is designed to survey the complex behaviors by which humans produce, prepare, present, and consume foods and the various methods used by archaeologists (including paleoethnobotany, zooarchaeology, osteology, residue analysis, and other artifact analyses) to address foodways and larger interpretations of lifeways at archaeological sites.

ANTH 457.name: Senior Honors in Anthropology
ANTH 457.description: Research and writing of the senior honors thesis.

ANTH 459.name: Selected Topics in Biological Anthropology Applied Area
ANTH 459.description: Applied biological anthropology topics for undergraduate students. Topics may include practical experience or laboratory study of anthropological materials.

ANTH 460.name: Paleoethnobotany
ANTH 460.description: This seminar class provides advanced undergraduate students a comprehensive understanding of the methods and applications of paleoethnobotany within archaeology, as well as providing some hands-on experience in working with archaeological plant remains.

ANTH 461.name: Archaeological Resource Management
ANTH 461.description: Federal legislation and regulations affecting identification, protection, and management of archaeological resources. Professional ethics and responsibilities and relationship of federal and state agencies, public interest groups, and professional archaeologists in conduct of federally sponsored archaeology.

ANTH 462.name: Early European Prehistory
ANTH 462.description: Origins and evolution of human culture in Europe through the beginnings of settled life. Primary focus on Paleolithic/Mesolithic chronology and lifeways.

ANTH 463.name: Rise of Complex Civilizations
ANTH 463.description: Development of complex societies in Old World from origins of agricultural economics to rise of states. Focus on Mesolithic, Neolithic, and Metal Age lifeways in Africa, Europe, and Asia.

ANTH 464.name: Principles of Zooarchaeology
ANTH 464.description: Basic osteological studies of major vertebrate groups, with emphasis on the aboriginal's use of animals in subsistence and culture. Identification and interpretation of archaeologically derived molluscan and vertebrate remains, with introduction to laboratory use of comparative collections.

ANTH 466.name: Archaeology of Southeastern United States
ANTH 466.description: Archaeological research on prehistoric American Indian cultures in Southeastern United States.

ANTH 469.name: Selected Topics in Archaeological Area
ANTH 469.description: Area studies in archaeological topics for undergraduate students. Topics may include practical experience or laboratory study of anthropological materials.

ANTH 470.name: Anthropology and the Genome
ANTH 470.description: How do studies of DNA and genomes impact our understanding of what it means to be human? What have ancient DNA studies recently revealed abut past and present human relations? This course covers the intersection between genomic science and anthropology. Learn basic population genetics and the molecular (lab) techniques, and discuss relevant themes, such as species and interpopulation relationships, migration and dispersals, personalized genomic testing, gene editing, epigenetics, identity, and ethics.

ANTH 472.name: Paleopathology
ANTH 472.description: Provides advanced undergraduate students with an in-depth knowledge of how diseases affect the human skeleton and an introduction to evolutionary medicine. The culture-history of each disease provides the context in which diseases first appeared, how they were experienced by individuals, and the cultural impacts of certain diseases, especially infectious diseases, on communities. Laboratory sessions are designed for hands-on examination of the signatures of diseases discussed in lecture.

ANTH 474.name: Basic Molecular Biology Techniques
ANTH 474.description: Provides advanced undergraduate students with practical experience in basic molecular biology techniques. Combines lectures, interactive discussions, and hands-on wet lab experience. Students will be able to perform and understand the fundamental principles of the most common types of DNA analyses by the course's end.

ANTH 480.name: Human Osteology
ANTH 480.description: Intensive examination of the human skeleton.

ANTH 483.name: Evolutionary Biology for Anthropologists
ANTH 483.description: This lecture course provides advanced undergraduate students with a fundamental background in evolutionary biology, both from historical and modern theoretical perspectives.

ANTH 486.name: Introduction to Forensic Anthropology
ANTH 486.description: Introduction to forensic anthropology, the science that utilizes methods from skeletal biology and archaeology as tools in human identification in a medico-legal context. Covers the human skeleton and dentition, methods employed in the estimation of age, sex, ancestry, stature, time since death, and trauma, and working in a medico-legal setting.

ANTH 489.name: Forensic Science and Human Rights
ANTH 489.description: Overview of the intersection of forensic science and human rights, emphasizing forensic anthropologists' role in human rights investigations. Practical, ethical, and theoretical implications of scientific work in the human rights arena. Special topics and in-depth case studies illustrating the complexity of human rights oriented forensic science work.

ANTH 490.name: Primate Evolution
ANTH 490.description: Living and fossil primate taxonomy, ecology, and comparative anatomy. Survey of primate fossil record with emphasis on the origin or major primate lineages.

ANTH 494.name: Primate Behavior
ANTH 494.description: Social organization and behavior of selected primates including group composition, size, and structure; patterns of mating; other social interactions; communication; and cultural behavior. Application of primate studies to human ethology.

ANTH 495.name: Human Paleontology
ANTH 495.description: Intensive survey of the human fossil record from the earliest hominid remains to the earliest origins of modern human form.

ANTH 430R.name: Fieldwork in Archaeology
ANTH 430R.description: Practicum work in archaeological data recovery and analytical techniques.

ARAB 231.name: Arabic for Heritage Speakers I
ARAB 231.description: This course is designed for students who grew up speaking / hearing Arabic at home and wish to develop their academic skills in the language. In this course, students will engage in reading, writing and speaking practice in formal and academic contexts, including the study of the Arabic writing system and relevant grammar topics.

ARAB 232.name: Arabic for Heritage Speakers II
ARAB 232.description: This course is designed for students who grew up speaking / hearing Arabic at home and wish to develop their academic skills in the language. In this course, students will engage in reading, writing and speaking practice in formal and academic contexts, including the study of relevant grammar topics.

ARAB 251.name: Whole New Worlds: Fantasy, Sci-Fi, and Dystopia in the Middle East
ARAB 251.description: Examines themes and genres of fantasy, sci-fi, and dystopia in literature, film, and graphic novels from Middle East, in relation to relevant political, cultural, and historical contexts. Taught in English.

ARAB 320.name: Middle Eastern Film
ARAB 320.description: Examines cinemas of the Arab world, Israel, Iran, and Turkey, with attention to aesthetic and formal elements of films as well as cultural, political, and historical context. Conducted in English.

ARAB 321.name: The Israeli-Palestinian Conflict in Literature, Film, and Popular Culture
ARAB 321.description: Examines cultural representations of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, including literature, film, and music, and introduces students to relevant political and historical context. Taught in English.

ARAB 331.name: Culture and Daily Life in the Arab World
ARAB 331.description: This course will examine aspects of daily life, customs, traditions, and cultural practices in a number of Arabic speaking countries, while also developing advanced reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills in Arabic.

ARAB 332.name: Contemporary Issues and Current Events in the Arab World
ARAB 332.description: This course will examine current political, economic, and social issues in a number of Arabic speaking countries, while also developing advanced reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills in Arabic.

ARAB 351.name: Languages of the Middle East and North Africa
ARAB 351.description: This course is a survey of the languages that have been written and spoken in the Middle East and North Africa from 3100 BCE to the present. The course begins with the first attested language, Sumerian, but focuses especially on the Semitic languages such as Akkadian, Hebrew, Aramaic, and Arabic. Each language is situated historically, culturally, and linguistically, including topics such as language and politics, sociolinguistics, and dialectology.

ARAB 415.name: Topics in Arabic Literature, Language, History, and Culture
ARAB 415.description: Course topic varies. Taught in English.

ARAB 431.name: Media Arabic
ARAB 431.description: This course focuses on authentic Arabic media, print media, blogs, videos, and computer based material. Activities will include reading/listening news sources for comprehension, in-class discussions of current events in the Arab world, the geo-political situation, different Arab countries' economies, arising social issues and popular culture.

ARAB 432.name: Introduction to Modern Arabic Literature
ARAB 432.description: This course introduces students to the canonical texts of modern Arabic literature. It focuses on various trends in modern Arabic literature across genres, regions, and national literatures. Making use of film and social media will help students better understand the literary culture of the Arab world. Taught in Arabic.

ARAB 490.name: Internship
ARAB 490.description: Career-related experiences in the United States or abroad.

ARAB 490N.name: Internship
ARAB 490N.description: Career-related experiences in the United States or abroad.

ARCH 101.name: Introduction to the Built Environment
ARCH 101.description: Architectural design as a creative process based on visual thinking and ideas related to space, technology, and/or place. Scope and definition of the built environment in relation to contemporary society, building industry, and allied design professions. Orientation to courses and programs of the school.

ARCH 102.name: Visual Design Theory
ARCH 102.description: Principles of visual design, addressing form and space. Exploration of visual ideas through analysis. Introduction of terminology and vocabulary.

ARCH 107.name: Honors: Introduction to the Built Environment
ARCH 107.description: Students will attend ARCH 101 classes with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.

ARCH 111.name: Architecture and the Built Environment
ARCH 111.description: An introduction to architecture and the built environment for non-architecture majors. Significance of our surroundings, forces that create them. Creative aspects of design. Survey of examples from local to global. Strategies for individual and collective involvement.

ARCH 117.name: Honors: Architecture and the Built Environment
ARCH 117.description: Students will attend ARCH 111* classes, with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.

ARCH 121.name: Representation I: Visual Logic and Perception
ARCH 121.description: Introduction of analog and digital representation methods in two and three dimensions. Emphasis is on learning how various techniques impact design exploration and visual logic through drawing, visualization, and analysis, including drawing conventions, representational and graphic structure.

ARCH 122.name: Representation II: Intention and Communication
ARCH 122.description: Exploration of analog and digital representation methods and their relationships to design intent. Emphasis is on developing an understanding of how a variety of media address perceptual phenomena, abstraction, concepts of mapping and diagramming.

ARCH 171.name: Design I: Spatial Order I
ARCH 171.description: A beginning transdisciplinary studio that focuses on foundations of spatial composition and design. Key concepts include ideation, form, craft, spatial order, and three-dimensional thinking.

ARCH 172.name: Design II: Spatial Order II
ARCH 172.description: A transdisciplinary studio that focuses on more advanced spatial composition and design. Key concepts include analytical methods, scale, light and shadow, and experience.

ARCH 201.name: The American City: Citizens of the 21st Century
ARCH 201.description: This course studies cities in the United States situated within a global context. The course is organized thematically, including architecture, planning paradigms, urban design theories, social equity, the economies of growth, the role of infrastructure, urban ecologies, geographies of sustainability and the American connection to land and landscape. A series of American case studies will be presented related to these themes. Understanding the complex evolution of American urbanism from multiple perspectives will help students in the future, as citizens of the 21st century.

ARCH 211.name: History and Theory of Architecture I
ARCH 211.description: Architecture and ideas of building and community form in major world cultures from the prehistoric era to about 1750 CE.

ARCH 212.name: History and Theory of Architecture II
ARCH 212.description: Architecture and ideas of building and community form in major world cultures from 1750 CE to the late-20th century.

ARCH 213.name: Modern Architecture: Histories and Theories
ARCH 213.description: Examines the history and theory of modern and contemporary architecture through broad-based examinations of the questions of modernity and specific case studies of buildings, projects, landscapes and theories.

ARCH 217.name: Honors: History and Theory of Architecture I
ARCH 217.description: Students will attend ARCH 211* classes, with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.

ARCH 218.name: Honors: History and Theory of Architecture II
ARCH 218.description: Students will attend ARCH 212* classes, with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.

ARCH 221.name: Representation III: Digital Workflow
ARCH 221.description: Development of a systemic understanding of representational workflows across multiple platforms. Emphasis is placed on translating between multiple tools, techniques, and design ambitions while leveraging potentials created by computational power.

ARCH 227.name: Honors: Modern Architecture Histories and Theories
ARCH 227.description: Students will attend ARCH 213 classes with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.

ARCH 261.name: Tectonics and Stereotomics
ARCH 261.description: Design and expression with structural archetypes. Exploration of distinctions between structure and enclosure. Emphasis on formal ordering systems, spatial implications, and structural concepts. Topics include gravity loads, earth-shaping, massive construction and light frames. Combination lecture and lab format. First half semester course.

ARCH 262.name: Climatic and Daylight Design
ARCH 262.description: Introduction to design and expression with climate as a context and form-generator. Emphasis on design guidelines and formal ordering. Analysis of climates, selection of site and building design strategies, design for microclimates and enhancing daylighting. Combination lecture and lab format. Second half semester course.

ARCH 263.name: Design Implementation I: Principles
ARCH 263.description: Design and expression with structural archetypes, energy considerations, and material properties related to walls, floors, point loads, and enclosures. Emphasis on formal ordering systems and essential behaviors, including lateral bracing and load-tracing. Associated interior and exterior construction materials, methods, performance, and detailing. Enclosure strategies including performance (thermal and moisture) and expression. Schematic detailing. Design guideline sizing. Combination lecture and lab format. First half semester course.

ARCH 264.name: Design Implementation II: Assemblies
ARCH 264.description: Design and expression with structural archetypes, energy considerations, and material properties related to frames, trusses, and more complex organizations and assemblies. Emphasis on formal ordering systems and essential behaviors, including structural and thermal performance. Associated interior and exterior light steel, brick, stone and concrete masonry materials, methods, performance, and detailing. Design guideline sizing. Combination lecture and lab format. Second half semester course.

ARCH 271.name: Design III: Territory I
ARCH 271.description: Contextual determinants in architectural design. Development of alternative design strategies through analysis of a regional territorial condition. Exploration of material, climate, energy, comfort, and experience. Students establish a sense of design agency.

ARCH 272.name: Design IV: Territory II
ARCH 272.description: Contextual determinants in architectural design. Development of alternative design strategies through analysis of an extensive territorial condition. Exploration of material expression, structure, and performance. Students further establish a sense of design agency.

ARCH 321.name: Representation IV: Information Modeling
ARCH 321.description: Exploration of advanced information modeling programs. Emphasis is placed on learning how the digital model can assist in the design process through the representation of construction and analysis. Content includes the use of building information modeling to predict building performance and to document material properties.

ARCH 361.name: Design Research in Technology
ARCH 361.description: Input to the architectural design research from a range of technical issues. May include building codes, construction types, cost, fire resistance, area, and bulk, along with comfort parameters, lighting intentions, energy performance targets, energy programming and schedules, etc. Focus on framing the designer's tasks and the technical support of architectural qualities. Supports technical aspects of program development in ARCH 373*. Combination lecture and lab format. First half semester course.

ARCH 362.name: Schematic Design Technology
ARCH 362.description: Design concepts, form-making and supporting strategies from a range of technical issues in support of studio class projects. Exploration of the implications of technical aspects of program on schematic design. Focus on early design methods to engage design implications of technical knowledge. Combination lecture and lab format. Second half semester course.

ARCH 363.name: Design Implementation III: Systems
ARCH 363.description: Design and expression with structural archetypes, energy considerations, and material properties related to building systems and their interrelationship. Emphasis on formal ordering systems and essential behaviors, including structure to skin relationships. Associated interior and exterior enclosure materials, methods, performance, and high-performance skins. Design guideline sizing and detailed calculations. Combination lecture and lab format. First half semester course.

ARCH 364.name: Performative Design I: Passive Systems Design
ARCH 364.description: Design and expression for passive solar heating, natural ventilation, and passive cooling, including collection, storage, distribution, and shading. Introduction to passive systems computer modeling. Supports applications in design studio of projects with simple HVAC in skin-loaded buildings with few thermal zones. Combination lecture and lab format. First half semester course.

ARCH 365.name: Performative Design II: Active and Hybrid Systems Design
ARCH 365.description: Design and expression with mechanical heating, ventilation and cooling systems, electric lighting and their integration with passive design. Introduction to active systems computer modeling, carbon performance, and on-site renewable power generation. Supports applications in design studio of projects with simple HVAC in skin-loaded buildings with few thermal zones. Combination lecture and lab format. Second half semester course.

ARCH 373.name: Design V: Applied Research
ARCH 373.description: Understanding the design process through integrated design research. Methodologies includes analysis of site, environment, program, spatial and contextual conditions, user needs, precedent studies, typology, scale, socio-political and cultural influences. Culminates in execution of a comprehensive research document and design project.

ARCH 374.name: Design VI: Systems and Atmospheres
ARCH 374.description: Integration of design determinants emphasizing structure, sustainability, materials, and construction systems with respect to architecture's cultural role. Research and design incorporate technological and ecological systems into the production of experiential conditions.

ARCH 422.name: Special Topics in Urban Design
ARCH 422.description: Faculty initiated professional elective involving history and theory of urban form, urban developments, the study of landscape and urbanism, and related issues.

ARCH 423.name: Special Topics in Interior Architecture
ARCH 423.description: Faculty initiated professional elective involving interior architecture, history and theory of interior design, furniture design, lighting design, acoustical design, and related issues.

ARCH 424.name: Special Topics in Landscape Architecture
ARCH 424.description: Faculty initiated professional elective involving landscape architecture, history and theory of landscape architecture, ecology, and related issues.

ARCH 425.name: Special Topics in Architecture
ARCH 425.description: Faculty initiated professional elective in architecture and applied architectural theory.

ARCH 450.name: Special Topics in History, Theory, and Criticism
ARCH 450.description: Faculty initiated professional elective involving architectural history, theory, and criticism.

ARCH 451.name: Special Topics in Representation
ARCH 451.description: Faculty initiated professional elective involving representation and graphic communication.

ARCH 452.name: Special Topics in Sustainable Design
ARCH 452.description: Faculty initiated professional elective involving sustainability and progressive environmental design.

ARCH 454.name: Special Topics in Materials and Construction
ARCH 454.description: Faculty initiated professional elective that explores materials and construction, the physical development of large-scale, component, or installation construction.

ARCH 455.name: Special Topics in Digital Fabrication
ARCH 455.description: Faculty initiated professional elective involving fabrication and technology in design.

ARCH 461.name: Design Development Integrations
ARCH 461.description: Integration and design development of previously studied building systems from a sustainable design perspective, including energy use, passive systems, active systems, construction, lighting, and materials. Performance modeling for structure and carbon targets. Format: Lecture and lab. Projects integrated with studio.

ARCH 462.name: Professional Practice
ARCH 462.description: Management and organizational theories and practices for delivering professional design services. Included are assessment of the building industry and its influence on practice; analysis of the basic management functions within professional firms; and legal and ethical concerns facing practitioners today. Special obligations and privileges of the design professional.

ARCH 467.name: Honors Seminar: Research | Methods | Case Studies
ARCH 467.description: Seminar comparing and contrasting past and current approaches to research and inquiry particular to a design-based discipline. Approaches may include, but are not limited to, Art Historical, Scientific/Experimental, Observational/Anthropological, Economical/Statistical. Students pursue individual research projects while examining the methods of "the scholarship of design" and "design as scholarship" in the fields of architecture, urbanism, and landscape architecture. Students are encouraged to link historical methods of investigation and current positions of architectural production.

ARCH 471.name: Design VII: Integrations
ARCH 471.description: Active integration of cultural considerations, programmatic possibilities, and technical exploration and precision as related to the development of an architectural project. Consideration of site-design, life safety, building structure, environmental systems, and high-performance building criteria are addressed within the context of ideas of resilience, regeneration, abundance, and sustainability.

ARCH 472.name: Design VIII: Cultural Immersion
ARCH 472.description: Advanced research and design projects examining themes of culture, landscape, and territory through travel and off-campus study.

ARCH 474.name: Advanced Architectural Design: Landscape Architecture I
ARCH 474.description: Introduces students to techniques, concepts, and practices of landscape architecture and landscape planning with particular emphasis on development of representational and communication skills using digital and analog media. Strategic and formal design concepts are introduced as vehicles for the exploration of a wide range of media and techniques for analyzing landscapes, projecting design alternatives, and communicating design ideas.

ARCH 475.name: Advanced Architectural Design: Landscape Architecture II
ARCH 475.description: This design studio focuses on issues of space and form in landscape architectural design. Working at small and intermediate scales, students explore contemporary and historical theories of space and form through a range of analog and digital media with a particular emphasis on 3-dimensional modeling. Students work rapidly across several projects in order to explore multiple formal and spatial concepts and practice new techniques.

ARCH 477.name: Honors: Independent Study in Architecture
ARCH 477.description: Individual studies and projects under faculty direction, for honors students only. Credit adjusted to complexity and level of effort required.

ARCH 491.name: Foreign Study
ARCH 491.description: Research and design projects conducted in various locations abroad.

ARCH 492.name: Off-Campus Study
ARCH 492.description: Research and design projects conducted in various off-campus locations.

ARCH 493.name: Independent Study in Architecture
ARCH 493.description: Student initiated, individual studies and projects under direction of faculty sponsor. Credit adjusted to complexity and level of effort required.

ARCH 494.name: Foreign Studies Sketchbook
ARCH 494.description: Investigations of historic urban fabric and architecture in various locations abroad. Analysis and sketch records in sketchbook format required.

ARCH 495.name: Cultural Engagement
ARCH 495.description: Investigations of historic and contemporary contexts in various locations abroad.

ARCH 496.name: Design IX: Provocations
ARCH 496.description: Thematic studio requiring research, critical examination and individual engagement through design speculation of critical positions within the discipline addressing topics outlined by individual instructors.

ARCH 497.name: Independent Study – Advanced Architectural Design Studio
ARCH 497.description: Student initiated, individual research and design under direction of faculty sponsor.

ARCH 499.name: Design X: Consequences – Diploma Studio
ARCH 499.description: Final culminating design studio experience for Bachelor of Architecture professional degree. Development of a position and reflection on consequences in advanced architectural design. In-depth work on thematic issues as defined by instructor. Required graphic and written products. Restricted to students in their final academic semester.

ARCH 465R.name: Directed Research
ARCH 465R.description: With the sponsorship of a faculty member, each student works on a specific topic or project related to that faculty member's area of expertise, research, scholarship, or creative activity.

ARCH 478R.name: Preparation for Self-Directed Diploma Studio
ARCH 478R.description: Faculty oversight of student-initiated topic for critical inquiry. Related research on the student-selected topic, context, nature of inhabitation, and applicable precedents results in the synthesis of visual and textual work, including a statement of intent, program, and site for a self-directed project in subsequent semester.

ARCH 496S.name: Design IX: Provocations – Collaborative Engagement
ARCH 496S.description: Thematic studio requiring research, critical examination and individual engagement through design speculation of critical positions within the discipline addressing topics outlined by individual instructors. Supports service learning with engaged community partner. Includes purposeful service experience and student reflection.

ARCH 498R.name: Design X: Consequences – Self-Directed Diploma Studio
ARCH 498R.description: Final culminating design studio experience for Bachelor of Architecture professional degree. Development of a position and reflection on consequences in advanced architectural design. In-depth work on thematic issues as defined by student with faculty oversight expanding on design proposal, research, and documentation undertaken in a previous seminar.

AREC 110.name: Opportunities in Agricultural, Food and Resource Economics
AREC 110.description: Overview of the curricular requirements for departmental majors, current issues in associated fields of study, and career opportunities.

AREC 201.name: Economics of the Global Food and Fiber System
AREC 201.description: Introduction to microeconomic and macroeconomic principles and their application to the global food and fiber system. Specific topics include consumer and producer behavior, market equilibrium, monetary and fiscal policy, and international trade.

AREC 212.name: Introduction to Agribusiness Management
AREC 212.description: Introduction to agribusiness firm characteristics and decision-making. Overview of economic principles and the basic functions of management ― planning, organizing, controlling, and directing. Specific topics include firm structure, forecasting, marketing and selling, budgeting, break-even analysis, use of financial statements, capital investment, supervision, staffing, and evaluation.

AREC 270.name: Economic Perspectives on Natural Resource and Environmental Issues
AREC 270.description: Exploration of the economic causes of natural resource depletion and environmental degradation, employing the concepts of externalities, public goods, and market failure. Use of economic logic and analysis to assess the relative effectiveness of alternative policy approaches for addressing such problems. Application to issues of air quality, climate change, water quality, water quantity, energy use, fisheries management, endangered species protection, and waste recycling.

AREC 310.name: Career Planning and Placement
AREC 310.description: Career planning, job markets in the agricultural industry, and techniques to obtain employment, including recruitment/placement services, resume construction, personal interviewing, and job-offer evaluation/analysis.

AREC 312.name: Rural Real Estate Appraisal
AREC 312.description: Theory, methods and procedures of real estate appraisal applied to rural property; trends in real estate values; factors influencing real estate values; approaches used in real estate valuation.

AREC 313.name: Agricultural Law
AREC 313.description: Survey of legal topics related to agribusiness operations and production agriculture in Tennessee. Topics include introduction to legal system, property, contracts, farm and business organization, civil liabilities, and estate planning.

AREC 314.name: Environmental Law
AREC 314.description: Survey of legal topics related to the natural environment, including an overview of the most important federal environmental statutes and the regulatory tools and concepts used to mitigate environmental degradation.

AREC 324.name: Quantitative Methods
AREC 324.description: Quantitative analytical tools used in economics and business. Simple and multiple linear regression techniques applied to economic data. Analysis of cross-section and time series data. Optimization techniques applied to economic and business decisions.

AREC 331.name: Agricultural Commodity Policy
AREC 331.description: Economics rationale for and effects of historical and current policies and programs for the agricultural commodity sector including price and income support, supply management, and crop insurance. Relationship of domestic commodity policy to international trade agreements.

AREC 332.name: Food Policy
AREC 332.description: Economic rationale for and effects of policies and programs relating to food production and consumption, including hunger and nutrition, safety, labeling, advertising, organic production, and local food systems.

AREC 333.name: Agricultural Conservation Policy
AREC 333.description: Economic rationale for and effects of policies and programs for the management of soil and water resources control, nutrient and pesticide application, and the protection of agricultural lands and wildlife habitats.

AREC 342.name: Farm Business Management
AREC 342.description: Principles and procedures for determining most profitable business organizations and systems of operation; attention to traditional and nontraditional agricultural enterprises and businesses; nature of managerial processes; business records and their uses; budgeting; acquisition and management of capital, land, labor and machinery; farm business planning.

AREC 345.name: Climate Change and Renewable Energy Economics
AREC 345.description: Overview of climate change economics and policy and avenues for addressing climate change, including renewable energy. Assessment of the economic, environmental, and policy forces that are shaping the policy debate surrounding climate change policy. Exploration of methods for evaluating the economic costs and benefits of climate policy and investment in renewable energy.

AREC 350.name: The Food and Agricultural Marketing System
AREC 350.description: Survey of U.S. food and fiber marketing system; marketing functions; industry structure; market channels; marketing options of farmers; basic analysis of marketing problems.

AREC 352.name: Futures and Options Markets
AREC 352.description: Examination of futures and options markets. Emphasis is placed on using futures and options in a risk management and pricing context pertaining to trading, marketing, hedging, and procurement of agricultural commodities and natural resources in relation to the agribusiness/agricultural sectors.

AREC 356.name: Marketing Team Participation
AREC 356.description: Participation in the development of a total marketing plan for a product sold to or by farmers. Includes product identification; market research; and development of an action plan, including an extensive promotional plan, financial analysis, and evaluation. Requires preparation of final plan for presentation in written, oral, and visual formats. Plan presented in national competition during the National AgriMarketing Conference.

AREC 395.name: Executive Seminar Series
AREC 395.description: Exposure to real-world applications of business and economic principles, agricultural policy implications, and business and institutional leadership through face-to-face interaction with leaders in the food and agricultural Industry. Engagement of students in discussion of a range of cutting-edge topics such as the challenges of feeding the world and the impact of technology on the future of the industry.

AREC 410.name: Senior Seminar
AREC 410.description: Capstone experience for departmental majors involving application of curricular knowledge and skills to one or more case studies in the field of agricultural and resource economics.

AREC 412.name: Agricultural Finance and Risk Management
AREC 412.description: Microeconomic and financial concepts applied to decision problems faced by farms and agribusinesses; financial statement analysis; firm capital structure; time value of money, capital budgeting and investment analysis, risk management and diversification; computer applications.

AREC 420.name: International Agricultural Trade and Marketing
AREC 420.description: Introduction to real and monetary aspects of international trade effect on agricultural commodity flows; partial equilibrium analysis of international trade in agricultural products; institutional aspects of international marketing of agricultural products.

AREC 442.name: Advanced Agribusiness Management
AREC 442.description: Advanced concepts in developing business and marketing plans and in applied management principles, such as inventory control and pricing techniques. Discussion of management issues including going international, employee supervision, management succession, and guerilla marketing. Teamwork emphasized in managing an agribusiness firm through game simulation. Written and oral presentation required.

AREC 444.name: Agricultural Production and Technology Management
AREC 444.description: Advanced topics in agricultural production management and applied use of advanced tools to make farm management decisions. Topics include business structure, managing income tax, machinery management, human resources, and the adoption and use of new and emerging technologies. Applied tools include mathematical programming, regression analysis, and spreadsheet decision tools.

AREC 460.name: Rural Economic Development
AREC 460.description: Use of economic principles in understanding rural economic development at community and regional levels, emphasizing the linkages between rural and urban communities, business location decisions, and how geography shapes markets. Integrating historical and current information, students will explore efficiency and equity as driving forces behind public and private sector policy to encourage, manage, and forecast domestic and international development.

AREC 470.name: Policy Analysis for Environmental and Natural Resource Management
AREC 470.description: Application of a policy analysis framework to conflicts and issues associated with natural resource use and related environmental quality impacts. Design of institutional changes to improve economic efficiency and equity, with emphasis on the potential applicability of market-type and incentive-based policy mechanisms.

AREC 492.name: Off-Campus Internship
AREC 492.description: Pre-approved supervised experience with firm or organization in the field.

AREC 493.name: Independent Study
AREC 493.description: Directed individual or team research and report writing. Special courses in specific topics.

AREC 494.name: Special Topics in Agricultural and Resource Economics
AREC 494.description: Topics and formats vary to address current issues and opportunities for student development.

AREC 499.name: Undergraduate Research
AREC 499.description: Experience in research projects under supervision of staff members. Student should make arrangements for research project with instructor prior to enrollment.

ARED 350.name: Field Experience
ARED 350.description: Tasks related to teaching and to teacher roles.

ARED 400.name: Theory and Practice in Art Education I
ARED 400.description: Basic instruction and hands on practice for K-12 level appropriate 2-D and 3-D art experiences that include production, form and function (art criticism), art context (art history), personal perspective (aesthetics), academic language and lesson plan formats.

ARED 401.name: Theory and Practice in Art Education II
ARED 401.description: Advanced instruction and hands on microteaching practice that includes elementary, middle, and secondary theme or centrally focused unit plans based upon diversity, multiculturalism, visual culture, technology and interdisciplinary methods.

ARED 440.name: Instruction, Pedagogy, and Assessment in Art Education
ARED 440.description: Examination and construction of curriculum, instruction and assessment as related to advanced theory and teaching practices in art education.

ARED 350N.name: Field Experience
ARED 350N.description: Tasks related to teaching and to teacher roles.

ART 101.name: Introduction to Art: Surface
ART 101.description: An introduction to the elements and principles of design using a variety of media. Studio projects, lectures and discussion will explore how the principles of design transcend media. Readings and discussion will inform how to analyze and critique contemporary art.

ART 102.name: Introduction to Art: Time
ART 102.description: An introduction to the elements and principles of creating time-based arts using a variety of media. Studio projects, lectures and discussion will explore film, video, animation, sound, and associated disciplines.

ART 103.name: Introduction to Art: Space
ART 103.description: An introduction to elements and principles of design using a variety of media. Studio projects, lectures and discussion will explore how the principles of design transcend media. Readings and discussion will inform how to analyze and critique contemporary art.

ART 299.name: Special Topics
ART 299.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department.

ART 301.name: Student Exhibition
ART 301.description: Exhibition of student work, including off-campus venues, e.g. Gallery 1010.

ART 402.name: Art and Culture
ART 402.description: This course will examine art, culture, and ideology. Course content and format (studio and/or lecture) may vary.

ART 444.name: Studio Art Research
ART 444.description: Active research investigations in faculty-led initiatives.

ART 455.name: Professional Practice Seminar
ART 455.description: This course covers the tools and skills necessary for arts professionals to advocate for themselves in a range of arts related environments. Covered in the course are a sustainable life in the arts, the professional job hunt, grant applications, writing, social media, vocations in the arts, business plans, residencies, support for artists/arts professionals, copyright, curatorial practice, commissions, working with commercial galleries and non-profit spaces.

ART 456.name: Studio Art Internship
ART 456.description: On-site, practical work designed to bridge the university experience with the workplace prior to graduation. Must be pre-arranged with the department.

ART 484.name: Museum Studies III: Field Projects
ART 484.description: Special field projects including restoration, preservation, registration, and other related research on or off campus.

ART 495.name: Visiting Artist Seminar
ART 495.description: Study and discussion of contemporary art issues conducted by different visiting artists each semester.

ART 499.name: Special Topics
ART 499.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department.

ARTA 211.name: Drawing I
ARTA 211.description: Development of drawing skills from a variety of sources including life drawing. Projects will emphasize composition, technique, and content.

ARTA 212.name: Drawing II
ARTA 212.description: Techniques of expression in drawing based on both observation and content. Includes a life drawing component.

ARTA 213.name: Painting I: Introduction
ARTA 213.description: Capacities of oil and acrylic painting on canvas.

ARTA 214.name: Painting II
ARTA 214.description: Techniques of expression in oil and/or acrylic.

ARTA 216.name: Watercolor II
ARTA 216.description: Capacities of transparent watercolor with attention to individual exploration of surface, space, and concept.

ARTA 219.name: Special Topics in Drawing/Painting
ARTA 219.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department to enhance and expand the painting, drawing, and watercolor curricula.

ARTA 231.name: Photography I
ARTA 231.description: Introduction to the art of photography. Taking and processing of photographs through both traditional film/darkroom and digital.

ARTA 262.name: Intaglio I
ARTA 262.description: Metal plate intaglio printing in traditional and contemporary techniques of etching, soft ground, drypoint, aquatint, and color methods.

ARTA 263.name: Lithography I
ARTA 263.description: Stone and aluminum plate lithography applying traditional and contemporary techniques of crayon, tusche, transfer methods, state proofs, and photolithography.

ARTA 264.name: Screen Printing I
ARTA 264.description: Screen printing as a fine art medium including development and application of various basic stencils in compositional printing.

ARTA 265.name: Relief
ARTA 265.description: Relief printing in traditional and contemporary techniques from wood, linoleum, and plastics.

ARTA 266.name: Monoprint and Monotype
ARTA 266.description: Investigations of traditional and contemporary techniques exploring the variable print using intaglio, relief, and lithographic processes.

ARTA 269.name: Special Topics in Printmaking
ARTA 269.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department.

ARTA 291.name: Book Arts and Papermaking
ARTA 291.description: Book arts and papermaking as a medium for two- and three-dimensional art. Emphasis on development of a personal form.

ARTA 311.name: Drawing III
ARTA 311.description: Individual expression in drawing using varied media and approaches.

ARTA 312.name: Drawing Portfolio Review
ARTA 312.description: Review of prior work in drawing.

ARTA 313.name: Painting III
ARTA 313.description: Individual expression with varied media on canvas.

ARTA 314.name: Painting Portfolio Review
ARTA 314.description: Review of prior work in painting.

ARTA 330.name: Photography Portfolio Review
ARTA 330.description: Review of prior work in photography.

ARTA 341.name: Digital Photography
ARTA 341.description: Studio course introducing theory and techniques of use of computer in photography.

ARTA 342.name: Large Format Photography I
ARTA 342.description: Studio course introducing theory and practice of photography using large format view camera.

ARTA 360.name: Printmaking Portfolio Review
ARTA 360.description: Review of prior work in printmaking.

ARTA 361.name: Intermediate Print Workshop
ARTA 361.description: Individual and collaborative studio work encompassing theory and practice in intaglio, lithography, relief printing, screen printing, monoprint, papermaking, book arts, and/or photo-print processes.

ARTA 391.name: Intermediate Two-Dimensional Arts
ARTA 391.description: Individual sections for various artistic disciplines.

ARTA 411.name: Drawing IV
ARTA 411.description: Advanced drawing with emphasis on individual concepts and personal expression.

ARTA 413.name: Painting IV
ARTA 413.description: Advanced painting stressing individual concepts and personal expression with varied media.

ARTA 419.name: Special Topics in Drawing and Painting
ARTA 419.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department to enhance and expand the two-dimensional arts curriculum.

ARTA 431.name: Photography III
ARTA 431.description: Individual development of photographic problems and techniques.

ARTA 461.name: Advanced Print Workshop
ARTA 461.description: Individual and collaborative studio work encompassing theory and practice in intaglio, lithography, relief printing, screen printing, monoprint, papermaking, book arts, and/or photo-print processes.

ARTA 469.name: Special Topics in Printmaking
ARTA 469.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department.

ARTA 495.name: Visiting Artist Seminar
ARTA 495.description: Study and discussion of contemporary art issues conducted by different visiting artists each semester.

ARTA 496.name: Capstone
ARTA 496.description: Students will engage in self-initiated research to demonstrate proficiency in two-dimensional arts.

ARTA 431R.name: Photography III
ARTA 431R.description: Individual development of photographic problems and techniques.

ARTA 461R.name: Advanced Print Workshop
ARTA 461R.description: Individual and collaborative studio work encompassing theory and practice in intaglio, lithography, relief printing, screen printing, monoprint, papermaking, book arts, and/or photo-print processes.

ARTB 221.name: Ceramic Sculpture
ARTB 221.description: Introduction to sculptural formats with a focus on ideas and ceramic process. This course will address clay preparation, clay finishing, and kiln firing.

ARTB 222.name: Beginning Pottery
ARTB 222.description: Introduction to clay with an emphasis on utilitarian form. This course will address pottery wheel techniques, clay preparation, glazing and kiln firing.

ARTB 229.name: Ceramics: Special Topics
ARTB 229.description: Student- or instructor-initiated courses to be offered at convenience of department.

ARTB 241.name: Beginning Sculpture
ARTB 241.description: Introduction to the materials, concepts, technical processes, and history of sculpture. Materials include wood, plaster, steel, and plastics.

ARTB 243.name: Mold-Making and Casting
ARTB 243.description: Examines possibilities and processes related to mold-making. A variety of casting materials will be explored including metals, wax, rubber, plaster, and ceramic shell.

ARTB 245.name: Metal Fabrication
ARTB 245.description: Introduction to steel as a material for the creation of sculpture. Development of welding techniques, design of cold connections, and engineering of structural components.

ARTB 246.name: Mixed Media Sculpture
ARTB 246.description: Includes installation art, performance, and conceptual art. Contemporary issues and materials related to sculpture are examined through research and studio projects.

ARTB 249.name: Special Topics in Sculpture
ARTB 249.description: Instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department.

ARTB 320.name: Ceramics: Portfolio Review
ARTB 320.description: Review of prior work in ceramics.

ARTB 321.name: Intermediate Ceramic Sculpture
ARTB 321.description: Continued investigation of handbuilding with an emphasis on the development of individual ideas and expression.

ARTB 322.name: Intermediate Pottery
ARTB 322.description: Continued investigation of throwing with an emphasis on the development of individual ideas and expression.

ARTB 323.name: Intermediate Pottery and Ceramic Sculpture
ARTB 323.description: Continued investigation of sculpture and/or utilitarian forms with an emphasis on idea development and process. This course will address clay preparation, clay finishing, and kiln firing.

ARTB 340.name: Sculpture Portfolio Review
ARTB 340.description: Review of prior work in sculpture and development of new work.

ARTB 341.name: Intermediate Sculpture
ARTB 341.description: Students begin defining and developing their visual vocabulary relative to contemporary sculptural issues. Emphasis on studio projects, research, and discussion.

ARTB 343.name: Intermediate Mold-Making and Casting
ARTB 343.description: Further exploration of casting methods and processes with an emphasis on metals including bronze, aluminum, and iron.

ARTB 345.name: Intermediate Metal Fabrication
ARTB 345.description: Further exploration of construction in steel and other metals with an emphasis on welding, cold connections, and structural design.

ARTB 346.name: Intermediate Mixed-Media Sculpture
ARTB 346.description: Further investigation into installation art, performance, and multi-media art. Contemporary issues and materials related to sculpture are examined through research and studio projects.

ARTB 391.name: Intermediate Three-Dimensional Arts
ARTB 391.description: Individual sections for various artistic disciplines.

ARTB 421.name: Advanced Ceramic Sculpture
ARTB 421.description: Continued investigation of sculpture with a focus on idea development and individual direction. This course will address clay preparation, clay finishing, and kiln firing.

ARTB 422.name: Advanced Pottery
ARTB 422.description: Continued investigation of utilitarian forms with a focus on idea development and individual direction. This course will address clay preparation, glazing, and kiln firing.

ARTB 423.name: Ceramics Research Project
ARTB 423.description: Student- or faculty-led research project in ceramics.

ARTB 424.name: Ceramics: Clays and Glazes
ARTB 424.description: Clay chemistry, clay bodies, glaze theory, and calculation. Formulating, mixing, and testing of clay bodies and glaze formulas.

ARTB 429.name: Ceramics: Special Topics
ARTB 429.description: Student- or instructor-initiated courses to be offered at convenience of department.

ARTB 441.name: Advanced Sculpture
ARTB 441.description: Individual development of sculptural problems and techniques. Students work independently while participating in group projects, critique, and discussion.

ARTB 443.name: Advanced Mold-Making and Casting
ARTB 443.description: Advanced exploration of casting methods related to metals including bronze, aluminum, and iron. Emphasis on individual studio and research projects.

ARTB 445.name: Advanced Metal Fabrication
ARTB 445.description: Advanced exploration of construction in steel and other metals through welding, design of cold connections, and engineering of structural components.

ARTB 446.name: Advanced Mixed-Media Sculpture
ARTB 446.description: Advanced investigation into the sculptural possibilities of installation art, performance, and multi-media. Contemporary issues are examined through research and studio projects.

ARTB 449.name: Special Topics in Sculpture
ARTB 449.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department.

ARTB 496.name: Capstone
ARTB 496.description: Students will engage in self-initiated research to demonstrate proficiency in three-dimensional arts.

ARTB 421R.name: Advanced Ceramic Sculpture
ARTB 421R.description: Continued investigation of sculpture with a focus on idea development and individual direction. This course will address clay preparation, clay finishing, and kiln firing.

ARTB 422R.name: Advanced Pottery
ARTB 422R.description: Continued investigation of utilitarian forms with a focus on idea development and individual direction. This course will address clay preparation, glazing, and kiln firing.

ARTC 232.name: Introduction to Performance Art
ARTC 232.description: Development of basic concepts and techniques for the creation of performance art.

ARTC 233.name: Animation I
ARTC 233.description: Development of basic concepts and techniques for the creation of animated works, including stop-motion, 2D animation, and key-framing.

ARTC 234.name: Introduction to Sound Art
ARTC 234.description: Development of basic concepts and techniques for the creation of sound art.

ARTC 235.name: Introduction to Digital Media and 16mm Film as Art
ARTC 235.description: Development of basic concepts and techniques for the creation of film as an art form.

ARTC 236.name: Introduction to Cinema and Video Art
ARTC 236.description: Development of basic concepts and techniques for the creation of works of cinema and video art.

ARTC 239.name: Special Topics in Four-Dimensional Arts
ARTC 239.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department.

ARTC 330.name: 4D Arts Concentration Progression Requirement Review
ARTC 330.description: Review of prior work in four-dimensional arts.

ARTC 333.name: Animation II
ARTC 333.description: Variable, in-depth techniques for the creation of animated works.

ARTC 340.name: Topics in Post-Production
ARTC 340.description: Content varies. Selected topics in film/video post-production with a shared emphasis on technical skills, creative approaches, and theoretical underpinnings. Topics may include, but are not limited to: editing, sound design, sound mixing, visual effects, color grading.

ARTC 391.name: Intermediate Four-Dimensional Arts
ARTC 391.description: Individual sections for various artistic disciplines.

ARTC 401.name: Experiments in Sequencing
ARTC 401.description: Advanced study and development of art or design works based on the concepts and techniques of sequencing.

ARTC 402.name: Experiments in Space
ARTC 402.description: Advanced study and development of art or design works based on the concepts and techniques of spatiality.

ARTC 403.name: Experiments in Systems
ARTC 403.description: Advanced study and development of art or design works based on systemic concepts and techniques.

ARTC 430.name: Internship
ARTC 430.description: On-site work experience in the media production field. Pre-approval in the 4D Arts Program required.

ARTC 431.name: The Business of Cinema
ARTC 431.description: Advanced study of motion picture producing and of the film and video industries.

ARTC 432.name: Advanced 4D Arts I
ARTC 432.description: Advanced study and development of concepts and techniques for the creation of time-arts works as an art form with an emphasis on individual projects.

ARTC 433.name: Animation III
ARTC 433.description: Development of individual projects in animation with an emphasis on conceptual challenges, personal expression and professional practices.

ARTC 435.name: Narrative Filmmaking
ARTC 435.description: Development of concepts and techniques for the creation of narrative films with an emphasis on individual projects.

ARTC 436.name: Video Art
ARTC 436.description: Continued development of concepts and techniques for the creation of video works as an art form with an emphasis on individual projects.

ARTC 439.name: Special Topics in Four-Dimensional Arts
ARTC 439.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department.

ARTC 495.name: Visiting Artist Seminar
ARTC 495.description: Study and discussion of contemporary art issues conducted by different visiting artists each semester.

ARTC 496.name: Capstone
ARTC 496.description: Students will engage in self-initiated research to demonstrate proficiency in four-dimensional arts.

ARTD 150.name: The Idea of Graphic Design
ARTD 150.description: An overview of design as visual message-making and as an act of cultural interpretation. Contemporary and historic design and its forms are examined, along with an introduction to design and creative concepts.

ARTD 251.name: Beginning Graphic Design I
ARTD 251.description: Introduction to the elements and principles of graphic design and concept development. Survey of design tools, materials, and processes. Emphasis on creative strategies for idea generation and the relationship of visual form and meaning.

ARTD 252.name: Beginning Graphic Design II
ARTD 252.description: Continued exploration into elements and principles of graphic design including in-depth study of visual theories and design vocabulary. Introduction to the role of design in contemporary culture.

ARTD 255.name: Graphic Design Production
ARTD 255.description: Traditional and computer-generated techniques for the production of print and digital media in graphic design. Introduction to computer systems, software, and techniques.

ARTD 350.name: Graphic Design Portfolio Review
ARTD 350.description: Review of prior work in graphic design.

ARTD 351.name: Intermediate Graphic Design I
ARTD 351.description: Intermediate study of graphic design including research methodologies and practices as they relate to the design process. In-depth investigations into audience and context in relationship to form and meaning.

ARTD 352.name: Intermediate Graphic Design II
ARTD 352.description: Continued intermediate study of graphic design with an emphasis on the visual, technical, and theoretical aspects of representing information and managing visual complexity.

ARTD 400.name: Typography
ARTD 400.description: Principles of typography, as well as classical and contemporary type forms, as vehicles for communication. An intensive introduction to the fundamentals of type, from individual letterforms to large bodies of textual information. Attention to formal, technological, rhetorical, and historical issues.

ARTD 405.name: Interaction Design
ARTD 405.description: Exploration of current technologies and their significance to interactive and screen-based design.

ARTD 410.name: Advanced Typographic Investigation
ARTD 410.description: Expands on principles introduced in Typography (ARTD 400). Projects will include work in reflective as well as electronic environments with an emphasis on personal exploration.

ARTD 425.name: Illustration
ARTD 425.description: Develops skills and critical analysis for effective visual communication. Projects will explore the relationship between image and meaning. Students will explore a variety of media as they develop a personal visual vocabulary.

ARTD 444.name: Graphic Design Research
ARTD 444.description: Active research investigations in faculty-led initiatives.

ARTD 450.name: Design in Culture
ARTD 450.description: A consideration of design as an act of cultural interpretation. Historic and contemporary design and design issues are examined through presentations, discussions, readings, and writings. Student assessment will come from writing, projects, presentations, and contributions to class discussion.

ARTD 451.name: Advanced Graphic Design
ARTD 451.description: Advanced design investigations into the theory and techniques of visual problem-solving as applied across many applications of design. Emphasis on the study of identity and systems.

ARTD 452.name: Graphic Design Capstone
ARTD 452.description: Student-led project under faculty direction including advanced application of research, project-development and execution. Includes individual presentations to professional panels.

ARTD 455.name: Graphic Design Professional Seminar
ARTD 455.description: Professional practices including client relationships, design management, and business practices. Assembly, organization, and editing of the professional portfolio.

ARTD 456.name: Graphic Design Practicum
ARTD 456.description: On-site, practical work designed to bridge the university experience with the workplace prior to graduation. Must be pre-arranged with the department.

ARTD 459.name: Intersections in Design
ARTD 459.description: Advanced investigations into the role of design in a broader context.

ARTD 495.name: Visiting Artist Seminar
ARTD 495.description: Study and discussion of contemporary art issues conducted by different visiting artists each semester.

ARTD 351R.name: Intermediate Graphic Design I
ARTD 351R.description: Intermediate study of graphic design including research methodologies and practices as they relate to the design process. In-depth investigations into audience and context in relationship to form and meaning.

ARTD 352R.name: Intermediate Graphic Design II
ARTD 352R.description: Continued intermediate study of graphic design with an emphasis on the visual, technical, and theoretical aspects of representing information and managing visual complexity.

ARTD 444R.name: Graphic Design Research
ARTD 444R.description: Active research investigations in faculty-led initiatives.

ARTD 452R.name: Graphic Design Capstone
ARTD 452R.description: Student-led project under faculty direction including advanced application of research, project-development and execution. Includes individual presentations to professional panels.

ARTH 152.name: Survey of Islamic Art
ARTH 152.description: Introduction to the arts of the Islamic lands from the beginnings of Islam on the Arabian Peninsula through their spread in the succeeding centuries and their impact on the increasingly global contemporary art world. Distinctive art and architecture of this tradition developed and explores the vibrant diversity that came to define its parameters by the advent of modernity. Islamic art across the globe, from the Indian Subcontinent, to Spain, to the Atlantic world.

ARTH 162.name: Art of Africa, Oceania, and Pre-Columbian America
ARTH 162.description: Survey of the traditional arts of the cultures of Black Africa, the Pacific and the Americas (focusing primarily on the period before the European conquest). Sculpture, painting, pottery, textiles, architecture, and human adornment will all be examined.

ARTH 167.name: Honors: Art of Africa, Oceania, and Pre-Columbian America
ARTH 167.description: Consent of instructor required. Survey of the traditional arts of the cultures of Black Africa, the Pacific and the Americas. Study grounded in reading, writing, and discussion.

ARTH 172.name: Western Art: Ancient through Medieval
ARTH 172.description: Major monuments in Western art with emphasis on Europe from antiquity through the Middle Ages.

ARTH 173.name: Western Art: Renaissance to Contemporary
ARTH 173.description: Major monuments in the history of European and American art from the Renaissance to the present.

ARTH 177.name: Honors Western Art: Ancient through Medieval
ARTH 177.description: Consent of Department required. Major monuments in Western art with emphasis on Europe from antiquity through the Middle Ages. Study grounded in reading, writing, and discussion.

ARTH 178.name: Honors Western Art: Renaissance to Contemporary
ARTH 178.description: Consent of Department required. Major monuments in the history of European and American art from the Renaissance to the present. Study grounded in reading, writing, and discussion.

ARTH 183.name: Asian Art
ARTH 183.description: Selected major monuments of South and East Asian art (archaeological material, sculpture, architecture, painting, prints) in their social, political, and religious contexts.

ARTH 187.name: Honors: Asian Art
ARTH 187.description: Consent of instructor required. Selected major monuments of South and East Asian art (archaeological material, sculpture, architecture, painting, prints) in their social, political, and religious contexts. Study grounded in reading, writing, and discussion.

ARTH 279.name: Special Topics in Art History
ARTH 279.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department.

ARTH 375.name: Seminar in Art History I
ARTH 375.description: Seminar for majors. Introduction to the practice and methodology of art history.

ARTH 402.name: Seminar in Art History II
ARTH 402.description: Seminar for majors. Builds on ARTH 375 but with an emphasis on research and effective written and oral presentation. Capstone class.

ARTH 403.name: History of Photography
ARTH 403.description: Survey of the history of photography from the introduction of the daguerreotype and calotype to more recent trends. Emphasis will be placed on aesthetics and the use of photography as a medium for artistic expression.

ARTH 405.name: Topics in Visual and Legal Culture
ARTH 405.description: Introduction to laws that govern creation, circulation, and criminalization of certain artworks. Highlights the often surprising ways in which images, objects, and laws knit together to create a form of social connective tissue – a finely grained network that simultaneously reflects and shapes its particular historical moment. Drawing on the methodologies of both art history and legal history, this course will challenge students to think critically about the visual arts, the legal system, and, ultimately, our cultural understanding of creativity itself.

ARTH 410.name: Art and Image in the Age of Pharaohs
ARTH 410.description: Explores four thousand years of Egyptian art form the building of the Great Pyramids and the splendor of the New Kingdom to the achievements of its Hellenistic successors and beyond. Focuses on royal monuments, images of life, death, and afterlife along the Nile, mummies and funerary art, religion and temples, sculpture, luxury arts as well as objects of everyday life.

ARTH 411.name: Art of South and Southeast Asia
ARTH 411.description: Survey of the art and architecture of the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia. The major achievements of each period are examined in relation to their religious, political, and social contexts.

ARTH 413.name: Art of China: Neolithic Period Through the Song Dynasty
ARTH 413.description: Survey of the art and architecture of China up through the 13th century including early bronze-casting, funerary arts, Buddhist arts, painting, and ceramics. Selected major monuments are examined in relation to their religious, political, and social contexts.

ARTH 414.name: Art of China: Yuan through Qing Dynasties
ARTH 414.description: Survey of the art and architecture of China from the fourteenth through the nineteenth centuries including painting, religious and secular architecture, woodblock prints, and ceramics. Selected major monuments are examined in relation to their religious, political, and social contexts.

ARTH 416.name: Chinese Art of the 20th and 21st Centuries
ARTH 416.description: Survey of Chinese art from the late 19th century through the present. Hong Kong, Taiwanese, and expatriate artists are also considered.

ARTH 419.name: Art of Japan
ARTH 419.description: Survey of the art and architecture of Japan from the Neolithic period to the 19th century. The major achievements of each period are examined in relation to their religious, political, and social contexts.

ARTH 421.name: Greek Art
ARTH 421.description: Achievements of Greek art in architectural decoration, sculpture, minor arts, and painting from their beginnings in the Geometric period, through the Classical periods of the fifth century BC, to their dissemination during the Hellenistic period across the Mediterranean, Europe, and the Near East. Special emphasis on stylistic developments, the contributions of known artists, and the relationship between art and various aspects of Greek life and thought.

ARTH 422.name: Roman Art
ARTH 422.description: Architecture, sculpture, and painting during the 1000+ years of Rome's cultural dominance from the hyper-realism of the Republic, to Classical beauty of the Augustan age, and abstract symbolism in Late Antiquity. Considers how adaptations of earlier traditions such as the Greek and Etruscan and the diverse artistic heritages encompassed within the empire fused into something new and substantially different than what had come before.

ARTH 425.name: Early Christian and Byzantine Art to 1350
ARTH 425.description: Art in Italy and the Eastern Empire from the beginnings of Christian art to c. 1350. Mosaic and painting, sculpture and architecture.

ARTH 431.name: Medieval Art of the West, 800-1400
ARTH 431.description: Western European art of the Dark Ages, Romanesque, and Gothic periods.

ARTH 433.name: History of Film and Modern and Contemporary Art
ARTH 433.description: Study of the development and interaction between the cinematic arts and the visual arts within the context of modern art history.

ARTH 441.name: Northern European Painting, 1350-1600
ARTH 441.description: Overview of art and material culture in the regions encompassed by present day France, Germany, and the Netherlands in the 14th through 16th centuries. Content includes new artistic genres and media such as oil painting and printmaking; the location and circulation of art (markets, sacred spaces, regionalism and internationalism, exchange with Italy); uses and conflicts over religious imagery, and the impact of the Protestant Reformation.

ARTH 443.name: Islamic Art in Global Context I: Medieval
ARTH 443.description: Explores the role of art and material culture in the development of Islam beginning with its establishment on the Arabian Peninsula in the seventh century. Focusing on cultural relationships with Roman religion, Christianity, and Judaism, we consider the interconnected nature of architectural and artistic milestones across the Mediterranean world and beyond, stretching from Spain and North Africa in the West to the Arabian Peninsula, Iraq, and Iran in the East.

ARTH 444.name: Islamic Art in Global Context II: Early Modern
ARTH 444.description: This course surveys the development of Islamic art and material culture during a critical period of change in the Islamic lands, the western Mediterranean, and the wider world from 1400 to 1800. It explores artistic, economic, and intellectual interchange between the Christian and Islamic lands from the European Renaissance up to the dominance of colonial and imperial powers.

ARTH 451.name: The Art of Italy, 1250-1450
ARTH 451.description: Surveys the significant artistic developments of the late middle ages through the beginning of the Renaissance in Italy, including the exploration of naturalism in Giotto's Arena Chapel, Alberti's theory of linear perspective, and Gentile Bellini's travels and work at the Ottoman court. Artists and monuments: Donatello, Piero della Francesca, Botticelli, Leaning Tower of Pisa, Brunelleschi's dome of the Florence Cathedral.

ARTH 452.name: Art of Italy, 1475-1600
ARTH 452.description: Surveys the height of the 're-birth' of the visual arts and the revival of classical antiquity now known as the Italian Renaissance. The 15th and 16th centuries witnessed landmark artistic, intellectual, and technological innovations such as humanism, the development of printmaking, the rise of the artist as genius, and the discipline of art history itself. Artists include Leonardo da Vinci, Raphael, Michelangelo, Titian, and Palladio.

ARTH 453.name: Art of Southern Europe, 1575-1700
ARTH 453.description: Concentrated study of Caravaggio, Bernini, and Italian Baroque developments in all media. Spanish Baroque painting and sculpture with special attention to Velazquez.

ARTH 455.name: The Global Renaissance
ARTH 455.description: Surveys art at the crossroads of exchange encounters in the 15th and 16th centuries and introduces intellectual models for approaching art in the early modern world that pay attention to both global forces and power structures such as trade, religion, and colonialism, but also indigenous epistemologies and identities.

ARTH 456.name: Global Baroque Art and Architecture
ARTH 456.description: Introduces students to the diverse artistic production of the seventeenth century across the globe, not only in conversation with artistic developments in 16th-century Italy, but also against a backdrop of an expanding political and geographic world, including artistic and architectural centers across the globe, such as Cusco, Goa, Macau, Mexico City, and Nagasaki.

ARTH 461.name: Art of Southern and Eastern Africa
ARTH 461.description: Art traditions of the eastern and southern regions of Africa. Sculpture, painting, pottery, textiles, architecture, and human adornment will be examined. Some ancient Stone and Iron Age traditions will be examined, but the main emphasis will be on the diverse ethnic and regional art traditions practiced in the area from the 19th century to the present.

ARTH 462.name: Art and Archaeology of Ancient Africa
ARTH 462.description: Historical art traditions of sub-Sahara Africa. Topics to be covered include prehistoric rock paintings, art from archaeological sites and ancient kingdoms. The time period covered ranges from the first and second millennia BC for some of the early terracotta sculpture and rock paintings, the 11th through 19th centuries AD for the later ancient kingdoms.

ARTH 463.name: Arts of the African Diaspora
ARTH 463.description: Examines the aesthetic, philosophical, and religious patterns of the African descendants of Brazil, Surinam, the Caribbean, and the United States.
