Emphasis will be placed on the full range of art forms, including the sculptural and performance traditions, as well as architecture, textile, basketry, and pottery art forms.

ARTH 464.name: Oceanic Art
ARTH 464.description: Concentrated study of selected sculpture, textiles, architecture, and other traditional art forms of Polynesia, Micronesia, and Melanesia. Objects are discussed on the basis of style, style relationship, iconography and the uses to which they were put in their traditional religious, political, and social contexts.

ARTH 470.name: African American Art
ARTH 470.description: Traces the artistic and social legacy of African American art from the eighteenth century to the present day. Specifically, this class will focus on the ways in which artists used creativity to confront, deny, or complicate understandings of racial identity and racism. Examines broad scope of artistic production including painting, sculpture, photography, multi-media, fiction writing, and video art.

ARTH 472.name: History of 20th-Century American Art
ARTH 472.description: Developments in architecture, painting, and design from 1900.

ARTH 473.name: 19th-Century American Art
ARTH 473.description: Examines painting, sculpture, and print culture from the Revolutionary War to the turn of the 20th century.

ARTH 474.name: Transatlantic Modernism
ARTH 474.description: American-European artistic exchange during the first three decades of the 20th century leading to the creation of an art that was both modern and American. Considers Alfred Stieglitz, Georgia O'Keeffe, Gerald Murphy, Marsden Hartley, Gertrude Stein, Josephine Baker, Arthur Dove, Marcel Duchamp, and others.

ARTH 475.name: History of 19th-Century Art in Europe
ARTH 475.description: The evolution of Romanticism, Neoclassicism, and Realism in Europe, including the innovations of Manet, Impressionism, Cezanne, Post-Impressionism, Art Nouveau, and Symbolism.

ARTH 476.name: History of 20th-Century Art in Europe
ARTH 476.description: Development of the Modern and Post-Modern movements in Europe. Investigation of the progression of abstraction through more recent conceptual trends. Analysis of the work of individual artists such as Picasso, Matisse, and many others.

ARTH 479.name: Special Topics in Art History
ARTH 479.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department.

ARTH 483.name: History of Museums and Collections
ARTH 483.description: This course will introduce students to the history of collections, exhibitions, and museums through the history of systems of collecting and display from antiquity to the present. Readings will confront theoretical and methodological issues related to historiography, ethnography, and ethics. In addition to covering the history of museums, the course will relate history and theory to the major concerns of contemporary institutions and galleries.

ARTM 379.name: Special Topics in Museum Studies
ARTM 379.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department.

ARTM 479.name: Special Topics in Museum Studies
ARTM 479.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department.

ARTM 490.name: Introduction to Museum Studies
ARTM 490.description: Overview of museum and/or gallery work in contemporary society. May consider history, governance, financial structure, exhibitions, collections, education, development, and guest services.

ARTN 101.name: Non-Major Introduction to Studio Art: Surface
ARTN 101.description: An introduction to the elements and principles of design using a variety of media. Studio projects, lectures and discussion will explore how the principles of design transcend media. Readings and discussion will inform how to analyze and critique contemporary art. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to studio art mark making with a concentration on surface development.

ARTN 102.name: Non-Major Introduction to Art: Time
ARTN 102.description: An introduction to the elements and principles of creating time-based arts using a variety of media. Studio projects, lectures and discussion will explore film, video, animation, sound, and associated disciplines. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to time-based art.

ARTN 103.name: Non-Major Introduction to Art: Space
ARTN 103.description: An introduction to elements and principles of design using a variety of media. Studio projects, lectures and discussion will explore how the principles of design transcend media. Readings and discussion will inform how to analyze and critique contemporary art. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to form and space in studio art.

ARTN 211.name: Non-Major Intro to Drawing
ARTN 211.description: Development of drawing skills from a variety of sources including life drawing. Projects will emphasize composition, technique, and content. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to drawing.

ARTN 213.name: Non-Major Intro to Painting
ARTN 213.description: Capacities of oil and acrylic painting on canvas. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to painting.

ARTN 221.name: Non-Major Intro to Ceramic Sculpture
ARTN 221.description: Introduction to sculptural formats with a focus on ideas and ceramic process. This course will address clay preparation, clay finishing, and kiln firing. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to ceramic sculpture.

ARTN 222.name: Non-Major Intro to Pottery
ARTN 222.description: Introduction to clay with an emphasis on utilitarian form. This course will address pottery wheel techniques, clay preparation, glazing and kiln firing. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to ceramic pottery.

ARTN 231.name: Non-Major Intro to Photography
ARTN 231.description: Introduction to the art of photography. Taking and processing of photographs through both traditional film/darkroom and digital. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to photography.

ARTN 232.name: Non-Major Intro to Performance and Sound
ARTN 232.description: Development of basic concepts and techniques for the creation of performance and sound art. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to performance and sound art.

ARTN 239.name: Non-Major Intro to Special Topics in Four-Dimensional
ARTN 239.description: Student- or instructor-initiated course offered at convenience of department for non-art majors.

ARTN 241.name: Non-Major Intro to Sculpture
ARTN 241.description: Introduction to the materials, concepts, technical processes, and history of sculpture. Materials include wood, plaster, steel, and plastics. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to sculpture.

ARTN 262.name: Non-Major Intro to Intaglio
ARTN 262.description: Metal plate intaglio printing in traditional and contemporary techniques of etching, soft ground, drypoint, aquatint, and color methods. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to intaglio printing.

ARTN 263.name: Non-Major Intro to Lithography
ARTN 263.description: Stone and aluminum plate lithography applying traditional and contemporary techniques of crayon, tusche, transfer methods, state proofs, and photolithography. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to lithography.

ARTN 264.name: Non-Major Intro to Screen Printing
ARTN 264.description: Screen printing as a fine art medium including development and application of various basic stencils in compositional printing. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to screen printing.

ARTN 265.name: Non-Major Intro to Relief
ARTN 265.description: Relief printing in traditional and contemporary techniques from wood, linoleum, and plastics. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to relief printing.

ARTN 266.name: Non-Major Introduction to Monoprint and Monotype
ARTN 266.description: Investigations of traditional and contemporary techniques exploring the variable print using intaglio, relief and lithographic processes.

ARTN 291.name: Non-Major Intro to Book Arts and Papermaking
ARTN 291.description: Book arts and papermaking as a medium for two- and three-dimensional art. Emphasis on development of a personal form. This section is for non-art majors who would like an introduction to book arts and papermaking.

ASL 111.name: Elementary American Sign Language I
ASL 111.description: Development of expressive and receptive sign language skills. Video text and interactive teaching method used. Class conducted totally in sign.

ASL 112.name: Elementary American Sign Language II
ASL 112.description: Development of expressive and receptive sign language skills. Video text and interactive teaching method used. Class conducted totally in sign.

ASL 211.name: Intermediate American Sign Language I
ASL 211.description: Sequence (ASL 211*-ASL 212*) stresses fluency of expressive and receptive sign language skills. Using language in context is emphasized. Grammatical structures of ASL and cultural implications of the Deaf Community.

ASL 212.name: Intermediate American Sign Language II
ASL 212.description: Sequence (ASL 211*-ASL 212*) stresses fluency of expressive and receptive sign language skills. Using language in context is emphasized. Grammatical structures of ASL and cultural implications of the Deaf Community in the United States and other countries internationally.

ASL 310.name: Practicum
ASL 310.description: Supervised practicum. Bilingual teaching, and social justice theory and practice. Lesson planning.

ASL 311.name: Advanced American Sign Language I: Educational Contexts
ASL 311.description: This course emphasizes advanced expressive and receptive American Sign Language skills in an educational context. Review of grammatical structures. Students will learn and demonstrate communication skills appropriate to deaf-related professions.

ASL 410.name: Practicum
ASL 410.description: Supervised practicum. Planning social justice oriented units for the ASL/English bilingual classroom.

ASL 421.name: History and Culture of the Deaf
ASL 421.description: Comprehensive overview of historical and socio-cultural aspects of the Deaf. Students will explore beliefs, theories, and evidence about the historical experience of Deaf people; the influence of geographic, cultural, educational, and economic forces on Deaf people; concepts and implications of disability theory; social and medical models as ways of defining the Deaf population; demographics including the various subcultures and under-represented groups in the larger Deaf community; impact of Deaf education on the history and organizational structure of the Deaf community.

ASL 422.name: Deaf Literature and ASL Folklore
ASL 422.description: This course provides an opportunity for ASL students to explore various genres of literature by and about d/Deaf people. Concentrates on d/Deaf characters and the influences of Deaf culture and Deaf history on literacy works from early 1900s to the present. There will be extensive use of videotaped materials. The course content will include viewing and discussing works performed by Deaf poets, writers, dramatists, and storytellers. Taught in ASL.

ASL 435.name: Linguistics of American Sign Language
ASL 435.description: Introduction to grammatical and linguistic structures of ASL. Language variations, discourse, bilingualism, and language contact also covered. Conducted in ASL.

ASL 445.name: Teaching of American Sign Language: Grade Pre K-5
ASL 445.description: ACTFL standards-based pedagogy, research, assessment, curricula, and instructional materials for the Pre K-5 ASL classroom.

ASST 301.name: South Asian Cinema: Bollywood and Beyond
ASST 301.description: Introduces classic, Bollywood, and diasporic South Asian film. Presents films beloved by diverse audiences across the globe for their entertainment values but that also pose questions of identity, nationalism, and modernity. Examines why the storytelling in the films viewed is so compelling and how the films are situated in the social, cultural, and historical contexts in which they were created.

ASTR 151.name: A Journey through the Solar System Lecture
ASTR 151.description: Study of Earth's nearest astronomical neighbors, including the sun, planets, asteroids, and comets. Seasons, solar and lunar eclipses, motion of the planets in the night sky, recent planetary space probe discoveries, development of our modern understanding of the origin and evolution of our solar system and its place in the universe, discovery of extrasolar planets in distant solar systems. A minimum of mathematical analysis.

ASTR 152.name: Stars, Galaxies, and Cosmology Lecture
ASTR 152.description: Life and death of stars, exotic objects including white dwarfs, supernovae, neutron stars, pulsars, and black holes. Structure of galaxies, formation of large-scale structure in the universe, and cosmological issues such as the big bang, dark matter, dark energy, and the past, present, and projected future behavior of the universe in light of modern astrophysics and particle physics. Conditions for the existence of life in the universe and the possibility of extraterrestrial intelligence. A minimum of mathematical analysis.

ASTR 153.name: A Journey through the Solar System Lab
ASTR 153.description: Principles for interpretation of astronomical observations are reinforced in laboratory. ASTR 151* and ASTR 153* must both be completed to earn credit for a single semester of laboratory-based astronomy.

ASTR 154.name: Stars, Galaxies, and Cosmology Lab
ASTR 154.description: Principles for interpretation of astronomical observations are reinforced in laboratory. ASTR 152* and ASTR 154* must both be completed to earn credit for a single semester of laboratory-based astronomy.

ASTR 217.name: Honors: Introductory Astronomy
ASTR 217.description: Introduction to astronomy and astrophysics. Historical perspectives in understanding the celestial universe with emphasis on the laws of physics as they apply to the changing conceptions of the universe; structure of the solar system and celestial motions; evolution and properties of stars; galactic structure and models of the universe; observational technique and interpretation of underlying physical laws in accompanying lab. The ASTR 217*-ASTR 218* sequence satisfies the College of Arts and Sciences' requirement for a natural science with laboratory.

ASTR 218.name: Honors: Introductory Astronomy
ASTR 218.description: Introduction to astronomy and astrophysics. Historical perspectives in understanding the celestial universe, with emphasis on the laws of physics as they apply to the changing conceptions of the universe; structure of the solar system and celestial motions; evolution and properties of stars; galactic structure and models of the universe; observational technique and interpretation of underlying physical laws in accompanying lab. The ASTR 217*-ASTR 218* sequence satisfies the College of Arts and Sciences' requirement for a natural science with laboratory.

ASTR 411.name: Stellar Structure and Stellar Evolution
ASTR 411.description: An introduction to stars and the physical principles governing stellar structure and stellar evolution. Topics include equations of state for stars, hydrostatic equilibrium, energy production and energy transport in stars, the birth of stars, extrasolar planets, main sequence stars, solar neutrinos and neutrino oscillations, red giants and post mainsequence evolution, pulsating variable stars, white dwarfs, neutron stars and pulsars, accretion in binary star systems, novae, X-ray bursts, supernovae, and production of the elements in various stellar processes.

ASTR 421.name: General Relativity, Black Holes, and Cosmology
ASTR 421.description: An introduction to the general theory of relativity and its application to issues of current interest in astronomy and astrophysics. Topics include a review of special relativity, the equivalence principle and principle of general covariance, the mathematics (tensor calculus) of general relativity, the geometry of spacetime, motion of particles and light in flat and curved spacetime, spherical and rotating black holes, neutron stars and pulsars, gamma-ray bursts, quasars, gravitational waves, and current topics in modern cosmology: dark matter, dark energy, and the expanding and accelerating Universe; the big bang, the cosmic microwave background radiation, the theory of inflation; and the Planck scale and quantum gravity.

ASTR 490.name: Special Topics in Astronomy
ASTR 490.description: Topics of current interest in astronomy and astrophysics.

AUSP 300.name: Introduction to Communication Disorders
AUSP 300.description: Nature, etiology, and incidence of speech, hearing, and language disorders.

AUSP 302.name: Acoustics and Perception
AUSP 302.description: Basic acoustics. Introduction to psychoacoustics and speech perception.

AUSP 303.name: Introduction to Hearing Science
AUSP 303.description: Introduction to disorders of hearing. Fundamental aspects of auditory anatomy and physiology.

AUSP 305.name: Phonetics
AUSP 305.description: Basic phonetics, including recognition and production of spoken English sounds with analysis of their formation, phonetic transcription of speech, phonetic aspects of dialect variation.

AUSP 306.name: Anatomy and Physiology of Speech
AUSP 306.description: Anatomy, physiology, and embryological development of the speech production mechanism.

AUSP 320.name: Speech and Language Development
AUSP 320.description: Speech and language development in the normal child.

AUSP 435.name: Introduction to Speech Sound Disorders
AUSP 435.description: Etiology, diagnosis, and treatment of articulatory and phonological disorders.

AUSP 453.name: Diagnostics in Audiology and Speech-Language
AUSP 453.description: Information about basic assessment tools and procedures in speech-language pathology and audiology.

AUSP 455.name: Introduction to Adult Speech and Language Disorders
AUSP 455.description: Introduction to the neural bases for adult communication disorders.

AUSP 457.name: Senior Honors Thesis
AUSP 457.description: Students in the speech pathology program work individually under the direction of a tenure-track faculty member to write an honors thesis. The thesis must be approved by the departmental honors committee.

AUSP 461.name: Introduction to Language Pathology in Children
AUSP 461.description: Etiology, diagnosis, and treatment of language impairments in children.

AUSP 494.name: Introduction to Aural Habilitation/Rehabilitation of the Hearing Impaired
AUSP 494.description: Introduction to psychosocial aspects, amplification components/characteristics, assistive devices, speech acoustics, speech perception, speech reading, parent-infant, pre-school and school years of children, communication impairments/handicaps/remediation of adults, effects of aging/remediation on the elderly, and case studies.

AUSP 499.name: Senior Seminar in Communication Sciences and Disorders
AUSP 499.description: Capstone experience. A writing-emphasis course exploring the forces shaping the profession of communication disorders in the past, present and future.

BAS 310.name: Analytic Models for Decision Optimization
BAS 310.description: Analytical approaches for generating solutions to optimization problems, decision models, and queuing systems. Linear and integer programming, decision making under uncertainty, Monte Carlo simulation, and waiting line models. Formulation, solution, analysis, and interpretation of spreadsheet-based models for common business decision-making situations such as supply chain network design, portfolio analysis, scheduling, media mix, and product mix decisions.

BAS 320.name: Regression Modeling
BAS 320.description: Simple linear regression and correlation analysis, time series analysis, multiple regression, variable selection, regression diagnostics, partial correlation, and categorical data analysis techniques. Use of statistical computing software. Applied course appropriate for a general audience.

BAS 340.name: Experimental Methods and Process Improvement
BAS 340.description: Statistical methods for process improvement. Special/common cause model of variation directed towards understanding sources of variation affecting process operations. Strategies of process experimentation, including randomization, blocking, sequential experimentation, and replication. Use of statistical computing software.

BAS 370.name: Search Advertising Optimization
BAS 370.description: Creating, managing, and optimizing Google Ads search advertising campaigns for a local nonprofit. Fundamentals of online advertising metrics and best practices for data-driven improvement of campaigns. Emphasis on communicating data insights to a non-technical audience. Assessment takes place via official Google Ads certification exams, allowing for the option of obtaining Google Ads certifications.

BAS 454.name: Statistics for Business Analysts
BAS 454.description: Application of statistical tools in the context of business problems. Data management, ANOVA, regression, predictive modeling, model performance. Use of SAS software. Preparation for SAS certification exam.

BAS 464.name: Operations Analytics
BAS 464.description: Operations Analytics focuses on data-driven decision making in operations management. Through a case-based, interactive, learning-by-doing approach, students learn a systematic set of analytics methodologies and apply various analytics tools such as spreadsheets, data visualization, optimization, and simulation, to make important operations decisions from large datasets.

BAS 471.name: Statistical Methods
BAS 471.description: Numeric and graphic description of data, probability and probability distributions, simulation, and sampling distributions. Estimation and hypothesis testing for one and two samples, parametric and nonparametric approaches, bootstrapping, and randomization tests. Multiple linear regression review and further issues, diagnostics and validation, and analysis of count data. Data Screening. Use of SAS and other statistical software.

BAS 474.name: Data Mining and Business Analytics
BAS 474.description: Understanding and application of data mining methods. Data preparation, exploratory data analysis and visualization, cluster analysis, logistic regression, decision trees, neural networks, association rules, model assessment, and other topics. Applications to real world data. Use of standard computer packages.

BAS 475.name: Applied Time Series and Forecasting
BAS 475.description: Model building techniques for linear time series models, practical methods for univariate time series forecasting, Box-Jenkins forecasting methods, forecasting based on exponential smoothing, autoregression and stepwise autoregression, and forecasting from regression models. Use of standard computing packages. Major writing requirement.

BAS 476.name: Data Engineering and Visualization
BAS 476.description: Fundamentals of programming using Python with particular focus on data preparation, visualization, and data understanding. Topics include but are not limited to reading data, object-oriented programming, loops, conditional processing, aggregating, merging, and dynamic visualization. Experience gained in producing repeatable data products in Python that automatically ingest, process, and display data in interactive plots.

BAS 479.name: Capstone for Business Analytics
BAS 479.description: Case studies in business analytics illustrating various aspects of descriptive, predictive, and prescriptive modeling. Strong emphasis on data preparation and statistical programming using SQL, R, and/or other standard software along with writing and presentation skills.

BAS 492.name: Internship
BAS 492.description: Supervised off-campus experience in application of statistical principles and methods in business, industry, or government, culminating in a written and oral report.

BAS 493.name: Independent Study
BAS 493.description: Faculty directed reading and investigation of specified topic in probability or statistics culminating in a written report.

BAS 494.name: Quantitative Research in Business Analytics
BAS 494.description: Business analytics and statistics research under direction of a faculty member.

BAS 370S.name: Search Advertising Optimization
BAS 370S.description: Creating, managing, and optimizing Google Ads search advertising campaigns for a local nonprofit. Fundamentals of online advertising metrics and best practices for data-driven improvement of campaigns. Emphasis on communicating data insights to a non-technical audience. Assessment takes place via official Google Ads certification exams, allowing for the option of obtaining Google Ads certifications.

BAS 494R.name: Quantitative Research in Business Analytics
BAS 494R.description: Business analytics and statistics research under direction of a faculty member.

BCMB 200.name: Introduction to Research in Biochemistry and Cellular and Molecular Biology
BCMB 200.description: Participation in an active research program in biochemistry, cellular or molecular biology. Students work with researchers to acquire expertise in laboratory practices, planning experiments, interpreting results, and formulating hypotheses.

BCMB 230.name: Human Physiology
BCMB 230.description: Fundamentals of human physiology, primarily from the perspective of cellular and organ-system interactions.

BCMB 311.name: Advanced Cellular Biology
BCMB 311.description: Cellular structure and function at the molecular and supramolecular level. Topics include protein structure and function, membrane structure and function, signal transduction and cell regulation, mitosis and the cell cycle, cytoskeleton and cell motility, cell-cell interactions and tissues.

BCMB 321.name: Introductory Plant Physiology
BCMB 321.description: Cell and organismal physiology of plants, metabolic processes, water relations, mineral nutrition, morphogenesis. Effects of age, light, natural rhythms, temperature, and other environmental factors on plant growth.

BCMB 322.name: Plant Physiology and Molecular Biology Lab
BCMB 322.description: Experiments on topics discussed in BCMB 321.

BCMB 330.name: Mechanisms of Development
BCMB 330.description: A survey course on cellular and molecular basis of embryonic development, differentiation via transcription, RNA processing and translation, sex determination in humans.

BCMB 333.name: Structural Biology and Human Health
BCMB 333.description: Structure of biomolecules and structural basis of health-related conditions and pharmaceuticals. Topics include fundamentals and experimental aspects of protein structure and function, medical conditions related to molecular structural variations and structural approaches to drug discovery and drug design.

BCMB 401.name: Biochemistry I
BCMB 401.description: First semester of a two-course sequence. Covers amino acid and protein structure and chemistry, protein folding, enzyme reactions mechanisms, carbohydrate and lipid structure, function and metabolism, photosynthesis and carbon fixation, membrane biochemistry, thermodynamics of biological systems, vitamins and coenzymes, citric acid cycle and oxidative phosphorylation, and signal transduction.

BCMB 402.name: Biochemistry II
BCMB 402.description: Second semester of a two-course sequence. Covers membrane lipid metabolism, amino acid metabolism and protein turnover, nitrogen fixation, nucleotide metabolism, nucleic acid structure, integration of metabolism and hormonal signaling, experimental methods of analyzing nucleic acids, DNA replication and repair, chromosome structure and function, RNA and protein synthesis, and control of gene expression.

BCMB 403.name: Neurogenetics Laboratory
BCMB 403.description: Experiments and lectures illustrating methods in modern genetics and neurobiology using model organisms, especially Drosophila or Caenorhabditis elegans.

BCMB 405.name: Biophysical Chemistry
BCMB 405.description: Covers (1) thermodynamics; free energy; entropy and enthalpy; chemical equilibrium; solution chemistry; protein folding; DNA melting; protein-ligand association; phase transition; (2) enzymatics; protonation and electron transport. (3) Molecular Structure and Interaction (3a) Theory: Quantum theory, Duality principle, Wave Equation, Single atom model, (3b) Applications: Simulated Molecular Dynamics. Spectroscopy (UV-Vis, Raman, Fluorescence, Circular dichroism, NMR), X-ray diffraction and scattering.

BCMB 409.name: Perspectives in Biochemistry and Cellular and Molecular Biology
BCMB 409.description: Current issues in biochemistry, cell biology, and molecular biology. Emphasis on current developments and their applications, societal and economic impacts, and moral and ethical implications. An oral presentation and a referenced library-research essay are required. A capstone course.

BCMB 412.name: Molecular Biology and Genomics
BCMB 412.description: Nucleic acid structure and DNA technology. Mechanisms of cell division, replication, transcription, translation, splicing, recombination, DNA repair and transposition, chromosome organization, DNA-protein interaction in gene regulation, genomic imprinting, epigenetics, RNA interference, and genome evolution.

BCMB 415.name: Foundations in Neurobiology
BCMB 415.description: Basic nerve cell physiology, nervous system organization, sensory and motor systems, neural basis of behavior, and nervous system development and plasticity.

BCMB 416.name: Neurobiology Laboratory
BCMB 416.description: Experiments designed to illustrate concepts of modern neurobiology using electrophysiological, historical, and behavioral neurobiological techniques.

BCMB 419.name: Cellular and Comparative Biochemistry Laboratory
BCMB 419.description: Experiments on protein structure, protein function, nucleic acids, and membranes/organelles using chromatography, protein purification, electrophoresis, immunochemical, and recombinant DNA methodologies.

BCMB 420.name: Advanced Topics in Biochemistry and Cellular and Molecular Biology
BCMB 420.description: Selected topics of current research interest in the areas of biochemistry, enzymology, structural biology, molecular biology and genetics, cellular and developmental biology, neurobiology, endocrinology, bioenergetics, computational biology, plant biology, etc. Emphasis on original literature and the experimental basis of current knowledge. Historical background, societal impact, ethical and moral implications, and future development of technologies.

BCMB 422.name: Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
BCMB 422.description: An introduction to the cutting-edge tools and approaches biologists and clinicians use to extract information from the vast amounts of genomic and proteomic data becoming available. Students gain hands-on experience with computational biology tools such as data mining, protein structure manipulation and prediction, interaction network analysis, DNA sequence analysis, gene function analysis, R studio for statistics and data visualization, and dimensionality reduction for large datasets. Students apply these tools to biomedical research questions in course projects.

BCMB 423.name: Neural Basis of Behavior
BCMB 423.description: Structural and functional organization of neural circuits mediating fundamental aspects of behavior including the acquisition, control and processing of sensory information; control and coordination of movement; spatial orientation and navigation; learning and memory.

BCMB 424.name: Programming for Statistical and Graphical Analysis of Biological Data
BCMB 424.description: This is a hands-on introductory programming course with the emphasis on analyzing and visualizing biological data. The course will cover basic programming concepts including core data types, functions, flow control, modules, classes and interactions with files. It will also introduce popular libraries for numerical computing, data analysis, machine learning and scientific plotting. Toy examples in areas of structural biology, cell imaging, transcriptomics, genomics and systems biology will be used. Students are encouraged to bring their own data analysis/modeling projects to the course and work on them as a part of the graded component. Upon completing the course, students will be able to use programming tools to perform data analysis, to make publication quality plots, and to learn advanced computational methods with the help of coding. Python will be used as the primary programming language of the course.

BCMB 433.name: Analytical Techniques in Human Disease
BCMB 433.description: This is a 3-credit hour course on a quantitative study of biological matter in health and disease. Coursework will be on select methods of biophysical chemistry and structural biology that include Diffraction and Scattering, Spectroscopy, and Computational Biology that are routinely used to understand the basis of ailments, and for pharmacology and therapy.

BCMB 440.name: General Physiology
BCMB 440.description: Principles of cellular and organ-system animal physiology.

BCMB 452.name: Independent Research in Biochemistry and Cellular and Molecular Biology
BCMB 452.description: Special experimental problems under direction of a faculty member.

BCMB 455.name: Scientific Communication
BCMB 455.description: Focus on oral communication of scientific information. Construct and effectively deliver seminar-style scientific presentations with skillful use of language and visual aids.

BCMB 457.name: Honors Thesis
BCMB 457.description: Written presentation of faculty-supervised student research.

BCMB 459.name: Biophysical Crystallography
BCMB 459.description: Theories and practices of X-ray diffraction, neutron diffraction and neutron scattering to elucidate the structure of nucleic acids, proteins, nucleosomes, ribosomes and viruses. Application of 3-D structures in designing drugs against AIDS, cancer, cardiac disease and neurodegenerative disorders.

BCMB 461.name: Cancer Biology
BCMB 461.description: A comprehensive view of cancer. Topics include the basic mechanism of cancer formation and metastasis, animal models for studying cancer, microbes and cancer, with possible clinical rounds with oncologists. The class will be taught through lectures, videos, and possible "experiential" learning through UT's Cancer Center.

BCMB 493.name: Independent Study
BCMB 493.description: Independent study under the direction of a faculty member.

BCMB 452R.name: Independent Research in Biochemistry and Cellular and Molecular Biology
BCMB 452R.description: Special experimental problems under direction of a faculty member.

BCPP 101.name: Introduction to Public Policy
BCPP 101.description: Required of and restricted to first-year students in the Baker Center Living and Learning Community. Exploration of the basic characteristics of the public policy making system and process, as well as a set of current policy problems.

BCPP 102.name: Freshman Seminar
BCPP 102.description: Required of and restricted to first-year students in the Baker Center Living and Learning Community. Acquisition of policy analysis skills through participation within groups in development of a proposal to address a current public policy issue. Enrichment of students' experience through exposure to guest lecturers, exploration of career opportunities, and participation in co-curricular activities related to the field of public policy.

BCPP 317.name: Baker Scholars Seminar
BCPP 317.description: Required of and restricted to Baker Scholars. Support of Scholars' professional development and progress on their required projects. Instruction on the philosophy of research and methodologies relevant to the field of public policy. Review of examples of public policy research. Exploration of internship and career opportunities.

BCPP 480.name: Policy Process and Program Evaluation
BCPP 480.description: Provides an introduction to policy research and research design, such as benefit/cost analysis, experiments, surveys, linear regression, and basic data visualization with emphasis on skills related to gathering, managing, processing, presenting, and interpreting data. Application of these analytical tools to concrete public policy issues, affording students the opportunity to examine specific policy questions in depth and develop solutions and recommendations. Ability to identify and analyze public policy using a range of tools. Communication of the results of applied policy research work in writing through the development of a professional portfolio.

BCPP 481.name: Advanced Policy Process and Program Evaluation
BCPP 481.description: Provides an introduction to emerging policy analytical methods and tools, such as interval regression using Stata, data collection technology (e.g., Python, Machine Learning), and geographic data visualization/analysis (e.g., ArcGIS). Application of these analytical tools to concrete public policy issues, affording students the opportunity to examine specific policy questions in depth and develop solutions and recommendations. Development of project management skills; acquisition of expertise in research, including the gathering, visualization, and analysis of data; and cultivation and honing of presentation and communication skills. Communication of the results of applied policy research work in writing through the development of a professional portfolio.

BCPP 490.name: Policy Capstone
BCPP 490.description: Application of analytical tools to a concrete public policy issue, affording students the opportunity to examine a specific policy question in depth and develop solutions and recommendations pro bono for a real client. Development of project management skills; acquisition of expertise in research, including the gathering, visualization, and analysis of data; and cultivation and honing of presentation and communication skills. Capstone may be done on an individual or team basis.

BCPP 495.name: Special Topics in Public Policy
BCPP 495.description: Seminar addressing an area of study or current issue within the field of public policy.

BCPP 497.name: Baker Scholars Project
BCPP 497.description: Restricted to Baker Scholars. Completion of a research thesis investigating a specific public policy issue or implementation of a creative initiative that contributes toward understanding of public policy issues, improved governance, civic engagement, or public service.

BIOL 100.name: Discovering Biology at UT
BIOL 100.description: Intended for new UT students (first-year or transfer), interested in majoring in biology. Discovering Biology at UT will introduce students to the biology degree, and explore the 4 concentrations to help students decide if biology is the right major for them. Additionally, students will practice study strategies specific to introductory biology courses (but applicable to ALL classes) to help them learn effectively in the large classroom. Finally, this course will introduce students to a variety of STEM-specific co-curriculars including undergraduate lab research. By the end of this course, students will have vision of their life as a biology major at UT and a tool kit of academic and social support resources, that will prepare them to reach their STEM goals.

BIOL 101.name: Introduction to Biology: Cells, Genetics, and Physiology
BIOL 101.description: For non-biology majors, introduction to the principles of biology as they relate to cellular and organismal level processes. Topics include cell structure and major fundamental metabolic processes such as energy flow in biological systems, protein synthesis, and aspects of genetics. Includes a survey of human anatomy and physiology with topics relating to human health.

BIOL 102.name: Introduction to Biology: Biodiversity and Ecology
BIOL 102.description: For non-biology majors, introduction to the principles of biology as they relate to biodiversity and ecological processes. Topics include a survey of evolutionary theory, an analysis of major representative organisms in the Tree of Life, and ecosystem dynamics including human impact on the environment.

BIOL 105.name: Parasites, Pathogens, and Pandemics: Infectious Disease and Society
BIOL 105.description: Explores the nature of human infectious disease, including diseases such as bubonic plague, tuberculosis, malaria, AIDS, influenza, and Ebola, and non-human diseases and zoonoses. How diseases emerge and spread, how they can be controlled, and what diseases may shape future life on the planet (zombie apocalypse?) will also be discussed.

BIOL 106.name: The Living City
BIOL 106.description: More than half the world's population lives in cities and is directly involved in ecological and evolutionary processes governing urban environments. Cities are unique ecosystems that develop novel organismal communities, alter weather patterns, and concentrate resources. The course will investigate urban ecosystems, and the health and financial implications for people.

BIOL 113.name: Introductory Plant Biology I
BIOL 113.description: Introduction to the principles of plant biology including cell biology, respiration, photosynthesis, genetics (including mitosis, meiosis, Mendelian inheritance, gene expression) and classification and diversity of the prokaryotes, fungi, protista, and plant kingdoms.

BIOL 114.name: Introductory Plant Biology II
BIOL 114.description: Topics include plant anatomy, growth and nutrition, mechanisms of evolution, speciation, ecology (population, community, and ecosystem), and the interactions between plants and people (including origin of agriculture, the Green Revolution, genetic modification, plants as medicines, and a survey of current environmental issues related to plant biology).

BIOL 115.name: Introductory Plant Biology Laboratory
BIOL 115.description: Laboratory work will analyze plant structure, morphology, and function, with an emphasis on methods for observation, identification, and data collection. The discussion will focus on skills of biological experimentation, including designing experiments, analyzing data, reading scientific figures, and scientific communication.

BIOL 150.name: Organismal and Ecological Biology
BIOL 150.description: Intended for science majors, an introduction to the major biological concepts emphasizing the organismal and ecological aspects of life. Organized along themes of evolution, structure and function, information flow, exchange and storage, pathways of energy and matter, and systems.

BIOL 158.name: Honors: Organismal and Ecological Biology
BIOL 158.description: Same as BIOL 150* but designed for high achieving students.

BIOL 159.name: Skills of Biological Investigation
BIOL 159.description: Intended for science majors, an exploration of the skills necessary to conduct research in biology. Emphasis will be on reading primary literature, designing and carrying out experiments, summarizing and analyzing data, coming to conclusions from data, and presenting investigations in oral and written forms.

BIOL 160.name: Cellular and Molecular Biology
BIOL 160.description: Intended for science majors, an introduction to the major biological concepts emphasizing the cellular and molecular aspects of life. Organized along themes of evolution, structure and function, information flow, exchange and storage, pathways of energy and matter, and systems.

BIOL 167.name: Honors: Skills of Biological Investigation
BIOL 167.description: Same as BIOL 159* but designed for high-achieving students.

BIOL 168.name: Honors: Cellular and Molecular Biology
BIOL 168.description: Same as BIOL 160* but designed for high-achieving students.

BIOL 211.name: Eukaryotic Cell Biology
BIOL 211.description: A Quantitative Eukaryotic Cell biology lab course using yeast as a model system. Topics include cell growth, cell cycle, cytoskeleton, membrane trafficking, cell morphology, mitosis, cytokinesis, genetics, and gene expression. Experiments include light microscopy, cell growth assays, cellular trafficking assays, and transformation. The course also includes the use of image analysis software, and data quantification, analysis and presentation.

BIOL 220.name: General Microbiology
BIOL 220.description: Fundamental concepts in microbiology: evolution; structure and function of microbial cells; metabolic pathways; roles of microbes in nature and society; microbial diseases and immunity.

BIOL 229.name: General Microbiology Laboratory
BIOL 229.description: Basic techniques for the examination, cultivation, and identification of microorganisms.

BIOL 240.name: General Genetics
BIOL 240.description: Classical and modern principles of heredity. Topics include meiosis and transmission genetics; molecular genetics and gene expression; population and evolutionary genetics. Discussion sections will emphasize problem-solving skills. Emphasis on development of analytical skills.

BIOL 260.name: Ecology
BIOL 260.description: Relations between organisms and their environment, including human environmental problems. Topics include populations, communities, and ecosystems.

BIOL 269.name: Ecology Field-Based Laboratory
BIOL 269.description: Field-based activities that illustrate the relations between organisms and their environment, including human environmental problems.

BIOL 280.name: Evolution
BIOL 280.description: Survey of major topics in evolutionary biology, including elementary population genetics, concepts of fitness and adaptation, genetic and developmental bases of evolutionary change, modes of speciation, principles of systematic biology, paleontology and macroevolutionary trends in evolution.

BIOL 281.name: Evolution Discussion
BIOL 281.description: Readings and discussion of the major topics underlying Evolution lecture.

BIOL 407.name: Senior Honors Thesis
BIOL 407.description: Written preparation and oral presentation of faculty-supervised student research.

BME 201.name: Biomedical Engineering Seminar
BME 201.description: Overview of biomedical engineering with lectures, lab demonstrations and field trips.

BME 205.name: Anatomy and Physiology for Biomedical Engineers
BME 205.description: Introduction to the fundamental principles of human anatomy and physiology essential for the study of biomedical engineering. This course is designed to expose students to the fundamentals of biology and how medical devices interact with biological systems to diagnose and treat human disease.

BME 315.name: Signals and Systems Analysis
BME 315.description: Continuous- and discrete-time functions, Laplace transforms, convolution, sampling theory, continuous- and discrete-time Fourier series, continuous- and discrete-time Fourier transforms, z transforms and system identification in the time and frequency domain.

BME 341.name: Fluid Mechanics for Biomedical Engineers
BME 341.description: Introduction to fluid flow concepts, mass transport, and heat transfer in biological systems.

BME 347.name: Honors: Fluid Mechanics for Biomedical Engineers
BME 347.description: Honors section of BME 341; students will attend BME 341 classes with supplementary assignments. Introduction to fluid flow concepts, mass transport, and heat transfer in biological systems.

BME 405.name: Introduction to Drug Delivery
BME 405.description: Introduction to the fundamental principles of pharmacology, routes of drug administration, drug diffusion and permeation through tissue, and engineering strategies and materials used to improve drug distribution and transport to its site of action.

BME 409.name: Cell and Tissue Engineering
BME 409.description: Mammalian cell culture. Effects of mechanical forces on cells. Tissue engineering of cardiovascular and orthopedic devices.

BME 449.name: Biomedical Engineering Laboratory
BME 449.description: Experience with the unique problems associated with making measurements and interpreting data in living systems. Experiments may include mechanical testing of biological materials, imaging, and physiological measurements (EKG, EMG, ECG, etc.).

BME 450.name: Biomedical Engineering Design I
BME 450.description: Design of biomedical systems. Economics, optimization, reliability, patents, and product liability. Participation in team design efforts. Requires oral and written design reports.

BME 460.name: Biomedical Engineering Design II
BME 460.description: Design of complete biomedical device. Documentation includes complete specification, design calculations, preparation of working drawings, and cost analysis. Requires written and oral reports.

BME 473.name: Applied Biomechanics
BME 473.description: Applications of biomechanics to the industrial and orthopedic area. Design of orthopedic implant devices; biomechanics of injury and protection.

BME 474.name: Biomaterials
BME 474.description: Metals, polymers, and ceramics utilized in orthopedic, cardiovascular, and dental surgical implant devices. Corrosion and degradation problems. Material properties of primary importance and tissue response to synthetic materials.

BME 477.name: Honors: Applied Biomechanics
BME 477.description: Honors version of BME 473. Students will attend BME 473 classes with supplementary assignments.

BME 480.name: Computational Cell Biology
BME 480.description: Introduction to dynamical modeling in molecular and cellular biology. Topics include models and analysis of neurons and other excitable systems, fast and slow time scales, whole-cell models, intercellular communication, cell cycle controls, molecular motors, and stochastic and nonlinear dynamics in biological systems.

BME 483.name: Systems Neuroscience and Neurotechnology
BME 483.description: An engineering approach to systems-level functions of the human nervous system as well as the current and emerging neurotechnologies to restore neural functions lost by disease or injury. Ethical considerations and clinical application challenges including relevant regulatory (FDA) guidelines and chronic viability of promising technologies.

BME 485.name: Advanced Biomaterials: Biological Application of Nanomaterials
BME 485.description: 0-d, 1-d and 2-d nanomaterials synthesis and characterization with emphasis of surface properties. Chemical and biological functionalization of nanomaterials and nano-bio interfaces. Biological and biomedical application of nanomaterials.

BME 494.name: Special Project in Biomedical Engineering
BME 494.description: Problems related to recent developments and practice.

BME 495.name: Special Project in Biomedical Engineering
BME 495.description: Problems related to recent developments and practice.

BME 496.name: Emerging Topics in Biomedical Engineering
BME 496.description: Problems and studies on new topics in Biomedical Engineering.

BSE 104.name: Design Apprenticeship
BSE 104.description: Exposure to design in biosystems engineering through apprenticeship with senior design teams in BSE 402*. Apprentices will assist with design, construction, testing, analysis, and presentation of project. Will also include background in engineering design, engineering project management, and engineering design tools.

BSE 201.name: Career Opportunities
BSE 201.description: Activities and opportunities in the fields of specialization; required training for each area; projected career activities.

BSE 221.name: Mass and Energy in Biosystems
BSE 221.description: Introduction to thermodynamic concepts for biological systems (energy, mass and energy balances, processes and cycles); psychrometrics and psychrometric processes; biological systems and the biosphere (bioenergetics, hydrologic cycle, global energy cycle).

BSE 231.name: Biochemistry for Engineers
BSE 231.description: Fundamentals of biochemistry presented from an engineering point of view and applied to solve engineering-related problems. Topics to be covered include fundamental organic chemistry of amino acids, carbohydrates, lipids and other important biochemicals; the role and control of pH in biological solutions; fundamental biochemistry of proteins and enzymes; introduction to bioenergetics and metabolic pathways, and the replication, transcription, and translation of DNA.

BSE 321.name: Biothermodynamics, Heat, and Mass Transfer
BSE 321.description: Application of thermodynamics to biological systems; heat transfer with emphasis upon conduction and convection applications; introduction to diffusion mass transfer.

BSE 326.name: Engineering with Incompressible Fluids
BSE 326.description: An introduction to incompressible fluid mechanics that includes: fluid statics, the Bernoulli Equation, complex laminar and turbulent flow in piped networks, flow over immersed bodies, open channel flow, pump theory and sizing, and flow monitoring for application to ecological, agricultural, and environmental situations.

BSE 351.name: Basic Electrical and Electronic Principles
BSE 351.description: Electrical and electronic principles. circuit components; basic laws and theorems in electrical circuits; d.c. and a.c. circuit analysis; electromagnetism; transformers, three-phase circuits, etc. Includes in-class experiments.

BSE 400.name: Design Project I
BSE 400.description: With BSE 402*, this course comprises the biosystems engineering two-semester project sequence, in which student teams must tackle a stated problem, designing, building, and testing a prototype to determine success at meeting client performance criteria. This culminates the curriculum with a major design experience based on knowledge and skills acquired in earlier coursework and incorporating engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints. Includes development of a major design proposal, including engineering analyses, extensive documentation, and a culminating group presentation.

BSE 402.name: Design Project II
BSE 402.description: Culmination of capstone design sequence. Intensive design experience on project chosen and approved in BSE 400. Analysis, construction, testing, evaluation, and reporting required. Periodic oral and written reports and submission of design to external engineering design competition or display required.

BSE 403.name: Design Presentation and Reporting
BSE 403.description: Partner course to BSE 402* Senior Design II, emphasizing professional presentation and reporting of technical material associated with the two-semester Senior Design project.

BSE 404.name: Engineering Project Management
BSE 404.description: Fundamentals and theory of engineering design and engineering project management, ethical and legal responsibilities in biosystems engineering, incorporation of economic considerations in engineering design, individual professional development, and multiple oral presentations of technical information related to the senior design project.

BSE 411.name: Mechanical Systems Engineering
BSE 411.description: Fundamentals of power delivery systems and simple mechanisms; selection and design of mechanical, hydraulic, and tractive power transmission systems. Emphasis on off-road vehicles and bioprocessing systems.

BSE 417.name: Honors: Mechanical Systems Engineering
BSE 417.description: Honors version of BSE 411 that requires an additional honors component.

BSE 426.name: Design Hydrology and Monitoring for Agricultural, Low Impact Development (LID), and other Ecological Systems
BSE 426.description: A brief introduction to hydrology and hydrologic monitoring along with water-based design and modeling of Agricultural, LID, and other Ecological Systems.

BSE 427.name: Honors: Design Hydrology and Monitoring for Agricultural, Low Impact Development (LID), and other Ecological Systems
BSE 427.description: Honors version of BSE 426 that requires an additional honors component.

BSE 431.name: Bioprocess Engineering
BSE 431.description: Development of interdisciplinary bioprocess engineering; basics of biology in an engineering perspective; enzymatic reaction kinetics; metabolism and bioenergetics; cell growth kinetics and product formation; engineering principles applied to bioprocess engineering including mass balance, energy balance, and reaction kinetics; reactor design and systems; introduction to bioseparations; practical aspects of bioprocess engineers and process development.

BSE 437.name: Honors: Bioprocess Engineering
BSE 437.description: Honors version of BSE 431 that requires an additional honors component.

BSE 444.name: Practicum
BSE 444.description: Applications of engineering theory and design in selecting, sizing, and fabricating engineering materials, and in developing processes and systems typically used in biosystems engineering.

BSE 451.name: Electronic Systems
BSE 451.description: Basic electronics with biological applications. Analog and digital electronics; sensing and controlling physical and environmental parameters; sensor selection and interfacing; signal conditioning; process control. Includes laboratory experiments and design projects.

BSE 457.name: Honors: Electronic Systems
BSE 457.description: Honors version of BSE 451 that requires an additional honors component.

BSE 470.name: Special Problems in Biosystems Engineering
BSE 470.description: Selection, analysis solution, and report of problem.

BSE 480.name: Selected Topics in Biosystems Engineering
BSE 480.description: Current trends and problems in biosystems engineering.

BSE 499.name: Research Problem in Biosystems Engineering
BSE 499.description: Special research problems in biosystems engineering. Designed for students working without pay on largely self-directed research problems under the guidance of a departmental faculty mentor. May be used to meet up to 3 hours of technical elective credit with pre-approval of both the faculty mentor and, when the faculty mentor is a different person, the academic advisor.

BUAD 100.name: Inclusion: Becoming an Engaged Leader in a Diverse Community
BUAD 100.description: Integration into the Haslam College of Business with emphasis on academic and career planning, college success strategies, and professional development.

BUAD 102.name: Service Learning Seminar
BUAD 102.description: Service learning seminar, which provides a framework for participation in service to the community. The purpose is to increase the connection between campus and the local community, to educate students for citizenship and public service, and to highlight the positive role that business leaders play in the community.

BUAD 103.name: Learning Community Seminar
BUAD 103.description: Seminar covering topics of specific interest in a themed living learning community.

BUAD 107.name: Honors: Inclusion: Becoming an Engaged Leader in a Diverse Community
BUAD 107.description: Integration into the Haslam College of Business for university honors students with emphasis on academic and career planning, college success strategies, and professional development.

BUAD 200.name: Integrity: Becoming an Ethical Leader and Effective Communicator
BUAD 200.description: Appropriate written communication in a business environment, including discussion of plagiarism and academic integrity. Areas of content may include resume and cover letter development, report formatting, intercultural business communication, and personal reflection.

BUAD 202.name: Personal Finance
BUAD 202.description: This course provides financial education and practical information to all students, especially those not majoring in business. The primary objective is to empower students to become more financially informed individuals.

BUAD 205.name: Business Ethics
BUAD 205.description: An in-depth focus on business ethics that combines philosophical theory and empirical social science. This course examines the process of identifying, understanding, and effectively addressing contemporary ethical issues in the business enterprise. Perspectives from individual, organizational, societal, and international levels are considered.

BUAD 207.name: Honors: Integrity: Becoming an Ethical Leader and Effective Communicator
BUAD 207.description: Appropriate written communication in a business environment, including discussion of plagiarism and academic integrity. Areas of content may include resume and cover letter development, report formatting, intercultural business communication, and personal reflection. Specifically for honors students.

BUAD 208.name: Honors: Business Ethics
BUAD 208.description: Honors course designed for students seeking advanced professional orientation and experience in the application of ethics to the business environment. This course provides an in-depth focus on business ethics that combines philosophical theory, empirical social science, business ethics research perspectives, and service learning to course content. Examines the process of identifying, understanding, and effectively addressing contemporary ethical issues in the business enterprise. Perspectives from individual, organizational, societal, and international levels are considered.

BUAD 210.name: Success in the Haslam College of Business
BUAD 210.description: Integration into the Haslam College of Business for transfer students with emphasis on academic and career planning, college success strategies, and professional development.

BUAD 217.name: Leadership Seminar: Approaches
BUAD 217.description: Introduction to approaches and frameworks of leadership within the business context.

BUAD 299.name: Special Topics
BUAD 299.description: Seminar covering special topics in business.

BUAD 300.name: Insight: Becoming Personally and Professionally Aware as a Leader
BUAD 300.description: Course will focus on equipping students with career, industry, and professional development knowledge necessary to becoming competitive for internships and other professional opportunities. Areas of content may include interviewing, personal branding, and business case analyses.

BUAD 307.name: Honors: Insight: Becoming Personally and Professionally Aware as a Leader
BUAD 307.description: Course will focus on equipping students with career, industry, and professional development knowledge necessary to becoming competitive for internships and other professional opportunities. Areas of content may include interviewing, personal branding, and business case analyses. Specifically for Haslam honors students.

BUAD 317.name: Leadership Seminar: Thesis Preparation
BUAD 317.description: Approaches to contemporary business research design: literature review, research methodologies, measurement, data analysis, and interpretation.

BUAD 331.name: CBM I: Supply Chain Management
BUAD 331.description: The course will focus on the concepts that enable coordination of the end-to-end relationships between supply chain members from raw material inputs through conversion to delivery of product/services to end customers with a goal of developing a sound understanding of the impact of seamlessly managing flows of products, services, information and financial elements across the supply chain to provide optimal value to customers. Emphasis is on the skills needed to integrate end-to-end supply chain activities through improved processes and relationships as well as innovation in new products and services to achieve and maintain competitive advantage with customers.

BUAD 332.name: CBM I: Demand Management
BUAD 332.description: Analysis of current and future markets opportunities. Translation of identified opportunities into strategies to select, acquire, and retain customers that are consistent with overall organizational objectives. Includes design, execution, and evaluation of strategies from the perspective of an organization within a channel of distribution context.

BUAD 337.name: Honors: CBM I: Supply Chain Management
BUAD 337.description: Coordinating the end-to-end relationships between supply chain members from inputs to delivery of product/services. Understanding impact of demand and supply information flows across the supply chain. Emphasis on integrating activities through improved processes and relationships to achieve and maintain competitive advantage.

BUAD 338.name: Honors: CBM I: Demand Management
BUAD 338.description: Analysis of current and future markets opportunities. Translation of identified opportunities into strategies to select, acquire, and retain customers that are consistent with overall organizational objectives. Includes design, execution, and evaluation of strategies from the perspective of an organization within a channel of distribution context.

BUAD 341.name: CBM II: Lean Operations
BUAD 341.description: Design of the product delivery system in manufacturing and service operations. The dynamics of the supply chain. Managing flows in manufacturing and service processes. Specific techniques for designing process design, such as pull replenishment, cellular layout, standard work, and mixed model sequencing.

BUAD 342.name: CBM II: Information Management
BUAD 342.description: Emphasis on the concepts, structure, components (input, processes, output, feedback, and control) of information systems, and database design and management. Includes the role, function, and integration of information systems and technology into business activities.

BUAD 399.name: Special Topics
BUAD 399.description: Seminar covering special topics in business.

BUAD 400.name: Special Topics
BUAD 400.description: Topics of current interest in international business. Topics announced prior to offering.

BUAD 401.name: Peer Mentor Techniques
BUAD 401.description: Training of upper-class students as mentors and advisors for freshmen. Includes cognitive and developmental theories of the college-age student, teaching and learning styles, group communication and listening techniques, and mentoring and advising skills.

BUAD 402.name: Peer Mentor Practicum
BUAD 402.description: Peer mentoring of first year students.

BUAD 405.name: Impact: Becoming a Leader Who Makes a Positive Difference
BUAD 405.description: Course will focus on having students reflect on their experience as business students and helping them transition to their professional lives as alumni. Students will consider how they will use their business education to make a positive impact on the world going forward.

BUAD 407.name: Honors: Impact: Becoming a Leader Who Makes a Positive Difference
BUAD 407.description: Course will focus on having students reflect on their experience as business students and helping them transition to their professional lives as alumni. Students will consider how they will use their business education to make a positive impact on the world going forward. Specifically for Haslam honors students.

BUAD 410.name: Leadership Perspectives
BUAD 410.description: A holistic approach to the development of personal and professional leadership skills. Topics include organizational culture within differing institutional frameworks, models of leadership, individual motivation, mentorship, effective and artful communication, opportunity identification.

BUAD 417.name: Leadership Seminar: Applications
BUAD 417.description: Approaches to leading and leadership development through interaction with current industry leaders from multiple business and community environments.

BUAD 427.name: Leadership Seminar: Capstone
BUAD 427.description: Application of leadership concepts and methodologies in business and community environments.

BUAD 450.name: Service Learning: Diverse Community Issues and Application of Business Concepts
BUAD 450.description: Designed to help students apply business concepts to social/community service challenges. Course will utilize an action-based learning approach which will allow students to engage in productive partnerships with community agencies, corporations, and social science organizations. Students will create and execute project benefitting the philanthropic cause of a corporate sponsor.

BUAD 453.name: Global Strategic Management: Integrating Concepts and Applications
BUAD 453.description: This capstone course integrates strategic management concepts and cases with application through a comprehensive simulation. The course is a fully integrated strategy/simulation experience and will also draw on student's major, concentration, and collateral studies, as well as their broad business knowledge acquired in previous courses in the curriculum.

BUAD 457.name: Honors Global Strategic Management: Integrating Concepts and Applications
BUAD 457.description: This capstone course integrates strategic management concepts and cases with application through a comprehensive simulation. The course is a fully integrated strategy/simulation experience and will also draw on student's major, concentration, and collateral studies, as well as their broad business knowledge acquired in previous courses in the curriculum.

BUAD 492.name: Off-Campus Study
BUAD 492.description: Internships are a chance for students to gain hands-on experience in the business world, apply the knowledge learned in the classroom to real-world problems, and develop important professional skills. By participating in an internship, students gain a competitive advantage for future employment by providing meaningful work experience and an introduction to a potential career or employer. BUAD 492 is intended for internships that do not fit the requirements for internship credit in the students' major. Students must be engaged in rigorous, professionally applicable work that relates to their field of study, educational goals, and/or career aspirations that can be transferred to other employment or academic settings. The hiring organization must provide the student with a supervisor that provides routine feedback. Students will be eligible for 1 credit hour per 50 hours worked. The student can only enroll in BUAD 492 for the academic term in which they are completing the internship.

BUAD 499.name: Special Topics
BUAD 499.description: Seminar covering special topics in business.

BUAD 102S.name: Service Learning Seminar
BUAD 102S.description: Service learning seminar, which provides a framework for participation in service to the community. The purpose is to increase the connection between campus and the local community, to educate students for citizenship and public service, and to highlight the positive role that business leaders play in the community.

BUAD 492N.name: Off-Campus Study
BUAD 492N.description: Internships are a chance for students to gain hands-on experience in the business world, apply the knowledge learned in the classroom to real-world problems, and develop important professional skills. By participating in an internship, students gain a competitive advantage for future employment by providing meaningful work experience and an introduction to a potential career or employer. BUAD 492 is intended for internships that do not fit the requirements for internship credit in the students' major. Students must be engaged in rigorous, professionally applicable work that relates to their field of study, educational goals, and/or career aspirations that can be transferred to other employment or academic settings. The hiring organization must provide the student with a supervisor that provides routine feedback. Students will be eligible for 1 credit hour per 50 hours worked. The student can only enroll in BUAD 492 for the academic term in which they are completing the internship.

BULW 301.name: Legal Environment of Business
BULW 301.description: Survey of legal and ethical topics affecting business. Coverage includes legal and business ethics; dispute resolution mechanisms; and substantive and procedural law of regulation, torts, contracts, property, business associations, and employer/employee relations.

CBE 201.name: Material and Energy Balances
CBE 201.description: Steady-state and transient material and energy balances in chemical and biomolecular systems. Introduction to flowsheet software.

CBE 235.name: Fundamentals of Molecular Bioengineering
CBE 235.description: Summary of principles of biochemistry, molecular biology, and genetics from an engineering and applied science perspective. Examples of biologically-based molecular technologies and analysis and manipulation of living systems for technological applications.

CBE 240.name: Fluid Flow and Heat Transfer
CBE 240.description: Force, energy and mechanical energy balances; flow in tubes, piping systems, packed and fluidized beds; pumping and metering; steady and unsteady state heat conduction; heat transfer in tubes and heat exchangers; radiation.

CBE 250.name: Application of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Thermodynamics
CBE 250.description: Basic concepts related to engineering applications of thermodynamics to the chemical and biomolecular industries; emphasis on flow processes, real gases and liquids, protein synthesis and hydration, estimation of physical properties, phase equilibria of industrial chemical and pharmaceutical processes, and chemical reaction equilibria including biomolecular applications.

CBE 301.name: Application of Numerical and Statistical Techniques in Chemical Engineering
CBE 301.description: Numerical methods for regression, integration, solution for systems of linear/nonlinear algebraic and differential equations for applications to chemical engineering problems; statistical methods for probabilities, expectations, sampling, and estimation for applications to chemical engineering problems.

CBE 320.name: Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Laboratory
CBE 320.description: Experiments in unit operations such as pumps, heat exchangers, distillation columns, and fermenters. Application of the principles of transport phenomena.

CBE 340.name: Mass Transfer and Separation Processes
CBE 340.description: Stagewise operation. Application of analytical, graphical, and computer methods to design of stagewise separatory operations. Differential operations application of analytical and computer methods to the design of diffusive processes. Applications include gas absorption, stripping, binary distillation, and extraction.

CBE 350.name: Chemical and Bioengineering Reactor Fundamentals
CBE 350.description: Homogeneous and heterogeneous reaction kinetics; idealized homogeneous reactor models, both for closed and flow systems; analysis of batch reactor data; multiple reactions; non-isothermal reactions.

CBE 360.name: Process Dynamics and Control
CBE 360.description: Introduction to process modeling and industrial control system design. Mathematical tools for characterizing dynamic behavior of processes. Theory and practice of operating and controlling such systems.

CBE 380.name: Seminar
CBE 380.description: Presentation and discussion of topics in the practice of chemical and biomolecular engineering.

CBE 394.name: Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Co-op
CBE 394.description: Co-op experiences in chemical and biomolecular engineering. Technical report writing and presentations.

CBE 401.name: Review of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Fundamentals
CBE 401.description: Programmatic review of a broad series of topics covered in the chemical engineering curriculum. Emphasis is on problem-solving strategies and solution methodology.

CBE 407.name: Honors Seminar
CBE 407.description: Presentations and discussions on topics of importance to chemical and biomolecular engineers.

CBE 408.name: Honors: Advanced Engineering Mathematics
CBE 408.description: Mathematical methods for chemical & biomolecular engineering and related disciplines. Topics include vector spaces, matrices and eigenvalue problems, solution techniques for ordinary and partial differential equations, generalized Fourier series, integral transforms, stability analysis, and perturbation theory.

CBE 415.name: Advanced Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Laboratory
CBE 415.description: Solve open-ended problems in a chemical and biomolecular engineering laboratory environment. Incorporate principles of design of experiments and simulation tools in design and analysis.

CBE 425.name: Chemical and Biomolecular Process Economics
CBE 425.description: Concepts and methods of cost estimating, debt and equity financing, discounted cash flow methods, and estimation of product manufacturing costs. Includes case studies and the use of computer methods for financial and sensitivity analysis.

CBE 445.name: Separation Process Technology for the Pharmaceutical and Chemical Process Industries
CBE 445.description: Multicomponent distillation, theory and computer simulations; specialized technologies, including membrane separation, crystallization, adsorption, and chromatography.

CBE 447.name: Honors: Transport Phenomena
CBE 447.description: Overview of momentum, heat and mass transfer processes, the analogies, differential and macroscopic balances, applications involving molecular diffusion, including simultaneous mass transfer and chemical reaction.

CBE 452.name: Polymers and 3D Printing
CBE 452.description: Overview of polymer materials and 3D Printing. The first part of the course reviews the relevant topics in polymer science and engineering that is important for applications in 3D Printing. The second part looks at the technology, applications, and ecosystem of 3D printing.

CBE 458.name: Honors: Elements of Synthetic Biology and Metabolic Engineering
CBE 458.description: Cross-disciplinary course, an upper level continuation of 350, focuses on biocatalyst development for industrial biotechnology. The course covers synergistic approaches of synthetic biology and metabolic engineering to design complex cellular metabolisms to solve challenging problems related to health, energy, and environment with integration of state-of-the-art computational and experimental techniques.

CBE 473.name: Introduction to Multifunctional Nanocomposites
CBE 473.description: Cross-disciplinary course covering the fundamentals of advanced nanocomposites systems including preparation, properties, characterizations, processing, and applications.

CBE 475.name: Applied Microbiology and Bioengineering
CBE 475.description: Course at the interface of chemical engineering, biomolecular engineering, environmental engineering, microbiology, and biochemistry, highlighting the use of microbial and molecular bioprocesses at industrial scale. Topics include analysis of enzymatic reactions, biodegradation/wastewater treatment, analysis of basic bioreactor systems, biosensors, and biomolecular immobilization methods.

CBE 477.name: Honors: Advanced Biomolecular Engineering
CBE 477.description: Application of engineering approaches and analysis to molecular and cellular biological sciences.

CBE 480.name: Equipment Design, Economic Methods, and Process Safety
CBE 480.description: Design, optimization, and costing of chemical and biochemical plant equipment. Introduction to economic evaluation methods, capital investment, discounted cash flows, and net present worth. Introduction to advanced process safety protocols and procedures, including engineering ethics.

CBE 481.name: Green Engineering
CBE 481.description: Principles and practical aspects of the design, commercialization, and use of processes and products for determining their feasibility and economic potential while minimizing the generation of pollution at the source and risk to human health and environment.

CBE 488.name: Honors: Design Internship in Green Engineering
CBE 488.description: Selected students work in small groups to address the prevention of industrial pollution through improved design of chemical and biochemical processes. Directed by faculty and engineers from a host company.
