ELPS 352.name: Personally and Socially Responsible Leadership in Action
ELPS 352.description: Synthesis and application of leadership scholarship with a focus on the ethical and intercultural dimensions of leadership and communication across difference.

ELPS 411.name: Leadership Knoxville Scholars Capstone Seminar
ELPS 411.description: Application of collegiate leadership knowledge and experiences to problems facing the Knoxville community and use in lives and careers after college. Intensive interaction with leaders and leadership development activities in the Knoxville community support students' participation in a multi-semester problems project. Membership in the Leadership Knoxville Scholars program required for registration.

ELPS 450.name: Leadership in Transition
ELPS 450.description: An examination of organizational leadership for change. Application of leadership theories, frameworks, constructs, self-awareness, and skills to post-collegiate goals, life-long learning, leadership problems, and an applied project.

ELPS 451.name: Leadership in Transition Seminar
ELPS 451.description: An examination of organizational leadership for change. Application of leadership theories, frameworks, constructs, self-awareness, and skills to post-collegiate goals, life-long learning, and leadership problems.

ELPS 452.name: Experiential Leadership Capstone and Portfolio
ELPS 452.description: Application of leadership theories, frameworks, constructs, self-awareness, and skills to contemporary problems in a self-directed leadership project.

ELPS 457.name: Honors: Leadership Capstone and Portfolio
ELPS 457.description: Application of leadership theories, frameworks, constructs, self-awareness, and skills to contemporary problems in a self-directed leadership project.

ELPS 493.name: Independent Study
ELPS 493.description: Independent investigation of problems and issues in leadership.

ELPS 495.name: Special Topics
ELPS 495.description: Faculty-initiated courses. Detailed study of a specialized area of leadership. Topics vary.

ELPS 499.name: Experiential Leadership Proficiency
ELPS 499.description: Students' portfolio demonstrates documented proficient leadership experiences, self-awareness, and capacity. This course provides an opportunity for students to demonstrate their proficiency in collegiate leadership as evidenced by Leadership Studies co-curricular experiential requirement submission that meet or exceed the program standards.

ENED 409.name: Young Adult Literature
ENED 409.description: This introductory survey course will focus on; the literary merit and cultural contexts of works written for young adults; significant historical and contemporary works/authors; current trends and issues in the field of young adult literature; and pedagogical strategies for parents, teachers, and librarians.

ENED 459.name: Secondary English and ESL Methods
ENED 459.description: Techniques of teaching composition, language, and literature in English and English as a Second Language classrooms.

ENED 460.name: Teaching Reading and Literature in the Secondary School
ENED 460.description: Teaching basic reading skills and literature.

ENGL 101.name: English Composition I
ENGL 101.description: Intensive instruction in writing, focusing on analysis and argument. Strategies for reading critically, analyzing texts from diverse perspectives, developing substantive arguments through systematic revision, addressing specific audiences, integrating sources, and expressing ideas with clarity and correctness.

ENGL 102.name: English Composition II
ENGL 102.description: Advancing concepts introduced in ENGL 101*. Intensive writing instruction focused on inquiry and research. Strategies for formulating and investigating questions, locating and evaluating information, using varied sources and research methods, developing positions on intercultural and interdisciplinary issues from diverse texts (print, digital, and multimedia), and presenting research using appropriate rhetorical conventions.

ENGL 103.name: Writing Workshop I
ENGL 103.description: Self-paced Writing Center tutorial for students wanting additional instruction while enrolled in ENGL 101*, ENGL 131*, or ENGL 198* or having ACT English and composite scores at or below 18 (or SAT verbal/composite scores at or below 450/850). Individual instruction as needed in mechanics, paragraph development, and essay structure.

ENGL 104.name: Writing Workshop II
ENGL 104.description: Self-paced Writing Center tutorial for students wanting additional instruction while enrolled in ENGL 102*, ENGL 118*, ENGL 132*, ENGL 290*, or ENGL 298* or students advised to enroll by their ENGL 102*, ENGL 118*, ENGL 132*, ENGL 290*, or ENGL 298* instructors. Individual instruction as needed in critical reading and in developing and documenting the research paper.

ENGL 118.name: Honors: English Composition
ENGL 118.description: Grading scale and workload are same as in regular sequence though course proceeds at an accelerated pace. Emphasis on argumentation, critical inquiry, rhetorical analysis, and research methods. May include the study of a long work of literature or nonfiction in addition to a selection of interdisciplinary readings.

ENGL 121.name: Academic English for Undergraduate Students
ENGL 121.description: Development of English academic literacy for undergraduate students whose native or strongest language is not English, including reading, writing, vocabulary, and grammar, as well as some attention to listening, oral presentation, and pronunciation.

ENGL 122.name: Graduate Writing for International Students
ENGL 122.description: Intensive reading and writing instruction for international graduate students, focusing on a variety of critical and rhetorical approaches to academic writing in the disciplines. Strategies for improving professional oral communication. Comprehensive review of the essential grammar for research writing.

ENGL 131.name: Composition for Non-Native Speakers of English I
ENGL 131.description: Intensive instruction in writing, focusing on analysis and argument. Strategies for developing substantive arguments through systematic revision, addressing specific audiences, integrating sources, and expressing ideas with clarity and correctness. Individual conferences.

ENGL 132.name: Composition for Non-Native Speakers of English II
ENGL 132.description: Advancing concepts introduced in ENGL 131* or ENGL 101*. Intensive writing instruction focused on inquiry and research. Strategies for formulating and investigating questions, locating and evaluating information, using varied sources and research methods, developing positions on intercultural and interdisciplinary issues from diverse texts (print, digital, and multimedia), and presenting research using appropriate rhetorical conventions. Individual conferences.

ENGL 198.name: Chancellor's Honors Writing I
ENGL 198.description: Intensive writing and research instruction, with emphasis on critical inquiry, rhetorical analysis, persuasion/argumentation, and primary and secondary source research. Course topic includes exploration of debates concerning "human nature." Includes the study of longer works of nonfiction in addition to a selection of interdisciplinary readings.

ENGL 201.name: British Literature I: Beowulf through Johnson
ENGL 201.description: Major literary works from three periods ― Middle Ages, Renaissance and Restoration, and 18th century.

ENGL 202.name: British Literature II: Wordsworth to the Present
ENGL 202.description: Major literary works from three periods ― Romantic, Victorian, and 20th century.

ENGL 206.name: Introduction to Shakespeare
ENGL 206.description: An overview of Shakespeare's world and his work.

ENGL 209.name: Introduction to Jane Austen
ENGL 209.description: An overview of Jane Austen's world and her work.

ENGL 221.name: World Literature I: Ancient through Early Modern

ENGL 222.name: World Literature II: The Eighteenth-Century to the Present

ENGL 226.name: Introduction to Caribbean Literature
ENGL 226.description: Survey of the major genres in Caribbean literature. Course makes cross-cultural and cross-national comparisons; general overview of themes and styles. Major authors may include Naipaul, Rhone, Brathwaite, Hodge, Mais, Lovelace, and Marshall.

ENGL 231.name: American Literature I: Colonial Era to the Civil War
ENGL 231.description: Development of American literature from its beginnings to the Civil War.

ENGL 232.name: American Literature II: Civil War to the Present
ENGL 232.description: Development of American literature from Civil War to the present.

ENGL 233.name: Major Black Writers
ENGL 233.description: Black American literature as a literary tradition.

ENGL 237.name: Honors: American Literature I: Colonial Era to the Civil War

ENGL 238.name: Honors: American Literature II: Civil War to the Present

ENGL 251.name: Introduction to Poetry
ENGL 251.description: Poetry as a distinct mode of artistic expression. Critical tools for perceptive reading of poems.

ENGL 252.name: Introduction to Drama
ENGL 252.description: Critical tools for perceptive reading of play texts.

ENGL 253.name: Introduction to Fiction
ENGL 253.description: Fiction from the eighteenth through the twentieth centuries, emphasis on the novel. Critical tools necessary for judging varieties of fiction.

ENGL 254.name: Themes in Literature
ENGL 254.description: Study of important themes in English, American, and World literatures. Some sample themes are religion, crime, law, ecology, science, exploration, revolution, colonization initiation, education. Multi-genre focus. See Timetable for topics.

ENGL 255.name: Public Writing
ENGL 255.description: Rhetorical strategies for effective communication about public issues. Students will learn to write for multiple audiences and may be asked to participate in collaborative writing projects with business, academic, or political organizations.

ENGL 261.name: Themes in Creative Writing
ENGL 261.description: Theme-based course that offers practice in creative writing using literary models as well as practice in analytical interpretation. Sections may vary to focus on poetry, fiction, or nonfiction.

ENGL 263.name: Introduction to Creative Writing
ENGL 263.description: Practice in creative writing with an emphasis on fiction and poetry, combined with study of models and techniques.

ENGL 281.name: Introduction to Film Studies
ENGL 281.description: Selected world cinema feature films. Critical techniques necessary for understanding and analysis of narrative cinema. Basic elements of film expression and contours of film history.

ENGL 290.name: Intermediate Writing and Research
ENGL 290.description: Intensive practice in conducting and writing original research. Critiquing current scholarship to determine gaps in a research problem; locating, organizing, evaluating, integrating, and documenting diverse sources in order to construct and support research-based arguments; identifying salient features of different kinds of researched writing.

ENGL 295.name: Writing in the Workplace
ENGL 295.description: Rhetorical strategies and genres of professional communication. Includes principles of writing style, structure, and document design appropriate for audience and purpose.

ENGL 298.name: Chancellor's Honors Writing II
ENGL 298.description: Intensive writing and research instruction to build upon ENGL 198*, with emphasis on strategies for conducting independent research, locating and evaluating information, using varied sources and research methods, developing positions based on evidence, and writing up research using appropriate conventions within different disciplines. Course topic includes exploration of debates concerning the pursuit of truth and knowledge within different disciplines.

ENGL 301.name: British Culture to 1660
ENGL 301.description: English literature in the context of parallel developments in art, architecture, music, and social and intellectual history.

ENGL 302.name: British Culture: 1660 to Present
ENGL 302.description: English literature in the context of parallel developments in art, architecture, music, and social and intellectual history.

ENGL 303.name: American Cultures
ENGL 303.description: American literature across historical periods and in dialogue with social movements and significant developments in other arts.

ENGL 306.name: Shakespeare and Film
ENGL 306.description: Literary and cinematic study of Shakespearean drama and the aesthetics and politics of reception. Content Varies.

ENGL 311.name: Race in Horror, Sci-Fi, and Thriller

ENGL 321.name: Introduction to Old English
ENGL 321.description: Language and literature of England from c. 700 to c. 1100. Reading of prose works and shorter poetry in Old English. Cultural context of Anglo-Saxon England explored through critical essays, histories, and primary texts in translation. Focus on manuscript evidence and medieval and modern textual practices.

ENGL 331.name: Race and Ethnicity in American Literature
ENGL 331.description: Examines the role of ethnic and racial identity in the literature of the United States.

ENGL 332.name: Women in American Literature
ENGL 332.description: Women as writers and as subjects in American literature from its beginnings to the present.

ENGL 333.name: Black American Literature and Aesthetics
ENGL 333.description: Black American literature and aesthetics since 1899 with emphasis on cultural evaluations and the principles of being American.

ENGL 334.name: Film and American Culture
ENGL 334.description: American films as both works of art and social documents. Relationship between the medium of film and American culture in the 20th century.

ENGL 336.name: Caribbean Literature
ENGL 336.description: Survey of the major works of Caribbean literature; emphasis on poetry, drama, prose fiction, applicable theory, and critical terms. Major authors may include Brodber, Rhone, Lamming, Brathwaite, Naipul, Walcott, Selvon, Kincaid, and Marshall.

ENGL 339.name: Children's/Young Adult Literature
ENGL 339.description: Study of works about child and young adult characters, which may include fairy tales, picture books, and popular fiction from the nineteenth century to the present.

ENGL 340.name: Science Fiction and Fantasy
ENGL 340.description: Literary, historical, and philosophical approaches to Science Fiction and Fantasy.

ENGL 341.name: Religion and Spirituality in American Literature
ENGL 341.description: Examines religion and spirituality as themes, cultural influences, commitments, and rhetorical appeals in American literature. Content varies.

ENGL 342.name: Literature and Medicine
ENGL 342.description: Literary representations of illness, medical care, and biotechnology with an emphasis on the individual and social meanings of health and disease.

ENGL 345.name: Graphic Novel and Comics
ENGL 345.description: Literary and historical approaches to the graphic novel and comics as forms of visual narrative, with focus on narrative themes and formal mixture of visual and story elements.

ENGL 351.name: The Short Story
ENGL 351.description: American, British, and international. Content varies.

ENGL 355.name: Rhetoric and Writing
ENGL 355.description: Strategies of writing on personal and academic subjects. Discussion of student and professional writing.

ENGL 360.name: Technical and Professional Writing
ENGL 360.description: For students who need to sharpen their technical communication skills. Writing of definitions, process descriptions, proposals, abstracts, executive summaries, and major reports.

ENGL 364.name: Writing Fiction
ENGL 364.description: Introduction to writing novels and short stories.

ENGL 369.name: Writing Creative Nonfiction
ENGL 369.description: Introduction to the technical and stylistic elements of writing creative nonfiction.

ENGL 371.name: Foundations of the English Language
ENGL 371.description: Phonology, morphology, and syntax of English. History of the English language to 1800.

ENGL 372.name: The Structure of Modern English
ENGL 372.description: Descriptive study of contemporary English with emphasis on phrase, clause, and sentence structure.

ENGL 376.name: Colloquium in Literature
ENGL 376.description: Methods and objectives of literary study. Conferences to plan student's program in major.

ENGL 381.name: American Tales, Songs, and Material Culture: An Introduction to Folklore
ENGL 381.description: Modern folklore/folk-life studies. Emphasis upon folktale, tall tale, myth, legend, folk balladry and music, proverbs, riddles, superstitions, games, food, crafts, art, and architecture. Writing-emphasis course.

ENGL 389.name: Literature of the English Bible
ENGL 389.description: A literary and historical approach to the Bible, including characteristics of its narrative and poetic art, and analysis of the different types of literature found in it: myth, legend, folktale, law, history, biography, poetry, prophecy, and apocalypse.

ENGL 397.name: Honors Seminar in English Studies
ENGL 397.description: Seminar for students admitted to University and Departmental Honors programs. Variable content with an emphasis on literature and culture from an interdisciplinary Humanities perspective. Specific content determined by instructor.

ENGL 398.name: Junior-Senior Honors Seminar
ENGL 398.description: Seminar for students admitted to English honors program. Variable content determined by instructor, but usually focused on a particular literary period, genre, or issue.

ENGL 401.name: Medieval Literature
ENGL 401.description: Reading and analysis of a selection of literary works from the Old and Middle English period, as well as some continental texts; most will be read in modern English translation, and no previous knowledge of Middle English is required.

ENGL 402.name: Chaucer
ENGL 402.description: Reading and analysis of the Canterbury Tales and Troylus and Criseyde in Middle English.

ENGL 403.name: Introduction to Middle English
ENGL 403.description: A survey of the language and literature of England from the 12th through the 15th centuries. Reading of prose works and shorter poetry will be done in Middle English with special attention paid to grammar, style, dialect, and language change. The class will explore the culture of medieval England through critical essays, histories, and supplementary texts in translation.

ENGL 404.name: Shakespeare I: Early Plays
ENGL 404.description: Shakespeare's dramatic achievement before 1601. Reading and discussion of selected plays from romantic comedies, including Twelfth Night; English histories, including Henry IV; and early tragedy, including Hamlet.

ENGL 405.name: Shakespeare II: Later Plays
ENGL 405.description: Shakespeare's dramatic achievement between 1601 and 1613. Reading and discussion of selected plays from great tragedies, including Othello; problem plays, including Measure for Measure; and dramatic romances, including The Tempest.

ENGL 406.name: Shakespeare's Contemporaries I: Renaissance Drama
ENGL 406.description: English theatre between 1590 and 1640. Representative plays by Shakespeare's contemporaries – Marlowe, Webster, and Jonson.

ENGL 409.name: Shakespeare's Contemporaries II: Renaissance Poetry and Prose
ENGL 409.description: Principal achievements in poetry and prose of 16th-century authors – More, Wyatt, Marlowe, Spenser, Sidney, and Donne.

ENGL 410.name: Donne, Milton, and Their Contemporaries
ENGL 410.description: Principal achievements in poetry and prose of the first two-thirds of the 17th century. Includes such writers as Donne, Herbert, Lanyer, Bacon, Browne, Marvell, and Milton.

ENGL 411.name: Literature of the Restoration and Early 18th Century: Dryden to Pope
ENGL 411.description: Survey of English literature and culture from 1660 to 1745.

ENGL 412.name: Literature of the Later 18th Century: Johnson to Burns
ENGL 412.description: Survey of English literature and culture from 1745 to 1800.

ENGL 413.name: Restoration and 18th-Century Genres and Modes
ENGL 413.description: Study of one major genre or literary mode such as drama, novel, poetry, nonfiction, prose, satire, romance, or epic written between 1660 and 1800.

ENGL 414.name: Romantic Poetry and Prose I
ENGL 414.description: Emphasis on Wordsworth, Coleridge, and Blake with readings from Lamb, De Quincey, and other prose writers.

ENGL 415.name: Romantic Poetry and Prose II
ENGL 415.description: Emphasis on Keats, Shelley, and Byron with readings from Hazlitt, Peacock, and other prose writers.

ENGL 419.name: Later Victorian Literature
ENGL 419.description: May include poetry by the Pre-Raphaelites, Arnold, Hopkins, and Hardy; prose by Arnold, Ruskin, and Carroll; plays by Gilbert and Wilde.

ENGL 420.name: The 19th-Century British Novel
ENGL 420.description: Major novelists from Scott to Hardy.

ENGL 421.name: Modern British Novel
ENGL 421.description: Authors such as Joyce and Woolf through contemporary British fiction writers.

ENGL 422.name: Women Writers in Britain
ENGL 422.description: Emphasis on the literary consciousness and works of women writers in Britain. Course content will vary. Authors covered may include Marie de France, Margery Kempe, Aemilia Lanyer, Elizabeth Cary, Aphra Behn, Frances Burney, Mary Wollstonecraft, Mary Shelley, George Eliot, Virginia Woolf, and Doris Lessing.

ENGL 423.name: Colonial and Post-Colonial Literature
ENGL 423.description: Emphasis on historical and theoretical methodologies for reading colonial and post-colonial literature.

ENGL 424.name: Jane Austen
ENGL 424.description: Close study of Austen's literary works, with special attention to their cultural and literary contexts.

ENGL 431.name: Early American Literature
ENGL 431.description: From the earliest texts to 1830, including exploration and discovery, Native American, colonial, revolutionary, and early national works.

ENGL 432.name: American Romanticism and Transcendentalism
ENGL 432.description: Prose and poetry of the American Renaissance from 1830 to the end of the Civil War. Includes writers such as Cooper, Emerson, Fuller, Poe, Thoreau, Hawthorne, Melville, Douglass, Jacobs, Whitman, and Dickinson.

ENGL 433.name: American Realism and Naturalism
ENGL 433.description: Literature from the time of the Civil War to World War I. Includes writers such as Alcott, Twain, Howells, James, Jewett, Harper, Crane, Norris, and Wharton.

ENGL 434.name: Modern American Literature
ENGL 434.description: World War I to the present.

ENGL 435.name: American Fiction to 1900
ENGL 435.description: Explores the development of American novels and short fiction published between the Revolutionary era and the end of the nineteenth century. Includes such writers as Rowson, Cooper, Poe, Hawthorne, Melville, Stowe, James, Twain, and Chesnutt.

ENGL 436.name: Modern American Novel
ENGL 436.description: Authors such as Faulkner, Steinbeck, and Welty.

ENGL 439.name: Race and Ethnicity in American Cinema
ENGL 439.description: Examines the role of ethnic and racial identity in the cinema of the United States.

ENGL 441.name: Southern Literature
ENGL 441.description: Southern writing from colonial period into the 20th century, including frontier humorists, local color writers, and the Southern Literary Renaissance.

ENGL 442.name: American Humor
ENGL 442.description: Development of American humor from the early 19th century into the 20th century with particular emphasis on Mark Twain.

ENGL 443.name: Topics in Black Literature
ENGL 443.description: Content varies according to particular genres, authors, or theories from 1845 to the present, including Langston Hughes and the Harlem Renaissance, Richard Wright and Gwendolyn Brooks, writing by black women, international black literature in English, and black American autobiography.

ENGL 444.name: Appalachian Literature and Culture
ENGL 444.description: Appalachian literature in the context of parallel developments in art, music, and cultural history.

ENGL 451.name: Modern British and American Poetry
ENGL 451.description: Formal, cultural, and thematic movements in 20th-century British and American poetry published before 1950. Includes writers such as Yeats, Frost, Eliot, Pound, Williams, Moore, Stevens, Stein, Hughes, and Auden.

ENGL 452.name: Modern Drama
ENGL 452.description: Survey of British, American, and international drama from 1880 to the end of World War II. Includes such playwrights as Ibsen, Chekhov, Shaw, Synge, O'Neill, Glaspell, Treadwell, Hughes, Pirandello, Brecht, and Wilder.

ENGL 453.name: Contemporary Drama
ENGL 453.description: Survey of British, American, and international drama since World War II. Includes such playwrights as Williams, Miller, Beckett, Dürrenmatt, Stoppard, Churchill, Shepard, Mamet, Shange, Wilson, Friel, Maponya, Highway, and Kushner.

ENGL 454.name: 20th-Century International Novel
ENGL 454.description: Fiction in English translation from such writers as Kafka and Camus through contemporary authors.

ENGL 455.name: Persuasive Writing
ENGL 455.description: Focuses on writing and analyzing persuasive texts in public, private, and academic contexts.

ENGL 456.name: Contemporary Fiction/Narrative
ENGL 456.description: Formal, literary-historical, and thematic movements in post-World War II British and American fiction and international fiction in translation. Focus on postmodern novels and short stories written after 1945, but readings may include some newly influential narrative forms such as the graphic novel, hypertext and digital fiction and the nonfiction novel.

ENGL 459.name: Contemporary Poetry
ENGL 459.description: Formal, cultural, and thematic movements in poetry published since 1950. Includes such writers as Lowell, Bishop, Brooks, Ginsberg, Plath, Larkin, Ashbery, Heaney, Baraka, and Walcott.

ENGL 460.name: Technical Editing
ENGL 460.description: Editing technical material for publication. Principles of style, format, graphics, layout, and production management.

ENGL 461.name: Global Communication for Science and Technology
ENGL 461.description: Theories, methods, issues, and practices for worldwide communication in science and technology. Topics may include nuclear security and nonproliferation, environmental studies, or health sciences and biotechnology in global contexts.

ENGL 462.name: Writing for Publication
ENGL 462.description: Principles and practices of writing for publication. Dissertations, theses, articles, and reports in science and technology.

ENGL 463.name: Advanced Poetry Writing
ENGL 463.description: Development of skills acquired in basic poetry-writing course.

ENGL 464.name: Advanced Fiction Writing
ENGL 464.description: Development of skills acquired in basic fiction-writing course.

ENGL 466.name: Writing, Layout, and Production of Technical Documents
ENGL 466.description: Principles of design for desktop publishing. Production of various documents to be incorporated into a professional portfolio.

ENGL 469.name: Advanced Creative Nonfiction Writing
ENGL 469.description: Develops skills in reading and writing creative nonfiction.

ENGL 471.name: Sociolinguistics
ENGL 471.description: Language in relation to societies. Theoretical and empirical study of language variation in individuals (style-shifting) and among social, cultural, and national/international groups.

ENGL 472.name: American English
ENGL 472.description: Phonological, morphological, and syntactic characteristics of major social and regional varieties of American English with attention to their origins, functions, and implications for cultural pluralism.

ENGL 474.name: Teaching English as a Second or Foreign Language
ENGL 474.description: Introduces major issues surrounding teaching ESL/EFL, including political implications of teaching ESL/EFL. Introduction to second language acquisition, learner variables in language learning, traditional and innovative approaches to ESL/EFL, and basic features of American English grammar necessary for teaching ESL.

ENGL 476.name: Second Language Acquisition
ENGL 476.description: How humans learn second languages. Examines theoretical models and research on such issues as differences between first and second language acquisition; the effect of age; cognitive factors in second language acquisition; learner variables; sociocultural factors; and implications for second/foreign language instruction.

ENGL 477.name: Pedagogical Grammar for ESL Teachers
ENGL 477.description: Aspects of English syntax and morphology presenting difficulties for non-native learners of English. Basic and complex sentence structures; the noun and article system; and verb tense, aspect, modality, and complementation.

ENGL 479.name: Literary Criticism
ENGL 479.description: Historical survey of major works of literary criticism.

ENGL 480.name: Fairy Tale, Legend, and Myth: Folk Narrative
ENGL 480.description: Study of forms of folk narrative. Normally includes Grimms', Andersen's, Irish, English, Appalachian, African, and Native American tales.

ENGL 482.name: Major Authors
ENGL 482.description: Concentrated study of at least one of the most influential writers in British or American literary history (e.g., Donne, Pope, Austen, Tennyson, Whitman, Faulkner, Lawrence, Baldwin, or Morrison). Content varies.

ENGL 484.name: Special Topics in Writing
ENGL 484.description: Original writing integrated with reading. Usually taught by a professional author.

ENGL 486.name: Special Topics in Criticism
ENGL 486.description: Special topics in theoretical and practical approaches to British and American literature. Content varies.

ENGL 489.name: Special Topics in Film
ENGL 489.description: Particular directors, film genres, national cinema movements, or other topics. Content varies.

ENGL 490.name: Language and Law
ENGL 490.description: Language in the Anglo-American legal process. Focus on differences between spoken and written language, lexical and syntactic ambiguity, pragmatics, speech act analysis, and the language rights of linguistic minorities.

ENGL 491.name: Foreign Study: Drama in Stratford and London
ENGL 491.description: Seeing, studying, and writing about drama as performed in London and Stratford-upon-Avon during the summer.

ENGL 492.name: Off-Campus Study: Drama in New York
ENGL 492.description: Seeing, studying, and writing about drama as performed in New York City.

ENGL 493.name: Independent Study
ENGL 493.description: Tutorial in subjects not adequately covered in regular courses.

ENGL 494.name: Cultural Rhetorics
ENGL 494.description: Rhetoric as cultural practice in connection with place, identity, and community. Focus on developing rhetorical understanding and theorizing through considerations that include language, constructions of the body, community, place, and material cultures.

ENGL 495.name: Introduction to Rhetoric and Composition
ENGL 495.description: Introduction to the historical, theoretical, and empirical modes of inquiry in rhetoric and composition and their implications for the teaching of composition.

ENGL 496.name: The Rhetoric of Legal Discourse
ENGL 496.description: Nature of legal language and written discourse types (opinions, memoranda, briefs). Introduction to legal research resources and techniques. Issue identification and argumentative techniques. Students will write position papers, memoranda, and briefs. No prior legal knowledge necessary.

ENGL 498.name: Senior Honors Thesis
ENGL 498.description: Second semester of English honors program. Working individually, the student produces a substantial critical or creative project under the direction of two members of the professorial staff.

ENT 350.name: Introduction to Entrepreneurship
ENT 350.description: An introduction to entrepreneurship with an emphasis on identifying, evaluating, and developing new venture opportunities. Topics include opportunity identification and evaluation, start-up strategies, business valuation, business plan development, attracting stakeholders, financing the venture, managing the growing business, and exit strategies.

ENT 410.name: Leadership in Nonprofits and Social Entrepreneurship
ENT 410.description: Organizations pursuing goals for the benefit of society face a unique set of challenges compared to those with primarily for-profit goals. Though charged with vitally important missions, nonprofits and social ventures (for-profit businesses with a social mission) are too often poorly led and managed. This course develops business-minded thinking and useful leadership skills in the future leaders of organizations with societal and nonprofit missions.

ENT 415.name: Start-Overs as Start-Ups
ENT 415.description: Not all entrepreneurial activity takes place within the confines of a brand new organization. For some organizations, entrepreneurial effort is required as an organization "starts over" due to poor performance, changes in leadership, new ownership, generational handoff, and/or other factors. This course centers on those situations where existing organizations need to be entrepreneurially refreshed in order to realize their potential.

ENT 425.name: Entrepreneurial Marketing
ENT 425.description: Entrepreneurial ventures face important and sometimes unique challenges marketing new products and/or services from new firms. New ventures must not only let consumers know that their products and/or services exist but also legitimize the venture in the minds of consumers. This course provides an in-depth look at entrepreneurial marketing strategies with an important focus on online presence and social media initiatives.

ENT 451.name: New Venture Planning
ENT 451.description: Integration of various functional disciplines and their application to general management of new ventures within established companies and entrepreneurial enterprises. Focuses on the components necessary for the development of a business plan.

ENT 460.name: Leading Innovation and Change
ENT 460.description: How managers identify and nurture new business opportunities while maintaining competitive advantage. Topics include examination of change models, the role of middle managers in large organizations, and ways to address resistance to change.

ENT 462.name: Innovation and Creativity
ENT 462.description: The goal of this course is to create a working prototype of a marketable product or service within the semester. Starting with a seed of a new product idea, students will conduct a market opportunity analysis, select a target market, and then define the product concept, features, benefits, and unique selling proposition. They will partner with technology experts, hardware and software developers, and others to physically create the product. In-class time will focus on experiential learning with creativity and innovation exercises and weekly executive briefings. Out-of-class time will focus on readings, simulations, field interviews, and work on the product prototype. Throughout the exercise, students will receive guidance and feedback from a professional Product Development Coach.

ENT 470.name: Managing an Entrepreneurial Start-Up
ENT 470.description:
Start-up companies have a high failure rate. Acquiring and balancing limited resources, changing direction quickly, building a coherent team, developing an organization's culture from scratch, managing intellectual property, and creating new markets all test a wide range of managerial skills not usually demanded in one person within a larger organization. Whereas a large company has a strong and well-defined structure and ample resources to deal with unexpected challenges, a start-up usually has insufficient resources and/or management experience, yet it must deal on a daily basis with important and often unpredictable forces. 

Students will be exposed to these tensions and experience through problem-based learning methods that illustrate what it is like to start and grow a new company. The course will provide students with the knowledge and experience to increase their likelihood of success whether as a principal in a small company or an investor representative. 

Managing a Startup is a problem-based learning (PBL) course, where the learning is student-centered, with faculty acting primarily in the role of facilitators. Active learning happens in this course because students are engaged in the analysis of the complex situations that underlie startup companies. The course leverages the on-line course management system Canvas to define weekly learning objectives, support electronic delivery of assignments, and provide robust video content from entrepreneurs, investors and key employees, who provide additional insights into the management decisions and ethical dilemmas the leader of a startup faces.

ENT 480.name: Franchising
ENT 480.description: Franchising is a system for expanding a business and distributing goods and services. It provides an opportunity to operate a business under a recognized brand name. It creates a relationship between the brand owner and the local operator. A franchise occurs when a business licenses its trade name and its operating system to a person or group who agrees to operate according to the terms of a contract. The class will explore franchising from the perspective of both a franchisor (an opportunity to scale a business) and a franchisee (an opportunity to become a business owner). We will discuss both the traditional or product-distribution franchises, and business-format franchises. Students will have an opportunity to interact with both franchise "brokers" and successful franchisors and franchisees. Students will compare and contrast various franchise opportunities and examine Franchise Disclosure Documents.

ENT 485.name: Funding Strategies for Entrepreneurs
ENT 485.description: Entrepreneurship funding sources and financial mechanisms necessary for securing and managing startup capital. Development of pro forma financial models, valuation techniques, and similar analyses will be covered in this course.

ENT 492.name: Entrepreneurship Internship
ENT 492.description: Integrates classroom knowledge with skill based competencies in entrepreneurship through first-hand experience working with an entrepreneur or with entrepreneurship-focused organizations.

ENT 496.name: Entrepreneurship Guest Lecture Series
ENT 496.description: Reserved for short, topic specific lectures and workshops available to all students with an interest in the special topic. Topics may be different from semester to semester.

ENT 499.name: Special Topics in Entrepreneurship
ENT 499.description: Topics of current interest in entrepreneurship.

ENT 410S.name: Leadership in Nonprofits and Social Entrepreneurship
ENT 410S.description: This course introduces students to obstacles facing nonprofit organizations and start-ups, provides students the tools and concepts essential to address these obstacles, and challenges students to use these tools and their own value systems in making "real dollar" grants to local nonprofits. The pedagogy is a blend of case studies, online learning (a six-module MOOC from Stanford), and service-learning work. In the service-learning portion of the course, students evaluate proposals from area nonprofits and award grants provided by the Learning by Giving Foundation and local philanthropists.

ENT 492N.name: Entrepreneurship Internship
ENT 492N.description: Integrates classroom knowledge with skill based competencies in entrepreneurship through first-hand experience working with an entrepreneur and with entrepreneurship-focused organizations.

EPP 123.name: Chocolate: Bean to Bar
EPP 123.description: Chocolate is one of the most popular foods in the world. More than 50 million people worldwide currently depend on chocolate (cacao) for their livelihood. Surprisingly, most people know very little about where chocolate comes from, the global impacts on various cultures, both historically and currently, or what "real" chocolate actually tastes like, despite the long history and association with chocolate. This course will introduce students to chocolate – the cacao plant and its associated pests and diseases, the underlying science, its history, and the impacts on past and current societies and cultures.

EPP 201.name: Impact of Insects and Plant Diseases on Human Societies
EPP 201.description: Insects and plant diseases have had a significant influence on human history, culture, and lifestyles. The science of entomology and plant pathology helps humankind understand the impact of insects and plant pathogens on these dimensions of human existence. The development of strategies to capitalize on the beneficial aspects of these organisms will also be explored.

EPP 210.name: Bugs: Bizarre, Beautiful, and Beneficial
EPP 210.description: This course will introduce students to the diverse world of insects and the integral interactions between insects and humans. More than one million insect species have been described, with estimates ranging from 10 to 30 million species yet to be discovered. Scientists estimate that there are about 250 million insects for every human on earth and they comprise about 10% of the earth's weight and represent ca. 80 to 85% of all life on earth! Fortunately, only a small percentage of all insects cause us grief, anguish, pain, and misery. The majority of them may be classified as bizarre, beautiful, or beneficial! This course will focus on the role of insects in our world, with an emphasis on their beneficial contributions to our quality of life.

EPP 313.name: Introductory Plant Pathology
EPP 313.description: Introduction to the microorganisms and environmental conditions causing disease in plants. Biology of pathogens, host-pathogen interactions, and disease development and principles of control.

EPP 321.name: Introductory Entomology
EPP 321.description: Structure, life history, habits, and principles of control of important insect pests of farm, garden, orchard, and household.

EPP 410.name: Diseases and Insects of Ornamental Plants
EPP 410.description: Symptoms, identification, and management of diseases and insect pests that affect plants in greenhouse, nursery, and landscape environments.

EPP 411.name: Forest Insects and Diseases
EPP 411.description: Insects and pathogens associated with trees and shrubs will be identified and their impacts on host plants evaluated.

EPP 425.name: Medical and Veterinary Entomology
EPP 425.description: Identification, biology, and control of arthropods that are parasites of humans and animals. The course focuses on arthropods and their biology, life histories, habitats, hosts, and options for management. Review and discussion of sampling/monitoring methods and decision-making guidelines to managing vector-borne diseases is also addressed.

EPP 485.name: Forensic Entomology and Crime Scene Investigations
EPP 485.description: Objectively observe, record, and determine how insects and other arthropods contribute to the overall analysis of a death event or crime scene, e.g., homicide, child/elderly neglect investigations, food contamination, and other civil and criminal applications. Learn how to collect, preserve, and identify forensically important arthropods as well as estimate post-mortem interval. Learn how to prepare written reports of investigation, write an affidavit, learn the basics of crime scene processing, identify and classify forensically important insects, and present findings in a mock court room.

EPP 493.name: Independent Study in Entomology or Plant Pathology
EPP 493.description: Laboratory, field, or library research in entomology, plant pathology, or integrated pest management under the guidance of a faculty member.

EPP 499.name: Undergraduate Research
EPP 499.description: Experience in research projects under supervision of faculty. Student should make arrangements for research project with faculty instructor prior to enrollment.

EPP 499R.name: Undergraduate Research
EPP 499R.description: Experience in research projects under supervision of faculty. Student should make arrangements for research project with faculty instructor prior to enrollment.

ESS 110.name: Energy for the World
ESS 110.description: Energy is one of the basic units of our physical world, and its availability strongly defines a populace's standard of living. Debates over the risks related to fracking, mining, nuclear power, hydroelectric dams, wind farms, solar farms, burning fossil fuels, and implications for climate change will be weighed against the need to deliver power to an increasing human population. In this course we will investigate how energy is derived from all the available technologies: from coal to tidal. This will include the full aspect of energy consumption including infrastructure, mining, energy storage, energy delivery, and waste disposal. As we discuss various countries and how they derive their energy, we will see that the proportion and the total amount of energy generated by the various technologies differ dramatically. Lastly we will discuss the inherent conflict generally between energy producers (generating self-wealth) and those downstream of the energy production (enduring poor environmental conditions), and how this conflict is becoming intergenerational.

ESS 120.name: Soils and Civilizations
ESS 120.description: Investigation of the close linkage between environmental degradation and civilization sustainability. Comparisons of past soil management practices to present-day issues of soil salinization, erosion, siltation, and climate change. Introduction to the role of soil resources in current global environmental issues and conflicts.

ESS 210.name: Introduction to Soil Science
ESS 210.description: Differences in soils; soil genesis; and the physical, chemical, and biological properties of soil. Relation of soil to agricultural and environmental sustainability, land use, and pollution. Soil management relative to tillage, erosion, moisture supply, temperature, aeration, fertility, and plant nutrition.

ESS 220.name: Waters and Civilizations
ESS 220.description: Investigation and discussion of the societal impacts on ancient and modern civilizations of water issues, including irrigation, flood control, droughts and desertification, dam construction, aquifers, drinking water, water pollution, and water rights.

ESS 242.name: Soil Morphology and Judging
ESS 242.description: Intensive course involving describing, classifying, and interpreting soils in preparation for regional and national soil judging contests.

ESS 301.name: Professional Development
ESS 301.description: Techniques of effective professional communications, professional ethics, interviewing, and the job search. Introduction of requirements for professional certification in various disciplines.

ESS 326.name: GIS/GPS Applications in Agriculture and Environmental Science
ESS 326.description: Introduction to the application of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and Global Positioning Systems (GPS) in agriculture, natural resources, and environmental science. Topics covered will include GIS software and concepts, LIDAR, mobile GIS, data acquisition, online mapping, and spatial analysis of data to solve problems. Case studies in environmental planning, land use, water quality, watershed management, and waste pollution will be used to provide hands-on experience with these emerging technologies.

ESS 334.name: Soil Nutrient Management and Fertilizers
ESS 334.description: Influence of soil properties on nutrient availability to plants. Management of inorganic and organic fertilizer materials and the determination of their fate in the soil-plant system. Nutrient management as it relates to agricultural sustainability and soil quality.

ESS 424.name: Environmental Stormwater Management
ESS 424.description: Investigation of sustainability issues regarding control of the hydrologic cycle, with special emphases on hydrologic estimation, hydraulic design, and best management practices for control of stormwater and associated erosion and water quality issues.

ESS 434.name: Environmental Soil Chemistry
ESS 434.description: Composition and chemical properties of soils and processes that govern fate and behavior of chemicals in the soil environment. Topics include ― clay mineralogy; soil organic matter; mineral weathering and stability; aqueous speciation; surface chemistry, ion exchange, adsorption, and molecular retention; oxidation-reduction; and soil acidity, alkalinity, and salinity.

ESS 442.name: Soil Genesis and Classification
ESS 442.description: Soil genesis and formation; observing and describing morphology of agricultural and forest soils; chemical and physical properties; and classification. Includes 3 weekend field trips.

ESS 444.name: Environmental Soil Physics
ESS 444.description: Basic understanding of soil physical properties and processes; influence of soil physical properties on water and chemical movement in soil; and practical experience in the measurement and analysis of soil physical properties, water flow, and chemical movement in soil.

ESS 454.name: Environmental Soil Biology
ESS 454.description: Biology and biochemistry of the soil environment as they apply to environmental and agricultural processes and sustainability. Topics include the soil habitat, microbial ecology and diversity, biogeochemical cycling of nutrients, biodegradation, and research methodology to investigate soil microorganisms.

ESS 462.name: Environmental Climatology
ESS 462.description: Study of global energy budget, past climates, climate variability, climate distribution, and climate change. Emphasis on global warming and its potential impacts on ecosystems, societies, and global sustainability. Students are required to apply quantitative, computer, and oral communication skills to analyze and report climate data for environmental planning.

ESS 492.name: Internship
ESS 492.description: Supervised experience with a departmentally-approved employer. Student is responsible for making arrangements. Requirements include maintaining a daily log, supervisor evaluations, and a final report.

ESS 494.name: Special Topics in Environmental and Soil Sciences
ESS 494.description: Varying topics and formats addressing current issues in the Environmental and Soil Sciences.

ESS 499.name: Undergraduate Research in Environmental and Soil Sciences
ESS 499.description: Special research problems in environmental and soil sciences.

ETEC 386.name: Integrating Technology into the Curriculum
ETEC 386.description: Use of technology to support teaching and learning; designed to prepare teacher preparation students to integrate a variety of computer-based technologies into the PreK-12 curriculum and adapt these technologies for diverse populations including students with mild disabilities as well as ESL students. Includes the creation of a personal learning network and the strategies and techniques of integrating the Internet, digital images, multimedia slideshows, educational digital stories, web-based tools, and interactive whiteboards.

FDSC 100.name: Science of Food
FDSC 100.description: Introduction to food science, basic principles of food science.

FDSC 110.name: Fermented Foods of the World
FDSC 110.description: Principles of food fermentation, fermented foods throughout the world, and health aspects of fermented foods.

FDSC 150.name: History and Culture of Food
FDSC 150.description: Impact of people and historical events on the production, distribution, and consumption patterns of food. The role of food as an indicator of cultural, societal, and historical changes around the world. Major technological advances in food processing and their impact on the globalization of the food supply.

FDSC 201.name: Professional Development
FDSC 201.description: Professional development expectations and opportunities. Individual written and oral reports. Group discussions on careers and food companies.

FDSC 241.name: Food Preservation and Packaging
FDSC 241.description: Principles, methods, and equipment used for preservation of foods.

FDSC 341.name: Food Engineering
FDSC 341.description: Units and dimensions, physical properties, transport processes, fluid flow, heat transfer, thermal and nonthermal preservation processes, refrigeration, freezing, evaporation, psychrometrics, mass transfer, membrane separations, and dehydration.

FDSC 390.name: Food Laws and Regulations
FDSC 390.description: A comprehensive examination of the laws and regulations designed to preserve the safety, wholesomeness, and nutritional quality of the United States food supply, and the agencies that enforce them.

FDSC 410.name: Food Chemistry
FDSC 410.description: Reactions of water, proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, minerals, enzymes, vitamins, and additives in foods.

FDSC 415.name: Food Analysis
FDSC 415.description: Principles, methods, and techniques for qualitative and quantitative analyses of composition and physical, chemical, and biological properties of food and food ingredients.

FDSC 418.name: Honors: Food Chemistry
FDSC 418.description: Reactions of water, proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, minerals, enzymes, vitamins, and additives in foods.

FDSC 419.name: Food Chemistry Lab
FDSC 419.description: Interaction of water, proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, minerals, enzymes, vitamins, and additives in foods and methods of evaluation of chemical properties of foods.

FDSC 421.name: Food Microbiology
FDSC 421.description: Physical, chemical, and environmental factors moderating growth and survival of foodborne microorganisms. Pathogenic and spoilage microorganisms affecting quality of foods and their control.

FDSC 428.name: Honors: Food Microbiology
FDSC 428.description: Physical, chemical, and environmental factors moderating growth and survival of foodborne microorganisms. Pathogenic and spoilage microorganisms affecting quality of foods and their control.

FDSC 429.name: Food Microbiology Lab
FDSC 429.description: Methods for examination, enumeration, cultivation, and identification of foodborne microorganisms.

FDSC 430.name: Sensory Evaluation of Food
FDSC 430.description: Principles and procedures of sensory evaluation of food, methods of test analyses, physiological, psychological, and environmental factors affecting sensory perception.

FDSC 442.name: Special Topics In Food Science
FDSC 442.description: Topics of current concern to the food industry.

FDSC 445.name: Applied Food Science
FDSC 445.description: Interactions and functions of dairy, egg, cereal, and other plant based ingredients during the production and storage of processed food products.

FDSC 490.name: Food Product Development
FDSC 490.description: Food Science capstone course. Application of principles of food chemistry, food processing and engineering, food microbiology, food laws and regulations, sensory evaluation, and statistics in the development of a food product concept.

FDSC 493.name: Practical Experience in Food Science
FDSC 493.description: Field experience in supervised internship in the food industry or relevant supervised experience in food science laboratory-related work. Students may not receive credit for FDSC 493 for paid work in the Department of Food Science. Pay for food industry internships is permissible and at the discretion of the industry sponsor.

FDSC 494.name: Scientific Presentation and Reporting
FDSC 494.description: A partner course for FDSC 493 - Practical Experience in Food Science or FDSC 499 - Undergraduate Research in Food Science (Undergraduate Research in Food Science) to serve as a platform for orally presenting research, internship, and laboratory experience in a variety of audiences.

FDSC 495.name: Quality Assurance and Sanitation Practices
FDSC 495.description: Design and evaluation of an industrial food processing operation to produce safe and high quality food products. Introduction to Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP) and Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) Programs.

FDSC 499.name: Undergraduate Research in Food Science
FDSC 499.description: Experience in research projects under supervision of staff members. Student should make arrangements for research project with instructor prior to enrollment.

FINC 300.name: Fundamentals of Finance
FINC 300.description: Survey of the basic principles of finance.

FINC 301.name: Survey of Financial Management
FINC 301.description: Survey of financial management principles covering investment, financing, and asset management functions of the firm.

FINC 306.name: Financial Management
FINC 306.description: Principles of financial management. Investment, financing, and asset management functions of the firm.

FINC 307.name: Honors: Survey of Financial Management
FINC 307.description: Survey of financial management principles covering investment, financing, and asset management functions of the firm.

FINC 308.name: Honors: Financial Management
FINC 308.description: Principles of financial management. Investment, financing, and asset management functions of the firm.

FINC 381.name: Real Estate Principles
FINC 381.description: Introduces the complexities of real estate and relative importance of value as a basis for effective decision-making. Covers the nature of real estate markets, participants, property rights, governmental policy, appraisal, investment, risk analysis, and contracts.

FINC 420.name: Financial Statement Analysis
FINC 420.description: Focus of course is on use of financial information rather than preparation of financial statements. Analysis is from the perspective of key users such as creditors, equity investors, financial analysts, and investment bankers.

FINC 425.name: Investment and Portfolio Management
FINC 425.description: Rigorous introduction to the fundamental principles and concepts of the valuation of stock and bonds (financial assets) in competitive and efficient financial markets. Risk and return analysis of portfolios of financial assets, capital market theory, security market theory, financial market microstructure, and professional ethics.

FINC 427.name: Honors: Investments and Portfolio Management
FINC 427.description: Rigorous introduction to the fundamental principles and concepts of the valuation of stocks and bonds (financial assets) in competitive and efficient financial markets. Risk and return analysis of portfolios of financial assets, capital market theory, security market theory, financial market microstructure, and professional ethics.

FINC 428.name: Honors: Financial Statement Analysis
FINC 428.description: Focus of course is on use of financial information rather than preparation of financial statements. Analysis is from the perspective of key users such as creditors, equity investors, financial analysts, and investment bankers.

FINC 435.name: Financial Markets and Institutions
FINC 435.description: Examine the process of capital formation and allocation, including an evaluation of money and capital markets. Study the theories and mathematics of interest rate determination and characterize the financial services firms which participate in these markets. Review the corporate policies and practices of financial service firms, including management of interest-rate, default, technology, and regulatory risks.

FINC 440.name: Fixed Income Analysis and Markets
FINC 440.description: Course examines the markets for fixed-income securities and consists of a rigorous treatment of fixed-income securities, markets, and portfolios. Topics include but are not limited to bond pricing, yield measures, duration, convexity, credit risk, bonds with embedded options, and construction of fixed-income portfolios.

FINC 445.name: Financial Derivatives
FINC 445.description: Different types of derivative financial assets are the focus of this course. Emphasis will be placed on real-world applications of theoretical and conceptual material discussed in this class.

FINC 450.name: Advanced Capital Budgeting
FINC 450.description: Application of capital budgeting techniques, including cash flow projections, risk analysis, capital rationing, and cost of capital estimation, to complex business situations. Course is designed to incorporate a greater understanding of capital budgeting across various business disciplines.

FINC 455.name: Financial Management: Theory and Practice
FINC 455.description: Decision-making topics in financial management, including valuation, capital budgeting under uncertainty, cost of capital, capital structure theory, and dividend policy. Major writing requirement.

FINC 457.name: Honors: Financial Management, Theory and Practice
FINC 457.description: Decision-making topics in financial management, including valuation, capital budgeting under uncertainty, cost of capital, capital structure theory, and dividend policy. Major writing requirement.

FINC 475.name: Insurance and Financial Planning Management
FINC 475.description: Course will cover the basic principles of risk management; insurance; and financial, estate and retirement planning. For students interested, an optional component of the class may include material for property and casualty pre-licensing education.

FINC 481.name: Real Estate Finance and Investment Analysis
FINC 481.description: Explores the major concepts, principles, analytical methods, and tools used to evaluate the financing of and investment in real property. Emphasis is also placed on understanding the factors influencing the dynamics of commercial real estate markets.

FINC 482.name: Real Estate Cases
FINC 482.description: Builds upon knowledge and skills from other real estate coursework in applied analysis of "real world" assets and case studies. Includes in-depth market analysis, financial analysis, and presentation of results. Students will be introduced to data sources and widely used software, interact with speakers from industry, and submit work to regional, national, or international case competitions.

FINC 490.name: Finance Help Desk
FINC 490.description: Hold "Help Desk" hours and assist students currently enrolled in Finance courses.

FINC 492.name: Off-Campus Study
FINC 492.description: Professional internship with practicing professionals under the direction of a faculty member.

FINC 494.name: Bloomberg Basics
FINC 494.description: This proprietary training course teaches students how to navigate the Bloomberg terminal, download data in Excel, and analyze data in four market sectors: Equities, Fixed Income, Forex, and Commodities. These skills are applicable in future coursework and/or on the job site.

FINC 495.name: Investment Fund Management
FINC 495.description: Students manage a portfolio(s) of real dollars and have fiduciary responsibility regarding same. Emphasis is on decisions that must be made by and/or for the ultimate investor using analytical tools and empirical evidence.

FINC 496.name: Bloomberg Advanced
FINC 496.description: This is a proprietary training program designed for students to gather, describe, and analyze data on a Bloomberg terminal, with a focus on experiential learning. Bloomberg terminals and Excel API will be utilized to illustrate how data analytics can improve financial decision-making. Topics include Financial Statement Analysis, Equity Valuation & Analysis, Weighted Average Cost of Capital, Fixed Income Valuation & Analysis, Operating, Financial, and Combined Leverage, Mergers & Acquisitions and Raising Capital.

FINC 492N.name: Off-Campus Study
FINC 492N.description: Professional internship with practicing professionals under the direction of a faculty member.

FORS 100.name: Forests and Forestry in American Society
FORS 100.description: Introductory course examining the role of forests in shaping American culture and society and exploring the evolution of the forestry profession in North America.

FORS 214.name: Tree Biology
FORS 214.description: An introduction to the anatomy and development of woody plants, their reproduction, growth requirements, and functioning.

FORS 215.name: Forest Ecology
FORS 215.description: Ecological interactions among tree species, other plant and animal species, and their environment. Forest ecosystem classification; energy, nutrient, and hydrologic cycles; and site quality. Perturbations and growth, survival and forest composition; forest succession; and fire ecology. Regeneration ecology through establishment and stand dynamics. Physiological ecology, ecological strategies, and adaptations of trees.

FORS 217.name: Honors: Tree Biology
FORS 217.description: Students will attend FORS 214 classes with supplementary assignments.

FORS 305.name: Prescribed Fire Management
FORS 305.description: Prescribed fire ecology, use, and management in forest stands.

FORS 314.name: Economics of Forest and Wildland Resources
FORS 314.description: Basic principles of forest resource economics, finance, and valuation. Microeconomic applications for forestry and natural resources. Financial analysis of private and public natural resource management decisions.

FORS 317.name: Honors: Economics of Forest and Wildland Resources
FORS 317.description: Students will attend FORS 314 classes with supplementary assignments.

FORS 321.name: Wildland Recreation
FORS 321.description: Introduction to Wildland Recreation: Historical and philosophical foundations of recreation, wildland recreation behavior, resources, policy, planning and management, and natural history interpretation.

FORS 322.name: Silvicultural Practices
FORS 322.description: Application of silvicultural techniques and tree improvement. Use of herbicides and fire management.

FORS 323.name: People and Forest Practices
FORS 323.description: Examination of how people, institutions, and society at large affect and are affected by forest management practices. Case studies and field applications will concentrate on the wide variety of linkages that exist in society among people and forests. Application of basic skills of collaborative problem solving will be emphasized. Overnight field trips are required.

FORS 327.name: Honors: Wildland Recreation
FORS 327.description: Students will attend FORS 321* classes with supplementary assignments.

FORS 329.name: Forest Resource Inventory
FORS 329.description: Tree, log, and lumber scaling and grading. Land inventory and stand mapping. Volume estimation.

FORS 331.name: Wood Science
FORS 331.description: A survey of the anatomy, properties, applications, and impacts of wood materials. Includes training in wood identification. Recommended for foresters, engineers, architects, materials scientists, and anyone with an interest in this important natural resource.

FORS 332.name: Forest Products Industry
FORS 332.description: An overview of the many steps in wood products manufacturing, from forest harvest to finished products. Includes visits to industrial facilities.

FORS 335.name: Principles of Urban Forestry
FORS 335.description: Introductory course covers the history of the urban forest, benefits and costs of urban forests, tree biology, urban soil, urban forestry planning and management, urban forestry and public policy, and public works.

FORS 337.name: Honors: Wood Properties and Uses
FORS 337.description: Students will attend FORS 331 classes with supplementary assignments.

FORS 345.name: Practical Arboriculture
FORS 345.description: Students will be exposed to modern hands-on techniques in arboriculture that will demonstrate real-world situations and teach students to respond appropriately. Techniques covered will include climbing, cabling, bracing, and pruning.

FORS 411.name: Principles of Wood Procurement and Forest Operations
FORS 411.description: An introduction to wood procurement, forest road building, and harvest planning. Topics will include different procurement methods, financial and resource assessment, negotiation skills, and legal requirements of wood procurement; basic forest hydrology and road construction concepts; and harvest technology and planning.

FORS 414.name: Tree Physiology
FORS 414.description: Tree structure, growth, development, function, and how these are related to the environment and to cultural practices. Influence of environmental variables on plant growth and distribution. Effects of forest management practices on growth and function.

FORS 420.name: Forest Resource Management
FORS 420.description: Introduction to forest-level management concepts from an economic perspective. Harvest determination; goal setting under multiple-use concepts; taxes; classical approaches to regulation, linear programming and harvest scheduling; and goal programming.

FORS 422.name: Forest and Wildland Resource Policy
FORS 422.description: Policy formulation and criteria for policy determination. Forest and wildland law and regulation. Theory of conflict resolution. Formal and informal resolution.

FORS 423.name: Wildland Recreation Planning and Management
FORS 423.description: Planning processes, master and site planning, and site design projects. Management strategies and methods of visitor and recreation site management. Case studies. Weekend field trips may be required.

FORS 427.name: Honors: Forest Resource Management
FORS 427.description: Students will attend FORS 420 classes with supplementary assignments.

FORS 433.name: Urbanization and Urban Soils
FORS 433.description: Course will cover the below-ground factors that affect tree establishment and survival in urban areas, specifically addressing the importance of soil structure, density, pH, water availability, and chemical properties (i.e. minerals, CEC).

FORS 435.name: Trees and the Law
FORS 435.description: Course will evaluate tree law cases in the United States, focusing primarily on tree problems between private neighbors, government, and public utilities.

FORS 492.name: Practicum in Forestry
FORS 492.description: Supervised experience at departmental-approved employment location.

FORS 493.name: Independent Study in Forestry
FORS 493.description: Special research or individual problem in forestry.

FORS 495.name: Internship in Wildland Recreation
FORS 495.description: A highly-structured field experience guided by specific learning objectives. Students earn one credit per two weeks of full-time field experience. The student is responsible for field placement. Must be pre-approved by the instructor and the field supervisor.

FORS 496.name: Internship in Forestry
FORS 496.description: Supervised experience at departmental-approved employment location arranged by the student. Students earn one credit per two weeks of full-time field experience. Internship learning objectives must be pre-approved by the advisor/instructor and the field supervisor. Daily log, supervisor evaluations, and final report required.

FREN 150.name: Intermediate French Transition
FREN 150.description: This course is designed to prepare students for enrollment in FREN 211.

FREN 217.name: Honors: Intermediate French I
FREN 217.description: For students of superior ability in French. Students follow enriched program with emphasis on speaking ability and reading, including literary selections.

FREN 218.name: Honors: Intermediate French II
FREN 218.description: For students of superior ability in French. Students follow enriched program with emphasis on speaking ability and reading, including literary selections.

FREN 302.name: Elements of French for Upper-Division and Graduate Students
FREN 302.description: Elements of language, elementary and advanced readings.

FREN 333.name: Intermediate Composition and Grammar
FREN 333.description: Emphasizes writing skills. Review of major grammatical points in French.

FREN 334.name: Intermediate Conversation and Phonetics
FREN 334.description: Emphasizes speaking skills, especially pronunciation. Further review of French grammar.

FREN 353.name: Introduction to Literary Analysis in French
FREN 353.description: Introduction to close reading and analysis of literary texts written in French. Works from a variety of periods and genres.

FREN 400.name: Consecutive and Simultaneous French-English and English-French Translation
FREN 400.description: Consecutive translation to and from English. Introduction to simultaneous translation to English.

FREN 405.name: Language and Culture of Business in the Francophone World
FREN 405.description: Study of basic French commercial terminology and institutions, in a global economic and political context.

FREN 410.name: Topics in Medieval/Early Modern French Literature
FREN 410.description: Close reading and analysis of literary texts from the Medieval/early modern periods.

FREN 415.name: Topics in Modern French and Francophone Literature
FREN 415.description: Close reading and analysis of modern and contemporary literary texts in French.

FREN 420.name: French Cinema
FREN 420.description: The French cinema from its earliest days to the present; introduction to Francophone film. Taught in English. Films in French with English subtitles.

FREN 421.name: Phonetics
FREN 421.description: Foundation in the science of phonetics. Practical exercises and individual performance.

FREN 422.name: Advanced Grammar
FREN 422.description: Improving one's written French by studying basic and more refined structures of the French language. Writing creative free-style compositions.

FREN 425.name: Introduction to Descriptive Linguistics
FREN 425.description: Introduction to concepts and methods of modern linguistics with an emphasis on analyzing the structure of human language. Provides a strong grounding in techniques of linguistic analysis in the subfields of phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, pragmatics.

FREN 431.name: Highlights of French Civilization
FREN 431.description: Survey of French civilization from the Gauls to World War II.

FREN 432.name: Contemporary French Culture
FREN 432.description: Current French cultural issues placed in historical perspective with a comparative emphasis.

FREN 433.name: French and Francophone Women Writers
FREN 433.description: Works by women writing in French from the Middle Ages to the present, considered in the context of French and Anglophone gender theory.

FREN 440.name: Capstone Experience in French
FREN 440.description: Synthesizing senior colloquium and tutorial in which students reflect on the raison d'être of the discipline from a multidimensional point of view.

FREN 450.name: Special Topics in French and Francophone Literature

FREN 455.name: Special Topics in French and Francophone History and Culture

FREN 490.name: Internship
FREN 490.description: Career-related experiences in the United States or abroad.

FREN 490N.name: Internship
FREN 490N.description: Career-related experiences in the United States or abroad.

FWF 212.name: Dendrology and Silvics of North American Trees
FWF 212.description: Identification, classification, and nomenclature of important North American trees and woody shrubs. Forest associations. Silvicultural characteristics of trees and stands as the basis for the practice of silviculture. Day field trips may be required.

FWF 250.name: Conservation
FWF 250.description: Use and abuse of wildland resources. Historical perspectives and current management of forests, wildlife, and fish of North America including aspects of outdoor recreation and pollution problems.

FWF 310.name: Wildland Fire Behavior and Management
FWF 310.description: An introduction to wildland fire management, covering the fundamentals of fire behavior, fire weather, equipment, and safety.

FWF 312.name: Principles of Silviculture
FWF 312.description: Principles for treating forest stands to achieve selected objectives.

FWF 313.name: Measurements and Sampling
FWF 313.description: Measurement techniques and sampling methods for vegetation. Estimation of animal populations. Map and aerial photo use.

FWF 315.name: Principles of Wildlife and Fisheries Management
FWF 315.description: Ecological relationships of wild animals with other animals and their habitats. Biological, social, and economic aspects of their management.

FWF 320.name: Human Dimensions of Natural Resources
FWF 320.description: Natural resource management as a social process focusing on how human, social, and institutional factors interact and integrate with complex and dynamic biophysical systems. Influence on natural resource management of human institutions, values, attitudes and behaviors, and place.

FWF 324.name: Applied Ecosystem Restoration
FWF 324.description: This course will build upon the principles of ecology to cover the theory and practical knowledge needed to restore the structure and function of ecosystems.

FWF 325.name: Wildlife Vegetation and Habitat
FWF 325.description: Introduction to interactions between plants and wildlife, including species of conservation concern. Emphasis is on plant species that comprise east Tennessee's primary wildlife habitats, and the utility of vegetation data in management. Students will be required to participate in at least one day-long field trip.

FWF 415.name: Upland Habitat Management
FWF 415.description: Detailed examination of applied management practices and their impact on wildlife habitat in forests, early successional cover, and cropland. Includes silvicultural techniques, prescribed fire, mechanical field treatment, herbicides, and food plots.

FWF 416.name: Planning and Management of Forest, Wildlife and Fisheries Resources
FWF 416.description: Integrated forest and wildland resource management through developing land management plans and analyzing case studies including conflict resolution.

FWF 420.name: International Natural Resource Issues
FWF 420.description: Identification and analyses of issues regarding forestry, wildlife, fisheries, and associated natural resources beyond U.S. borders. Biophysical, economic, and cultural elements impacting natural resources at the international level. Cases ― Northern Europe, Latin America, Indonesia, and Africa.

FWF 427.name: Honors International Natural Resource Issues
FWF 427.description: Identification and analyses of issues regarding forestry, wildlife, fisheries, and associated natural resources beyond U.S. borders. Biophysical, economic, and cultural elements impacting natural resources at the international level. Cases ― Northern Europe, Latin America, Indonesia, and Africa.

FWF 430.name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS) for Natural Resources
FWF 430.description: Introductory course in geographic information systems (GIS), with applications in natural resources. This course emphasizes creating detailed, professional grade maps, but also includes the basics of the theory, data collection, and analyses associated with GIS.

FWF 432.name: Communicating Forestry, Wildlife, and Fisheries Issues
FWF 432.description: Identification of the complex issues related to forestry, wildlife, and fisheries (FWF) management and conservation and develop the environmental communication skills needed to effectively convey these issues to various target audiences.

FWF 490.name: Topics in Forestry, Wildlife, and Fisheries
FWF 490.description: Current issues and problems in forestry, wildlife, and fisheries.

FWF 499.name: Undergraduate Research
FWF 499.description: Experience in research projects under supervision of staff members. Student should make arrangements for research project with instructor prior to enrollment.

FWF 325S.name: Wildlife Vegetation and Habitat
FWF 325S.description: Introduction to interactions between plants and wildlife, including species of conservation concern. Emphasis is on plant species that comprise east Tennessee's primary wildlife habitats, and the utility of vegetation data in management. Students will be required to participate in at least one day-long field trip.
