We consider the education of practitioners, locations of healing, and expectations that people had of medicine as ideas about the body and illness shifted with new discoveries and theories about health and disease. We examine the roles both of prominent individuals (Harvey, Pasteur, Ehrlich) and of general trends (industrialization, technology) in shaping medical practice and the medical professions.

HIST 373.name: Historical Issues
HIST 373.description: Variable content. Selected topics in history. Thematic focus, lecture-discussion format.

HIST 384.name: The History of Ireland and Irish in the World
HIST 384.description: Irish history from prehistory to the present, in a world-historical context. Explores emigration and experience of Irish immigrants outside Ireland.

HIST 385.name: Studies in World History
HIST 385.description: Variable content. Selected topics in world history involving analysis of two or more world cultures.

HIST 397.name: Honors Studies in History
HIST 397.description: Course for students admitted to honors programs. Variable Content seminar on various topics from a humanities perspective, with specific disciplinary content determined by instructor.

HIST 399.name: Technology and Innovation in Modern History
HIST 399.description: This course explores how culture and politics have shaped technological development, drawing on examples from the last three centuries. Historical topics are selected to shed light on contemporary controversies about the appropriate use of technology; students will examine contemporary debates about technology use in tandem with historical cases in which similar issues were at stake.

HIST 407.name: Honors: Senior Paper
HIST 407.description: Research for the senior thesis and completion of a partial draft. Required of students working for honors in history.

HIST 408.name: Honors: Senior Paper
HIST 408.description: Organization and writing of the senior honors thesis. Required of students working for honors in history.

HIST 410.name: Infectious Disease: A Global History
HIST 410.description: Course explores the social, political, biological, and environmental history of infectious diseases across the globe. Focuses on the histories of a select number of paradigmatic diseases (HIV-AIDS, syphilis, small pox, malaria) from a variety of geographical, chronological and methodological perspectives. Interdisciplinary approach. Research component.

HIST 415.name: Magic and Witchcraft in the Atlantic World
HIST 415.description: A survey of belief systems relating to witchcraft and magic from the Americas, Africa, and Europe prior to ca. 1850.

HIST 418.name: Honors: Seminar in Non-U.S. History
HIST 418.description: Variable content. Selected topics in non-U.S. history for honors students.

HIST 483.name: Historical Issues
HIST 483.description: Content varies. Selected topics in history.

HIST 485.name: Studies in Cross Cultural History
HIST 485.description: Comparative analysis of specific historical issues or specific facets of the relationships between two or more cultures. Variable content.

HIST 490.name: Internship in the Center for the Study of War and Society
HIST 490.description: A structured field work experience in public history at a research center documenting modern U.S. military history, including special projects such as grant writing, interviewing, and archival processing.

HIST 499.name: Senior Research Seminar
HIST 499.description: Historical writing based on original research in primary sources. Variable content. Required for all majors except history honors students. Writing-emphasis course.

HIUS 227.name: Honors: History of the United States

HIUS 228.name: Honors: History of the United States

HIUS 300.name: The Rise and Fall of Slavery in the United States
HIUS 300.description: History of the rise and fall of racial slavery in the United States.

HIUS 301.name: Borders, Burritos, and Gringos: The Entangled Histories of the United States and Mexico
HIUS 301.description: Explores the relationship of the United States and Mexico over five centuries, and their parallel and intersecting histories.

HIUS 302.name: The History of Immigration in the U.S. and the World
HIUS 302.description: Course offers a historical treatment of migrations, with focus on emigrants to the US but also within Europe. Discussion of causes and large consequences of immigration for today.

HIUS 310.name: American History Through Video Games
HIUS 310.description: This course explores how American history is represented (and misrepresented) on the digital screen. Games explored and chronological/geographical focus variable. Writing-emphasis course.

HIUS 312.name: Eastern Native American History
HIUS 312.description: Historical survey of Native American people who lived east of the Appalachians before contact through 1865. Writing-emphasis course.

HIUS 314.name: Native American Art and Material Culture
HIUS 314.description: Historical survey of the various forms of Native American Art and Material Culture from an Indigenous activist perspective.

HIUS 323.name: Rich and Poor in America
HIUS 323.description: This course examines the history of wealth and poverty in American society, with particular attention to the impact of economic inequality on democratic ideals and practices.

HIUS 325.name: Women in American History
HIUS 325.description: Experiences and perspectives of women in the US from the pre-Columbian era through the end of the 20th century.

HIUS 326.name: Gay American History
HIUS 326.description: History of same-sex desires, behaviors, relations, and politics from colonial America to the present.

HIUS 329.name: Native American History
HIUS 329.description: Histories of Native Americans East and West of the Mississippi.

HIUS 339.name: The History of Medicine in the Movies
HIUS 339.description: In this course, we explore the social and cultural history of 20th and early 21st century American medicine through the depiction of health care practitioners and health care systems in Hollywood movies. We use films as our central primary source, watching thirteen movies during the semester. Movies reveal a great deal about what was taken for granted at the time of each film's production. We examine how a range of social and professional conditions affected medicine over a century, including gender and race relations; physicians' paternalism and patients' autonomy; medical technology and expectations for care and cure; and ethical and professional norms for medical research and decision-making in-patient care. Readings from a variety of secondary and primary sources help us to put these films into their historical contexts.

HIUS 346.name: African American Religious History
HIUS 346.description: Focus on diverse religious histories of African Americans from the earliest years of the trans-Atlantic slave trade; transmission of African cultures to the New World to the present.

HIUS 349.name: United States Military History
HIUS 349.description: Shifting strategy, tactics, and weaponry involved in US wars. Relationship between American society and its armed forces.

HIUS 350.name: Colonial America to 1763
HIUS 350.description: Social and cultural developments in the American colonies from first contact between Europeans and native peoples through the mid-18th century.

HIUS 351.name: The American Revolution
HIUS 351.description: Growing estrangement of the American colonies from the British Empire; War for Independence; creation of American republic.

HIUS 352.name: The Early American Republic
HIUS 352.description: Examines economic, political, and social developments in early 19th-century America.

HIUS 353.name: The Civil War and Reconstruction Eras
HIUS 353.description: Examines major political, economic, and social developments in the United States during Civil War and Reconstruction eras.

HIUS 354.name: United States, 1877-1933
HIUS 354.description: America's political, economic, and social development from the Gilded Age through the Great Depression.

HIUS 355.name: United States 1933-Present
HIUS 355.description: American experience from New Deal to present. Emphasizes domestic history but includes military and foreign policy.

HIUS 356.name: The 1960s in America
HIUS 356.description: Politics, empowerment movements, and cultural rebellions of the 1960s

HIUS 361.name: Free Speech Fights: The First Amendment in American History
HIUS 361.description: Explores the origin and crucial turning points in the evolution of freedom of speech and freedom of the press in the United States.

HIUS 362.name: History of American Education
HIUS 362.description: Examines origins of education and rise of public schools in what is now the United States, from era before European colonization to present.

HIUS 363.name: U.S. Constitutional History to 1877
HIUS 363.description: Constitutional development of the United States through the end of Reconstruction.

HIUS 364.name: U.S. Constitutional History 1877-Present
HIUS 364.description: Constitutional development of the United States from the end of Reconstruction to the present.

HIUS 365.name: Food and Power in U.S. History
HIUS 365.description: American history through lenses of food and agriculture; emphasizes social, political, economic, and environmental questions, and interactions with the non-human world.

HIUS 373.name: Mo Money, Mo Problems: The History of Black Business in the United States
HIUS 373.description: This course examines the longstanding tradition of Black business in the United States.

HIUS 374.name: History of the Civil Rights Movement in the United States
HIUS 374.description: Examines history of the civil rights movement in the United States from Reconstruction to the present.

HIUS 376.name: African American Womenʼs History from Slavery to the Present
HIUS 376.description: Social, cultural, political, and economic history of black women in the United States from the earliest importation of slaves from Africa and the Caribbean to the present.

HIUS 379.name: African American Experience from Colonial Period to Civil War
HIUS 379.description: African American history to the Civil War era.

HIUS 380.name: African American Experience from Civil War to the Present

HIUS 381.name: History of Tennessee
HIUS 381.description: Tennessee's history from the 18th century to the present.

HIUS 382.name: Appalachian History
HIUS 382.description: Appalachian region from pre-Columbian times to post-industrial era.

HIUS 383.name: Studies in United States History
HIUS 383.description: Aspects of United States history. Content varies.

HIUS 386.name: Studies in Atlantic World History
HIUS 386.description: Integration of peoples and regions around the Atlantic Ocean. Ocean-centered focus. Content varies.

HIUS 395.name: American Experience in WWII
HIUS 395.description: Diplomacy and warfare in Europe and Asia; impact on American society.

HIUS 396.name: The American Century
HIUS 396.description: Focuses on role of popular culture in shaping and reflecting American ideals and influence in a 20th-century, global context.

HIUS 399.name: Podcasting US History
HIUS 399.description: Students in this course learn the skills needed to for creating podcasts while studying United States history. Students acquire abilities in oral communication and the technical aspects of podcasting, then create a podcast on a topic in US history. Historical content will vary by semester.

HIUS 417.name: Honors: Seminar in U. S. History
HIUS 417.description: Selected topics in American history for honors students.

HIUS 436.name: History of Gender and Sexuality in the United States
HIUS 436.description: Examines role of gender and sexuality in American social and cultural history.

HIUS 441.name: The American West
HIUS 441.description: Examines "the West" as both frontier and region, real and imagined, from the first contacts between natives and colonizers to multicultural encounters of the 20th century.

HIUS 443.name: Medicine and Healing in the Age of Slavery
HIUS 443.description: This course centers on the relationship between the practices of medicine and healing in the Age of Slavery (from the 16th century to Emancipation, mainly in the U.S. and the British Caribbean, with some readings on Cuba and Brazil). Our readings will begin with the West's construction of race as a physical, medical, and biological "fact."  We will contrast evidence of the realities of sickness under slavery and contemporary medical treatments with how enslaved communities used herbal healing traditions and other rituals employed to address afflictions of body and spirit. Finally, the class will consider the ethical implications of the intertwined history of slavery, race and science--and its legacies today.

HIUS 444.name: History of the South
HIUS 444.description: New South from Reconstruction through the Second Reconstruction.

HIUS 450.name: America and the World
HIUS 450.description: Course examines the impact of the modern United States on world history, and the impact that the world has had on modern U.S. history. Alongside traditional topics like war and diplomacy, the course emphasizes migration, social movements, intellectual and cultural exchanges, business and capitalism, and empire.

HIUS 471.name: The US-Mexican War
HIUS 471.description: The nineteenth-century borderland region between the United States and Mexico witnessed migration, conflict, and, eventually, outright warfare between the two republics. From the violent birth of the Texas Republic to the often-forgotten U.S.-Mexican War of 1846-1848, this course surveys political, social, cultural, and military history to understand what this contentious era meant to the diverse people drawn into the struggle.

HIUS 484.name: Studies in United States History
HIUS 484.description: Aspects of United States history. Content varies.

HONR 317.name: College Scholars Seminar
HONR 317.description: Sequence (HONR 317 and HONR 318) is required of all College Scholars each year and may be taken in any order.

HONR 318.name: College Scholars Seminar
HONR 318.description: Sequence (HONR 317 and HONR 318) is required of all College Scholars each year and may be taken in any order.

HONR 498.name: Honors: College Scholars Studies
HONR 498.description: Designed for College Scholars working on senior thesis, project, or performance.

HRM 360.name: Managing Human Resources
HRM 360.description: Theory, methods, and issues used to manage human resources in contemporary organizations. Overview of how organizations attract, motivate, develop, and retain employees, and how they interact with organizations representing employees. Designed to provide students with an opportunity to understand the functional areas of human resource management and the integration of these functions into an effective and efficient human resource management system.

HRM 480.name: Developing Human Resources
HRM 480.description: Ensuring that the skills, knowledge, abilities, and performance of the workforce meet the current and future organizational and individual needs through developing, implementing, and evaluating activities and programs addressing employee training and development, change and performance management, and the unique needs of particular employee groups.

HRM 481.name: Recruitment and Selection
HRM 481.description: Workforce planning, recruitment and selection, organizational entry and socialization. Planning, developing, implementing, administering, and performing ongoing evaluation of recruiting, hiring, orientation, and organizational exit to ensure that the workforce will meet the organization's goals and objectives.

HRM 482.name: Employee and Labor Relations
HRM 482.description: Developing, implementing, and evaluating the workplace to enhance relationships and the working environment. Learning and reviewing employer/employee needs and rights that support the organization's goals and objectives.

HRM 485.name: Compensation and Benefits
HRM 485.description: Strategies for maintaining high performance. Performance appraisal, compensation and benefits, employee and labor relations, health, safety and security issues.

HRM 490.name: Application of the Internship Experience
HRM 490.description: This course is designed to reflect on the students' internship experience to develop skills they can transfer to their career. It will develop analytical skills as well as develop their knowledge of career options in the field of management and human resources. This course will also prepare students to anticipate and successfully navigate the job search process.

HRM 492.name: Internship and Career Development
HRM 492.description: The internship has two parts, class and on-site work experience. The practical experience is critical in understanding the HRM curriculum and assists the student in reaching his/her career goal and in many cases leads to a full-time job. The classroom portion assists the student in getting ready for the corporate world through personality assessment, salary negotiation and professional networking. This class and practical experience will support the learning outcomes of the undergraduate assessment completed each year in the undergraduate program.

HRM 495.name: Special Topics
HRM 495.description: Detailed study of a specialized area of human resource management. Topics vary by semester and include human resource consulting, global staffing and human capital management, and current topics in human resource management.

HRM 496.name: Human Resource Management Guest Lecture Series
HRM 496.description: Reserved for short, topic specific lectures and workshops available to all students with an interest in the special topic. Topics may be different from semester to semester.

HRM 492N.name: Internship and Career Development
HRM 492N.description: The internship has two parts, class and on-site work experience. The practical experience is critical in understanding the HRM curriculum and assists the student in reaching his/her career goal and in many cases leads to a full-time job. The classroom portion assists the student in getting ready for the corporate world through personality assessment, salary negotiation and professional networking. This class and practical experience will support the learning outcomes of the undergraduate assessment completed each year in the undergraduate program.

HSP 207.name: Haslam Scholars Leadership Seminar
HSP 207.description: Exploration of critical issues in leadership and community engagement. Topics will vary. HSP 207 and HSP 208 required of all Haslam Scholars during their first and second years.

HSP 208.name: Haslam Scholars Leadership Seminar
HSP 208.description: Exploration of critical issues in leadership and community engagement. Topics will vary. HSP 207 and HSP 208 required of all Haslam Scholars during their first and second years.

HSP 287.name: Knowledge:
HSP 287.description: An examination of the purposes and value of education in a democratic society.

HSP 397.name: Honors Research
HSP 397.description: Designed for Haslam Scholars beginning their thesis/capstone research.

HSP 497.name: Honors Thesis I
HSP 497.description: Substantial scholarly, scientific, or artistic endeavor representing the capstone of a student's undergraduate education.

HSP 498.name: Honors Thesis II
HSP 498.description: Substantial scholarly, scientific, or artistic endeavor representing the capstone of a student's undergraduate education.

HTM 101.name: Science of Foods and Culinary Fundamentals
HTM 101.description: Scientific principles involved with selection, preparation, and evaluation of quality food.

HTM 102.name: Introduction to the Business of Hospitality and Travel
HTM 102.description: The class is a complete overview of the hospitality and travel industry. It will focus on the scope and pervasiveness of all facets of hospitality and tourism, and financial impacts.

HTM 150.name: Career Planning
HTM 150.description: This class focuses on resumes, cover letters, job interviewing, and professional interaction skills in the Retail, Hospitality, and Tourism Management industry.

HTM 210.name: Foodservice Operations Management
HTM 210.description: Principles of menu development, equipment selection, layout, purchasing, production, and service of food in volume.

HTM 211.name: Hotel and Resort Operations
HTM 211.description: Operational theory of lodging and an exploration of the lodging industry in terms of nature of work, organizational structure of lodging segments, the meaning of guest services, differentiation of brands, current industry issues, and evaluation of the market place.

HTM 212.name: Event Planning and Design
HTM 212.description: Understanding the concepts and models of conventions/meetings, roles of meeting planners, identifying decision makers, site selection, negotiating, budgeting, and marketing commitment.

HTM 225.name: Principles and Science of Foodservice Baking
HTM 225.description: This course will cover the basics of a bakeshop focusing on leavening agents, binding ingredients, and fats. With the ingredients of salt, flour, water, and yeast students will learn basic bread making of multiple styles of bread. Desserts covered in this course consist of custards, cakes, pies, and pastries.

HTM 299.name: Beverage Management
HTM 299.description: This course is designed as an overview of contemporary issues in beverage management, including general instruction in wines, beers, spirits and the legal implications relative to their selling, serving, and consumption.

HTM 311.name: Human Resources Management in Hospitality and Retailing
HTM 311.description: The core concepts of managing an organization's culturally-diverse workforce ― recruitment and selection, training and development, and employee relations.

HTM 326.name: Financial Management for the Hospitality Industry
HTM 326.description: Budget, cost analysis, computer, financial statement use in decision-making in lodging and foodservice systems.

HTM 335.name: Advanced Foodservice Techniques and Applications
HTM 335.description: This course will cover protein fabrication and cookery, sauce production, starches, grains, vegetables, and plate presentation. Students will learn recipe and menu writing along with the ability to prepare bulk quantities of food.

HTM 361.name: Issues and Trends in Customer Service
HTM 361.description: Building competencies in providing outstanding customer service in hospitality and tourism organizations. This course will create a unified approach to customer service; recognizing the importance of organization policies; internal marketing; and theories, examples, and approaches that will lead to increased business by attracting and retaining desired customers.

HTM 390.name: Leadership and Managing Corporate Culture
HTM 390.description: This class has been designed to address the unique transitional needs of hospitality students as leaders and pillars within today's society. More specifically, we will use this course to promote personal and professional development awareness. You will learn soft skills that assist with the development of individual leadership and organizational leadership tactics. This course will be structured to address self-awareness or self-mastery, to address the psychological issues that accompany your transition in today's diverse workforce.

HTM 410.name: Strategic Marketing for Hospitality and Tourism
HTM 410.description: Partnering with stakeholders within the hospitality and tourism industries to assist with enhancing tourism. Explores socio-cultural impacts of tourism and hospitality industries in order to sustainably create marketing plans for industry partners. Enhances soft skills through leadership, team building, and communication activities. Build on the principles of marketing knowledge from previous courses to promote their destination in a sustainable manner. Creates socially responsible future tourism consultants that understand strategic marketing plans that benefit all stakeholders in the community.

HTM 425.name: Legal Issues in Service Management
HTM 425.description: Legal rights and responsibilities of service industry managers, their staff, and clientele.

HTM 435.name: Advanced Event Planning and Design
HTM 435.description: Management techniques used in the execution of meetings, marketing, conventions, and special events. Emphasis on integration of management principles and strategic planning.

HTM 440.name: Special Topics: Hospitality and Tourism Management
HTM 440.description: Developments, issues, and problems in hotel, restaurant, and tourism. Variable topics.

HTM 445.name: Advanced Food Production and Service Management
HTM 445.description: Application of management concepts in menu design, personnel, cost control, and production and service of food.

HTM 450.name: Advanced Lodging Management
HTM 450.description: Designed to allow students to interpret operational problems currently occurring in the hotel industry in a case study, interactive environment. The student will analyze management opportunities and threats within a hotel and determine reasonable alternatives.

HTM 484.name: Critical Sustainable Tourism
HTM 484.description: Critical Sustainable Tourism: Explores the historic and current socio-cultural impacts of tourism on the environment, community, and government. Understand the complexities of tourism relationships from the host community and tourist perspective. Explain how tourism influences culture, communities, and societies through forces of racial/ethnic identity, class, gender, sex tourism, and the politicization of tourism. Identifying the power dynamics within tourism planning and development of a tourism destination. Emphasis on the study of both historic and current socio-cultural impacts of tourism on family, community, culture, government, and the environment, as well as other current issues.

HTM 492.name: Professional Experience
HTM 492.description: Supervised educational experiences in selected hospitality operations.

HTM 493.name: Independent Study
HTM 493.description: Individual problems or activities for students with special interests in hotel, restaurant, and tourism.

HTM 494.name: Directed Study: Hotel, Restaurant, and Tourism

IARC 101.name: Introduction to the Built Environment
IARC 101.description: Architectural design as a creative process based on visual thinking and ideas related to space, technology, and/or place. Scope and definition of the built environment in relation to contemporary society, building industry, and allied design professions. Orientation to courses and programs of the school.

IARC 107.name: Honors: Introduction to the Built Environment
IARC 107.description: Students will attend IARC 101 classes with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.

IARC 200.name: Human-Environment Relations
IARC 200.description: Introduction to environmental psychology theories: examine behavior in relationship to biological, social and environmental factors; role of needs assessments and research-based issues guiding design process.

IARC 207.name: Honors: Human-Environment Relations
IARC 207.description: Introduction to environmental psychology theories: examine behavior in relationship to biological, social and environmental factors; role of needs assessments and research-based issues guiding design process. Students will attend IARC 200* classes, with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.

IARC 211.name: History of Interior Design, Furnishings, and the Decorative Arts
IARC 211.description: Social, political, and physical influences through the movements and traditions of the interior environment in major world cultures from prehistoric – present.

IARC 217.name: Honors: History of Interior Design, Furnishings, and the Decorative Arts
IARC 217.description: Social, political, and physical influences through the movements and traditions of the interior environment in major world cultures from prehistoric – present. Students will attend IARC 211* classes, with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.

IARC 221.name: Theory of Color
IARC 221.description: History and application of color from a broader perspective on how it influenced the cultures of the United States as we know it today. Introduction to color systems and application of color in the interior environment. An expanded emphasis on how color may influence people, space, and place.

IARC 222.name: Interior Perspectives on Art
IARC 222.description: Examination of the relationships between interior spaces, notions of interiority, art, and material culture. Examining social contexts and the development of major movements in art and architectural history from the Renaissance to the present, and how this influenced or is reflected in the evolution of interior space design.

IARC 261.name: Materials, Resources and Textiles for Interiors
IARC 261.description: Application of interior architectural materials, textiles and resources used in designing interior environments. Focus on environmental sustainability, codes, function and aesthetics.

IARC 275.name: People, Spaces, Experiences & Politics
IARC 275.description: Introductory design investigations applying global contextual research of people, spaces, experiences and politics to the interior environment with a focus on historical, cultural, ethic, and/or social precedents which reinforce conceptual ideation and schematic design. Critical thinking through comparison and reflection, material explorations, and making are developed and applied based on global design research and perspectives. Program specified computer and software required.

IARC 276.name: Context, Concept, Input, and Interaction
IARC 276.description: Continuation of introductory design investigations of the interior environment. Emphasis on contextual analysis and development, design process from conceptual ideation to critical refinement of schematic design and user input/interaction. May be instructed in vertical, joint, or design build format. Program specified computer and software required.

IARC 321.name: Advanced Representation
IARC 321.description: Advanced digital workflow for building information management software as applicable to creative and professional development for interior architecture.

IARC 331.name: Construction Documents and Codes for Interior Architecture
IARC 331.description: Methods, processes, and procedures for creating construction documents for interior environments. Includes the use of building information management software, codes and regulations affecting the health, safety, and welfare of the public.

IARC 360.name: Business Principles and Practices
IARC 360.description: Inter-professional relationships and business practices, responsibilities, and liabilities.

IARC 361.name: Lighting for Interior Architecture
IARC 361.description: Lecture presentation of design principles in lighting, acoustics and mechanical systems. Course will emphasize fundamentals of lighting design practices and techniques.

IARC 372.name: Design Development and Construction Detailing Documentation for Interior Architecture
IARC 372.description: Comprehensive design process with emphasis on design development and basic construction documentation. Use of building information management software and focus on construction principles are integrated in the studio investigations. Program specified computer and software required.

IARC 375.name: Experimentation + Innovation
IARC 375.description: Intermediate Interior Architecture Studio focusing on design investigations of the interior environment with material systems and programming. Design process from program creation to conceptual ideation to critical refinement of schematic design. Program specified computer and software required.

IARC 376.name: Design Development and Construction Detailing Documentation for Interior Architecture
IARC 376.description: Comprehensive design process with emphasis on design development and basic construction documentation. Use of building information management software and focus on construction principles are integrated in the studio investigations. Program specified computer and software required.

IARC 420.name: Practicum for Interior Architecture
IARC 420.description: Supervised experience in a professional design firm. Business practices, project management and design philosophy.

IARC 422.name: Inclusive and Exclusive Design
IARC 422.description: An analysis of why design is important, how to engage community members in the design process, and design beyond aesthetics. Focus on empathy, collaboration, and community development as critical design competencies.

IARC 464.name: Research Methods for Designers
IARC 464.description: Exploration of design-related research methodologies. Topics cover the full life cycle of the research process, including: identifying a research question, evaluating significance, developing a conceptual framework, implementing a work plan, gathering, managing, and analyzing data, prototyping an argument, communicating research through writing as well as visualization and/or fabrication, presenting and publishing work.

IARC 475.name: Comprehensive Capstone Studio
IARC 475.description: Advanced design investigations of the interior environment. Emphasis on design process from conceptual ideation to critical refinement of design development. Projects include integration of large systems including fire separation, egress, lighting, materials, structure, acoustics, and environmental May be instructed in vertical, joint, or design build format. Program specified computer and software required.

IARC 476.name: Elective Studio
IARC 476.description: Advanced interior architecture investigations related to contemporary topics and theories. May be instructed in vertical, multi-disciplinary, self-directed, or design build format. Program specified computer and software required.

IARC 477.name: Honors: Senior Interior Architecture Project
IARC 477.description: Students will attend IARC 476 studio classes with supplementary design assignments required.

IARC 480.name: Furniture Design
IARC 480.description: Human factors data applied to design of body support, task support, storage and systems, construction drawings, and scale models. Advanced millwork design and materials and manufacturing processes.

IARC 491.name: International Study
IARC 491.description: Individual or group studio and/or study abroad. Academic research, field investigation, or studio experiences. Determination of credit based on particular international experience.

IARC 493.name: Directed Studies in Interior Architecture
IARC 493.description: Student- or staff-initiated research or studio investigation of special topic.

IARC 495.name: International Design Travel
IARC 495.description: International design travel. Students will participate in a culturally immersive experience to study, reflect, and critically compare all aspects of design including on-site historical and contemporary design, social context, religious practices, and social customs. Students will study design vocabulary in the native language of the designation and apply it within projects and writing assignments.

IARC 497.name: Honors: Independent Study in Interior Architecture
IARC 497.description: Individual studies and projects under faculty direction, for honors students only. Credit adjusted to complexity and level of effort required.

IARC 372S.name: Design Development and Construction Detailing Documentation for Interior Architecture – Service Learning
IARC 372S.description: Comprehensive design process with emphasis on design development and basic construction documentation. Use of building information management software and focus on construction principles are integrated in the studio investigations. Program specified computer and software required. Studio includes a service learning component through supervised projects with the community.

IB 407.name: Honors: International Business
IB 407.description: This course is designed to equip students with methods to lead, mobilize, and tackle challenges within an international business and multicultural context. Students will learn how to utilize a design thinking framework to become more adaptive and innovative leaders. The course explores how cultures, mindsets, and people vary, how to recognize these variances, and how to successfully lead and manage effectively within these environments. Through a combination of online learning modules, interactive lectures, and experiential assignments, students will explore unique opportunities and problems that confront leaders navigating in a global economic context.

IB 409.name: International Business
IB 409.description: Survey of strategic implications of conducting business operations in an international context. Analysis of relevant cross-national environments, including cultural, political, economic, and legal characteristics.

IB 429.name: International Economics for Business
IB 429.description: Statement of international transactions, exchange rate determination, risk management strategies, currency crises, monetary arrangements, comparative advantage, tariff and non-tariff trade distortions, trade policies, protectionist arguments, regional integration.

IB 439.name: Global Supply Chain Management
IB 439.description: Explores the complexities of managing supply chains in a global context. Addresses issues relating to the drivers of globalization and managing the supply and demand fulfillment processes across an extended and global organization. Topics include discussions of cultural differences, regional trading blocs, global procurement, offshoring, global infrastructure, security and risk, sustainability, market entry, service quality, gray markets, customer lifetime value, demand/supply integration.

IB 449.name: International Finance
IB 449.description: Understanding the intricacies of international finance including how multinational companies operate in a number of different business activities within multiple countries. Topics covered include international monetary system, balance of payments, exchange rate utilization, and foreign exchange derivatives including currency forwards, futures options and swaps.

IB 460.name: Global Capstone in International Business
IB 460.description: This capstone course is the culmination of the International Business coursework. It brings together knowledge gained in previous international business courses as well as abroad experiences and applies this to real-world business scenarios. Multidisciplinary in nature, this course will have contributions from multiple areas of business and will unify the major in a final cohort course. It is designed to develop and build the essential business, academic, and cultural skills necessary to succeed in international business with the inclusion of a consulting project that requires analysis of an international business situation.

IB 489.name: Study Abroad
IB 489.description: Study abroad program approved by the Haslam College of Business Undergraduate Programs Office.

IB 492.name: Off-Campus Study
IB 492.description: Internships are a chance for students to gain hands-on experience in the business world, apply the knowledge learned in the classroom to real-world problems, and develop important professional skills. By participating in an internship, students gain a competitive advantage for future employment by providing meaningful work experience and an introduction to a potential career or employer. With an international internship, students can acquire and hone additional skills that range from language proficiency to intercultural communication. IB 492 is intended for any internship, regardless of business major, that occurs outside of the United States. Students must be engaged in rigorous, professionally applicable work that relates to their field of study, educational goals and/or career aspirations that can be transferred to other employment or academic settings. The hiring organization must provide the student with a supervisor that provides routine feedback. Students will be eligible for 1 credit hour per 50 hours worked. The student can only enroll in IB 492 for the academic term in which they are completing the internship.

IB 499.name: Special Topics in International Business
IB 499.description: Topics of current interest in international business.

IB 492N.name: Off-Campus Study
IB 492N.description: Internships are a chance for students to gain hands-on experience in the business world, apply the knowledge learned in the classroom to real-world problems, and develop important professional skills. By participating in an internship, students gain a competitive advantage for future employment by providing meaningful work experience and an introduction to a potential career or employer. With an international internship, students can acquire and hone additional skills that range from language proficiency to intercultural communication. IB 492 is intended for any internship, regardless of business major, that occurs outside of the United States. Students must be engaged in rigorous, professionally applicable work that relates to their field of study, educational goals and/or career aspirations that can be transferred to other employment or academic settings. The hiring organization must provide the student with a supervisor that provides routine feedback. Students will be eligible for 1 credit hour per 50 hours worked. The student can only enroll in IB 492 for the academic term in which they are completing the internship.

IE 200.name: Engineering Statistics
IE 200.description: Introduction to probability concepts, probability distributions, data collection, descriptive statistics, discrete distributions, continuous distributions, estimation of means, confidence intervals, hypothesis tests, regression, and correlation. Emphasis on industrial engineering techniques for data collection, data analysis, and engineering probability and statistics.

IE 201.name: Introduction to Industrial and Systems Engineering
IE 201.description: This course introduces the incoming Industrial and Systems Engineering (ISE) students to the different aspects of the practice of industrial engineering including but not limited to supply chain logistics, healthcare, manufacturing and service operations, etc.

IE 202.name: Work Measurement and Introduction to Manufacturing Processes
IE 202.description: Introduction to methods, standards, work design, and productivity improvement. Work method design: exploratory, documentation, and analysis tools. Operation analysis: product, process and schedule design. Introduction to facilities layout, work design, work method improvement, time study, learning curves, and wage incentives systems. A survey of manufacturing processes, traditional machining, and non-traditional machining. Fundamental principles and procedures will be applied through a class project developed by students working in teams.

IE 250.name: Leadership in Industrial Engineering
IE 250.description: Aspects of leadership in a professional environment will be studied from current literature reading and discussions. Industry professionals will periodically lead the class to enlighten students to aspects of the practice of industrial engineering. Regular submission of written papers on assigned and discussed topics will be critically reviewed to emphasize key aspects of professional level written communications including content, format, and referencing.

IE 300.name: Quality Control and Management
IE 300.description: Theory and application of statistical quality control and improvement, including both traditional and modern methods; statistical process monitoring; and process and measurement system capability analysis.

IE 301.name: Operations Research I: Deterministic Models
IE 301.description: Integrated system modeling concepts. Linear mathematical programming models including modeling, the simplex procedure, sensitivity analysis, dual theory, transportation, transshipment, and assignment problems, and integer linear programming.

IE 304.name: Introduction to Human Factors Engineering
IE 304.description: Human capabilities and limitations affecting work, workplace, and work environment design. Emphasis on human factors methodology, human input requirements, human outputs, the design of human-machine interfaces, the analysis of stress on performance, and environmental factors such as noise, lighting, and atmospheric conditions. Focus on designing the task to fit the person.

IE 310.name: Operations Research II: Probabilistic Models
IE 310.description: Probabilistic Models, including decision makings under uncertainty, inventory models, Markov Chains, and queuing theory.

IE 317.name: Honors: Operations Research in Industrial Engineering II
IE 317.description: Students will attend IE 310 classes with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.

IE 340.name: Design of Experiments
IE 340.description: Development and discussion of fundamental theory, concepts and procedures required for the efficient design and analysis of industrial experiments. Topics covered include the statistical approach, screening procedures for factor and interaction effects in one-factor and multiple-factor experiments with and without restrictions on randomization, two-level and mixed-level full and fractional factorial designs with and without blocks, response surface methodology, and Taguchi methods. Integrated treatment of these topics provides knowledge and skills for process and product improvement in engineering applications. Use of specialized software for experimental data analysis.

IE 350.name: Service in Industrial Engineering
IE 350.description: Students engage in department outreach and engagement activities. Technical report writing and/or presentation is required. The credit earned from this course may be used as approved technical elective credit in the Industrial Engineering degree program (consult departmental academic advisor for details).

IE 401.name: Facilities Planning and Material Handling
IE 401.description: Fundamental concepts, theory and procedures for the study of facilities design and location; physical layout; material flow principles; and material handling. Product design, process planning and schedule design are integrated through the development of analytical procedures and use of layout planning software to enhance the decision-making process in the design, rationalization and improvement of factory and office layouts. The knowledge learned in this course is integrated with knowledge from selected related courses to develop a laboratory design project by students working in teams.

IE 402.name: Production System Planning and Control
IE 402.description: Theory and application of forecasting systems, including regression and time series models. Independent demand inventory models, including development of safety stock. All modules of Manufacturing Resource Planning (MRP) Systems. Master production scheduling, resource requirements planning, bill of material and inventory file structures, material requirements planning, capacity planning, shop floor and purchase order control. Overview of just-in-time inventory concepts and MRP's role in manufacturing automation.

IE 404.name: Industrial Engineering Design I
IE 404.description: Current real-world problems will be drawn from local production and service organizations and presented by personnel from these organizations. Senior industrial engineering student teams will solve these real-world problems under the guidance of their instructor using industrial engineering methodology. These problems emphasize problem definitions, analysis, and presentation with considerations for engineering standards and realistic economic, environmental, ethical, safety, social, political, and other pertinent constraints.

IE 405.name: Engineering Economic Analysis
IE 405.description: Role of engineering economy in engineering practice; principles of economic equivalence; time value of money and discounted cash-flow techniques; analysis of single and multiple investments; comparison of alternatives; capital recovery and tax implications; inflation; public sector analysis; cost estimation; depreciation schedules; break-even point concepts; decision making under uncertainty; risk analysis; introduction to investing in the financial market; basic accounting principles and financial statements including balance sheets, income statements, cost of goods sold statements, and business ratios.

IE 406.name: Simulation
IE 406.description: Simulation of complex business and industry processes using current simulation software (e.g., Arena) where management, strategic and operational decision making can be enhanced through modeling and analysis. Introduction to modeling concepts, flowcharting, random number generation, design of experiments, simulation logic, computer animation, and optimization. Utilization of statistical tools to analyze inputs and outputs to simulation models. Provides hands-on experiences in developing simulation models for relevant manufacturing and service industry case studies.

IE 407.name: Honors: Facilities Planning and Material Handling
IE 407.description: Students will attend IE 401 classes with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.

IE 408.name: Honors: Simulation
IE 408.description: Students will attend IE 406 classes, with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.

IE 421.name: Information Systems Analysis and Design
IE 421.description: Systems engineering approach to analysis and design of systems of information. Topics ― system development life cycle, system analysis methodologies, data analysis techniques, system design, joint application design, and rapid application design. Lab introduces analysis and design software tools.

IE 422.name: Industrial Engineering Design II
IE 422.description: Current real-world problems will be drawn from local production and service organizations and presented by personnel from these organizations. Senior industrial engineering student teams will solve these real-world problems under the guidance of their instructor using industrial engineering methodology. These problems emphasize problem definitions, analysis, and presentation with considerations for engineering standards and realistic economic, environmental, ethical, safety, social, political, and other pertinent constraints.

IE 423.name: Industrial Safety
IE 423.description: Accident causation, losses, and investigative techniques. Role of human, task/machine, and environment in accident prevention. Safety standards, codes, and laws. Product liability, design, evaluation, and management of safety organizations and programs. Hazard recognition, analysis, control and risk assessment, systems safety and related techniques.

IE 427.name: Introduction to Lean Systems
IE 427.description: Introduces an engineering based framework to implement process and system improvements within both the manufacturing and service enterprises. The students will be introduced to the basic concepts of lean systems including facility design and six sigma. The focus of the course will be to enable students to design complex processes and systems based on the physical system and the associated information system. Activities will include case studies, industry based projects, and the preparation of engineering reports.

IE 428.name: Honors: Information Systems Analysis and Design
IE 428.description: Students will attend IE 421 classes with supplementary assignments and/or class meetings.

IE 430.name: Supply Chain Engineering
IE 430.description: An overview of supply chain engineering with topics including: building a strategic framework to analyze supply chains, designing the supply chain network, planning demand and supply, planning and managing inventories, sourcing, transporting, and pricing products, and coordination and technology in the supply chain.

IE 450.name: Leadership Project in Industrial Engineering
IE 450.description: Students complete a self-directed leadership project. Technical report writing and/or presentation is required. The credit earned from this course may be used as approved technical elective credit in the Industrial Engineering degree program (consult departmental academic advisor for details).

IE 451.name: Creative Technical Problem Solving
IE 451.description: This course introduces creative technical thinking principles for problem solving to address larger challenges that create value for organizations and society. Thinking methods covered include ideality, functional analysis, nine windows of a system, migration to the system, 5 whys, cause and effect chains, separation principles, technical contradictions and S-curve analysis.

IE 452.name: Project Planning and Organizational Management
IE 452.description: Aspects of leadership in a professional environment will be studied from current literature reading and discussions. Industry professionals will periodically lead the class to enlighten students to aspects of organizational and project management. Lectures will be based on the Project Management Body of knowledge (PMBOK) and will qualify students to take the CAPM/PMP certification exam at the end of their Senior year. Each student will develop a project plan including Project Charter, scope management, Communication plan, with an oral project review presentation.

IE 465.name: Applied Data Science
IE 465.description: An introduction to applied data science including machine learning and data mining tools. Topics include supervised and unsupervised algorithms, techniques for improving model performance, evaluation techniques and software packages for implementation. Emphasis will be put on real-world applications in various domains including healthcare, transportation systems, etc.

IE 483.name: Introduction to Reliability Engineering
IE 483.description: Probabilistic failure models and parameter estimation (maximum likelihood, Bayes techniques). Model identification and comparison, accelerated life tests, failure prediction, system reliability, preventive maintenance, and warranties.

IE 484.name: Introduction to Maintainability Engineering
IE 484.description: Principles of maintenance and reliability engineering and maintenance management. Topics include information extraction from machinery measurements, rotating machinery diagnostics, nondestructive testing, life prediction, failure models, lubrication oil analysis, establishing a predictive maintenance program, and computerized maintenance management systems.

IE 493.name: Special Topics
IE 493.description: Recent developments in industrial engineering including new areas of application, new research techniques, and new methodologies.

IE 494.name: Special Topics
IE 494.description: Recent developments in industrial engineering, including new areas of application, new research techniques, and new methodologies.

IE 495.name: Special Topics
IE 495.description: Recent developments in industrial engineering including new areas of application, new research techniques and new methodologies.

INDS 211.name: History of Industrial Design
INDS 211.description: Industrial design, product design, furniture, within a social and cultural context in a global perspective, 20th and 21st centuries.

INDS 321.name: Digital Representation and Fabrication for Industrial Design
INDS 321.description: Exploration of basic computer-aided design programs in the representation of three dimensions. The use of digital fabrication machines such as 3D printer, and CNC computer numerical control mill.

INDS 371.name: Ideation Graphics Studio
INDS 371.description: Ideation drawing and methodology. Concentration on rapid freehand drawing related to process and development of product design.

INDS 372.name: Industrial Design Studio
INDS 372.description: Introduction to conceptual steps and prototyping skills in product design evolution, process, drawing and model making.

INMT 242.name: Business Software Applications
INMT 242.description: Instruction on the use of popular spreadsheet, database, and analytical software including how and when to apply the features of these types of applications to address a variety of business problems. Content emphasizes leveraging widely used business tools via hands-on activities.

INMT 341.name: Business Process Analysis
INMT 341.description: Topics include strategic uses of information technology in business processes, analysis of business processes (including transaction processing cycles), analysis of business process risk exposures and controls, and conceptual modeling and the development of information systems.

INMT 342.name: Introduction to Database Systems
INMT 342.description: This 'hands on', project-based course, involves the use of several technology tools to build and deploy database solutions. Topics include fundamentals of database technology, database design, database use, database system controls, and database implementation. Focus is on developing the technical and business skills necessary to successfully gather information and improve business processes in technology-driven environments. Students work with modern database management systems software and develop database project management skills.

INMT 441.name: Introduction to Cybersecurity in Business
INMT 441.description: Introduction to the theories, technologies, and procedures underlying the protection of information assets. Students work with a variety of tools to enhance their knowledge and technology skills. This course also includes study of key business issues related to designing and implementing cybersecurity.

INMT 442.name: e-Enterprise
INMT 442.description: This 'hands on', project-based course introduces students to key information management trends and challenges related to established and emerging technologies, and overviews key business applications and algorithms that support the flow of data in businesses, with a focus on Internet enabled business processes that connect buyers, suppliers, and trading partners in dynamic, real-time information sharing partnership. Students work with a variety of tools to enhance their knowledge and technology skills.

INMT 443.name: Business Applications and Tools
INMT 443.description: This 'hands-on', projects-based course introduces students to business application logic and object programming. Topics include fundamentals of business application logic, business application architectures, and project management. Students use application development tools and programming languages/scripts to write algorithms (including linking apps to databases and other file types).

INMT 499.name: Special Topics in Information Management
INMT 499.description: This course introduces and addresses the challenges related to managing new emerging and disruptive information technologies that are impacting business environments.

INPG 200.name: Introductory Interdisciplinary Topics
INPG 200.description: Selected topics related to the Interdisciplinary Programs in the College of Arts and Sciences. Acceptable for major or minor credit in any Interdisciplinary Program with the consent of the Director of Interdisciplinary Programs and the respective chairperson.

INPG 210.name: Introduction to Health Care Delivery
INPG 210.description: Health care professionals address topics selected to expose pre-health students to various specialty areas and issues in health care. Topics include ethics in health care delivery, professional school opportunities, and the admissions application process. The class meets at UT Medical Center.

INPG 220.name: Introduction to Law and the Legal Profession
INPG 220.description: Introduction to the practice of law, to areas of law taught in the first year of law school, and to legal method and authorities. Topics may include the legal profession, legal history, legal institutions, civil and common law systems, civil procedure, criminal law and procedure, torts, contracts, and property law.

INPG 353.name: VolsTeach: Perspectives on Math and Science
INPG 353.description: Provides an exploration of the development of ideas in mathematics and science throughout history. Emphasis on critical thinking and writing skills, lesson planning, and exploration of mathematical and science concepts.

INPG 385.name: VolsTeach: Research Methods in Science
INPG 385.description: Inquiry-based teaching methods in science. Students perform independent inquiries and learn to combine skills from mathematics and science to solve research problems. A component of the VolsTeach curriculum. By petition, may be applied towards the B.S. in Biological Sciences (BCMB, EEB, and Microbiology concentrations).

INPG 400.name: Advanced Interdisciplinary Topics
INPG 400.description: Selected topics related to the Interdisciplinary Programs in the College of Arts and Sciences. Acceptable for major or minor credit in any Interdisciplinary Program with the consent of the Director of Interdisciplinary Programs and the respective chairperson.

INPG 412.name: Arts and Sciences Ambassador Training
INPG 412.description: Instruction in the nature and value of a liberal arts education; practice in recruitment strategies; introduction to faculty and staff who represent the college and affiliated programs (ONSF, Center for Leadership and Service, etc.); support initiatives for the college.

INPG 497.name: Honors Thesis
INPG 497.description: Individual work by an advanced undergraduate student, culminating in the production of a written thesis. The thesis must be approved by a faculty mentor. Acceptable for major or minor credit in any interdisciplinary program with the consent of the Director of Interdisciplinary Programs and the respective chairperson.

INPG 499.name: Senior Portfolio
INPG 499.description: Students create a comprehensive, annotated portfolio of work completed for their major. It is expected that students will take this course during the semester that they graduate.

INSC 102.name: Introduction to Computers
INSC 102.description: Information and communication technology (ICT) for personal and professional use. History of computing and essential terminology. Common information systems, networks and applications.

INSC 201.name: Foundations of Information Sciences
INSC 201.description: History and core concepts of information representation, organization and retrieval. Human information behavior. Information production, consumption and use, information literacy and information policy.

INSC 210.name: Foundations of Information Technology
INSC 210.description: Principles, selection and use of computer-based information management applications. Application software, the Internet and web technologies. Systems development methods. Management of information systems. Network security, information security and information assurance.

INSC 220.name: Information Search
INSC 220.description: Planning and conducting information searches. Evaluating information sources.

INSC 295.name: Special Topics in Information Sciences
INSC 295.description: Study of a specialized area of information sciences or information technology. Topics vary by semester.

INSC 305.name: Internet and Society
INSC 305.description: Social study of the Internet, including historical development, Internet technologies and use. Internet ethics and governance. Contemporary issues concerning equitable access, privacy, security, intellectual property and censorship.

INSC 311.name: User-Centered Design
INSC 311.description: Application of user research theories and techniques for placing user needs across all design process stages. Conducting user research, gathering requirements and planning and developing intuitive, user-friendly products.

INSC 360.name: Programming for Information Applications
INSC 360.description: Programming languages with emphasis on data structures, in-built functions, user-defined variables, syntax and control structures for processing and visualizing datasets.

INSC 380.name: Information Management in Organizations
INSC 380.description: Theories and practices related to the processes, technologies, people, decisions and policies for managing information.

INSC 384.name: Database Design
INSC 384.description: Procedures and techniques in database design and development. Conceptual data modeling. Logical database design. Physical database design process. Structured Query Language (SQL).

INSC 395.name: Special Topics in Information Sciences
INSC 395.description: Study of a specialized area of information sciences or information technology. Topics vary by semester.

INSC 430.name: Foundations of User Experience
INSC 430.description: Concepts, principles and theories of user experience (UX). User research. UX lifecycle. Contextual and inclusive design.

INSC 435.name: Usability Testing and Methods
INSC 435.description: Processes and methods of testing information services and systems. Developing assessment reports for websites, mobile content and other information products.

INSC 436.name: Analytics and Metrics for User Experience
INSC 436.description: Concepts in analytics and metrics. Identifying, selecting and applying appropriate tools. Analyzing and interpreting data to improve services and systems.

INSC 439.name: Interfaces and Interaction Design
INSC 439.description: Human computer interaction and system design. Interface evaluations and prototype development for improved interfaces.

INSC 484.name: Database Applications
INSC 484.description: Applying database models to develop applications using a database management system. Developing prototype client/server applications. Advanced Structured Query Language (SQL).

INSC 486.name: Data Analytics
INSC 486.description: Concepts, techniques, and tools of data analytics. Collecting, extracting and transforming data. Mining data to discover hidden patterns and knowledge. Investigating application of data analytics in various information environments.

INSC 489.name: Information Visualization
INSC 489.description: Visual, intuitive and interactive representation of information. Fundamental understanding of human perceptual and cognitive capabilities, computer graphics, user interface and creativity. Designs and techniques for visualizing various types of data.

INSC 493.name: Independent Project or Research
INSC 493.description: Selected readings or independent research in an area of information sciences to be determined by the student in consultation with supervising faculty member and, ordinarily, in an area of study not covered by school curriculum.

INSC 495.name: Special Topics
INSC 495.description: Study of a specialized area of information sciences or information technology. Topics vary by semester.

INSC 499.name: Professional Experience
INSC 499.description: Translate knowledge into practice through a practicum, internship or other supervised work experience at a departmentally approved employer. May take place off or on campus.

INTE 150.name: International Education Experiences
INTE 150.description: Development of international and intercultural competencies through preparation for and completion of international educational experiences.

INTE 250.name: Special Topics in International Education
INTE 250.description: Critical exploration of international and intercultural issues in a disciplinary or interdisciplinary context through experiential forms of inquiry such as research, service-learning and internship.

IT 410.name: Getting into Online Learning
IT 410.description: This course prepares participants with interests in designing online learning environments for effective communication. These environments may be situated in a wide range of settings including business/industry, government, not for profits, schools, and higher education to name just a few. We focus on four core competencies: online social interactions, personalization, learner dispositions, and online assessment. We address issues of instructional design, accessibility, and universal design for learning (UDL). At the end of the course, learners will have the skills to design effective online learning environments. This course provides learners with experiences in developing online learning, and in the process, the tools necessary to become excellent and engaged online learners. At the end, learners will increase their ability to take coursework online, and will recognize engaging and efficient online instruction.

ITAL 111.name: Elementary Italian
ITAL 111.description: Introduction to Italian. Language laboratory required.

ITAL 112.name: Elementary Italian
ITAL 112.description: Introduction to Italian. Language laboratory required.

ITAL 146.name: Introduction to Basic Italian Pronunciation
ITAL 146.description: Online course in Italian pronunciation. Students improve their Italian pronunciation by understanding phonetic sounds and learning correct use of facial muscles to master their pronunciation skills. It will also help students increase their Italian vocabulary. Students who have an academic and professional connection to Italian are encouraged to attend, as the course will particularly look at the pronunciation of words in the fields of architecture, art, business, culinary arts, film, language arts, literature, music, theatre and travel.

ITAL 211.name: Intermediate Italian
ITAL 211.description: Sequence stresses reading, writing, listening, and speaking Italian to prepare for upper-division courses in the language. Language laboratory required.

ITAL 212.name: Intermediate Italian
ITAL 212.description: Sequence stresses reading, writing, listening, and speaking Italian to prepare for upper-division courses in the language. Language laboratory required.

ITAL 223.name: Intensive Intermediate Italian
ITAL 223.description: Stresses reading, writing, listening, and speaking of Italian to prepare for upper-division courses in the language.

ITAL 310.name: Special Topics in Literature and Culture
ITAL 310.description: Analysis of different periods of Italian literary and cultural production.

ITAL 314.name: Highlights of Italian Civilization, Culture, and Identity
ITAL 314.description: Examination of past and present Italian culture and identity as shaped by its political, religious, artistic, literary, and historical contexts. Taught in English.

ITAL 315.name: Special topics in Italian History, Literature, and Culture
ITAL 315.description: Focuses on significant events from the 15th- to the 21st- century Italian history, literature, and culture. Topics range from wars, emigration, crime, economic booms, financial crises, socio-political changes, music, and media studies. Taught in Italian.

ITAL 341.name: Intermediate Grammar, Composition and Conversation
ITAL 341.description: Grammatical analysis of Italian prose. Review of grammatical principles and their application in translation from English to Italian, both written and oral. Exercises in free composition.

ITAL 342.name: Intermediate Grammar, Composition and Conversation
ITAL 342.description: Grammatical analysis of Italian prose. Review of grammatical principles and their application in translation from English to Italian, both written and oral. Exercises in free composition.

ITAL 400.name: The Italian Renaissance through Popular Culture
ITAL 400.description: The course offers students the opportunity to view important cultural, social, and gender issues of the Italian Renaissance through the lenses of popular culture. Students will be required to read original texts and critical essays in light of relevant contemporary media (TV series, films, on-line resources).

ITAL 401.name: Dante and Medieval Culture
ITAL 401.description: Dante's times and the Divine Comedy.

ITAL 402.name: Petrarch and Boccaccio
ITAL 402.description: A cultural and literary survey from Petrarch to Machiavelli.

ITAL 405.name: Topics in Italian Culture, History, and Literature
ITAL 405.description: Comprehensive view and critical analysis of themes related to Italian culture. Taught in Italian. Topics vary by semester.

ITAL 406.name: Italian History through Art
ITAL 406.description: Surveys the history of Italian art from the Middle Ages to the 20th century, with emphasis on the social reasons that promoted it, and on the impact it had on Italian culture.

ITAL 411.name: Aspects of Modern Literature and Culture
ITAL 411.description: Representative works of Italian modern literature and culture. Taught in Italian.

ITAL 412.name: Advanced Literary Reading and Conversation
ITAL 412.description: A cultural and literary survey of contemporary Italian poetry and short stories. Taught in Italian.

ITAL 414.name: Italian Cultural Studies
ITAL 414.description: This course will examine Italian culture as a set of practices characteristic of Italian society, from its mode of material production to its eating habits, dress codes, celebrations, and rituals. The objective of the course is to achieve a greater understanding of contemporary Italian culture.

ITAL 415.name: History of Italian Theatre and Performance
ITAL 415.description: Explores major elements of Italian theatre from the 16th to the 20th century. Taught in Italian. Open to majors and minors.

ITAL 422.name: Topics in Italian Cinema
ITAL 422.description: Examination of Italian cinema from 1930 to the present focusing on feature films, documentaries and, depending on the topic of the course, on literary works in light of political, cultural, and social contexts. Films are shown in Italian with English subtitles.

ITAL 423.name: Language and Culture for the Italian Business World
ITAL 423.description: This course prepares students to experience and actively engage in the dynamic world of business in Italy. It fosters cultural competency, teaches practical communications skills, and cultivates the linguistic expertise necessary for making connections in one of the world's most important economies.

ITAL 442.name: Special Topics in Italian Culture
ITAL 442.description: Selected topics in Italian culture from the early Middle Ages to the present. Taught in English.

ITAL 490.name: Internship
ITAL 490.description: Career-related experiences in the United States or abroad.

ITAL 490N.name: Internship
ITAL 490N.description: Career-related experiences in the United States or abroad.

JAPA 313.name: Japanese Literature in English Translation
JAPA 313.description: Classical/traditional – masterpieces of poetry, fiction, and drama to 1868.

JAPA 314.name: Food, Fiction, and Film in Modern Japan
JAPA 314.description: Modern – literary and visual narratives through the lens of culinary and cultural history. Taught in English.

JAPA 315.name: Asian Film
JAPA 315.description: An examination of Asian national cinemas in historical and cultural context. Taught in English.

JAPA 321.name: Japanese Graphic Novel/Anime
JAPA 321.description: Reading and analysis of major contemporary Japanese graphic novels with special attention to related works of film and television animation. All readings are in English translation.

JAPA 351.name: Advanced Japanese I
JAPA 351.description: Includes conversation, drill, and composition practice with native speaker, as well as reading and translation.

JAPA 352.name: Advanced Japanese II
JAPA 352.description: Includes conversation, drill, and composition practice with native speaker, as well as reading and translation.

JAPA 365.name: Japanese for Business
JAPA 365.description: Japanese social management culture, and the global significance of economic and political developments in Japan. Commercial vocabulary, marketing, management, and other principles and business practices.

JAPA 413.name: Topics in Japanese Literature
JAPA 413.description: In English with readings in Japanese for minors.

JAPA 490.name: Japanese Internship
JAPA 490.description: Career-related experiences in the United States or abroad.

JAPA 493.name: Independent Study
JAPA 493.description: Exploration of academic interests in Japanese studies not available in regularly offered courses.

JAPA 490N.name: Japanese Internship
JAPA 490N.description: Career-related experiences in the United States or abroad.

JREM 175.name: Introduction to Journalism and Creative Media
JREM 175.description: Overview of all media platforms within their historical context. Students are introduced to theories and research in media and society. Students learn about the broad scope of journalism and creative media and will also gain experience with on-campus media.

JREM 200.name: Multimedia Writing
JREM 200.description: Students will be introduced to basic storytelling structures and approaches across media platforms. The writing intensive course also emphasizes instruction in grammar, structure, AP style, and media practices.

JREM 220.name: Scriptwriting for Creative Works
JREM 220.description: Introduction to creative scriptwriting for broadcast/cable television productions or streaming series. Includes copywriting for commercials. Scripts are expected to be pitch-ready by the end of the semester.

JREM 230.name: Multimedia Reporting
JREM 230.description: Students will cover a variety of news topics and events and will report on these stories across media platforms. The course introduces students to general assignment, enterprise, and beat reporting using principles of journalistic ethics. A combination of photography, video, sound, and graphics will be used for in-depth storytelling.

JREM 260.name: Studio Production
JREM 260.description: Introduction to studio production. Effective studio lighting, studio camera operations, video switching, and audio controls will be taught in addition to the roles of producing, directing, and floor managing.

JREM 320.name: Media Marketing and Promotions
JREM 320.description: This course provides students with practical skills for media marketing, promotions, and copywriting, and it stresses imagination, creativity, and writing skills. Students start out learning about what attracts consumers to particular media and content. Students learn strategies for reaching target viewers and listeners based on audience ratings and shares, demographics, and affinity to programs.

JREM 330.name: Communication for Media
JREM 330.description: In the media saturated world of today, engineers, scientists, social workers and people from various other fields are regularly asked to participate in media interviews about their work. This course will prepare students - not familiar with journalism processes and norms - to effectively and ethically communicate via media. Among the topics covered will be how to present research and other information to journalists, serve constructively as an interview subject, and create informational content for personal websites and blogs.

JREM 331.name: Digital Content Creation
JREM 331.description: Introduces students from varied disciplines to the basics of effective writing and content production across media platforms. Audience analytics is also introduced to give students the tools needed to understand their target audiences and how to effectively reach those audiences through digital content. Conceptual topics include professionalism and ethics.

JREM 333.name: Media Editing
JREM 333.description: Methods and practice in editing across media platforms with emphasis on the role of editors, content planning and digital curation; story development and organization; display of text and visual content; news verification; headlines and SEO; and proper language use.

JREM 336.name: Video Production
