SOCI 361.description: This course provides an environmental justice framework for understanding how racialized discrimination, gender, sexual orientation, income, and national origin are intrinsically connected to environmental degradation, climate change, and the failure to create a just and sustainable future for all of earth's inhabitants.

SOCI 362.name: Population
SOCI 362.description: Demographic factors and social structure. Trends in fertility, mortality, population growth, migration, distribution, and composition. Population policy.

SOCI 363.name: Food, Agriculture, and Society
SOCI 363.description: Social and environmental dimensions of production, distribution, and consumption of food, with particular emphasis on historical and cross-national examples.

SOCI 375.name: Gender in Society
SOCI 375.description: Exploration of gender in society utilizing various sociological perspectives with special focus on the relationships between social structures, social roles, and gender identities.

SOCI 400.name: Special Topics
SOCI 400.description: Variable topics. Scope of subject matter determined by students and instructor with consent of department.

SOCI 401.name: Special Topics in Criminology
SOCI 401.description: Variable topics in criminology. Scope of subject matter determined by students and instructor with consent of department.

SOCI 410.name: Sociology of Culture
SOCI 410.description: Examination of the role of culture in human social life from various theoretical perspectives. Exploration of social foundations of differentiation based on lifestyle and taste.

SOCI 411.name: Police and Society
SOCI 411.description: This course explores the role and function of police in society, including an emphasis on history, politics, economy, and culture. Special emphasis is placed on the relation between police power and the making of race, class, and gender dynamics and inequalities.

SOCI 415.name: Visual Criminology
SOCI 415.description: This course explores 1) the power and spectacle of crime and punishment and how its representation shapes our popular knowledge of and policy in criminal justice; 2) the key dimensions of visual criminology, its key theories, tools, and methods; and 3) the usefulness of digital research and advocacy skills for careers in media and social justice.

SOCI 419.name: Sociology and Science Fiction
SOCI 419.description: Examines how science fiction relates to social problems and issues. Will examine film and texts through the lenses of social theory.

SOCI 431.name: Applied Sociological Research
SOCI 431.description: Survey of advanced topics in sociological research, and hands-on application of research methods.

SOCI 433.name: Participatory Action Research
SOCI 433.description: Participatory Action Research (PAR) is a collaborative approach to research that brings together researchers and community members to identify, analyze, and act upon community challenges. In this course students will learn about the origins, processes, and epistemological underpinnings of PAR as we work with local community partners to carry out a community-based research project.

SOCI 442.name: Comparative Poverty and Development
SOCI 442.description: Critical examination of patterns of poverty and inequality in developing areas of the world, and review of major theories of development.

SOCI 446.name: The Modern World System
SOCI 446.description: Critical examination of the capitalist world-system as a social system, its coherence, boundaries, regions, member groups, cleavages, and patterns of conflict. Analysis of who gets what, why, and how in the global political economy.

SOCI 449.name: Youth Justice
SOCI 449.description: This course examines the historical and contemporary nature and social contexts of juvenile delinquency, as well as theoretical explanations of and social reactions to delinquency in American society.

SOCI 452.name: Race, Ethnicity, Crime, and Justice
SOCI 452.description: Examines racial/ethnic disparities in criminal offending and victimization, as well as different experiences with law enforcement, judicial, and correctional agencies. Emphasis on social justice.

SOCI 453.name: Gender and Crime
SOCI 453.description: Probes the gendered nature of offending, victimization, and criminal justice. Examines the different experiences of males and females, and theories that attempt to explain these differences.

SOCI 454.name: Restorative Justice
SOCI 454.description: Explores the restorative justice perspective on crime, harm and conflict and its global practices, which recognize reparation, reconciliation, and social justice.

SOCI 455.name: Law and Society
SOCI 455.description: How laws and legal processes are affected by social change, the social impact of legal sanctions, and relations between law and social justice.

SOCI 456.name: Punishment and Society
SOCI 456.description: Examines theories and practices of punishment, including imprisonment, capital punishment, transnational penal trends, and social policy alternatives.

SOCI 457.name: Honors Thesis in Sociology
SOCI 457.description: Independent study for developing and writing the honors thesis in sociology.

SOCI 460.name: Capitalism and Racism
SOCI 460.description: Explores the emergence of race and racism with capitalism through an examination of capitalist geographies, institutions, racialized labor dynamics, and in resistance to various forms of domination. Course themes may include racial slavery, divisions of labor, immigration, urban development and gentrification, financialization, privatization, globalization, intersectionality, and resistance movements.

SOCI 461.name: Immigration Politics and Policies
SOCI 461.description: Examines US immigration history, politics, and policies in sociological context, with particular attention to how social, political, and economic factors have shaped our national understanding of immigrants and immigrant rights, and how immigrants and advocates organize around policies.

SOCI 463.name: Community, Sustainability and Justice
SOCI 463.description: Examines social, economic and ecological factors that impact the health and well-being of communities and the bridges and barriers for realizing sustainable, healthy and just communities in the future.

SOCI 464.name: Political Economy of Natural Resources and the Environment
SOCI 464.description: Examines social structural and environmental aspects of power, poverty and inequality across multiple scales of analysis in relation to patterns of resource extraction, production and consumption, environmental degradation, climate change and globalization.

SOCI 465.name: Social Values and the Environment
SOCI 465.description: Human dimensions of ecosystem management and public policy. An applied focus on how social values are activated within specific biophysical and social settings.

SOCI 466.name: Special Topics in Race and Ethnicity
SOCI 466.description: Rotating topics on specific race and ethnicity areas. May include topics such as environmental racism, policing and race, race, terror and genocide, intersectionality, health disparities, immigration and ethnic change, and advanced Critical Race Theory.

SOCI 472.name: Civil Rights Movement
SOCI 472.description: Origins and development of the civil rights movement throughout the 20th century, with special emphasis on civil rights litigation of the 1930s-1950s and key events of the years 1954-1965.

SOCI 480.name: Capstone in Sociology
SOCI 480.description: Reflection on and assessment of sociology major, including theory, methods, experiential learning, and knowledge application; participation in department colloquia and/or lecture series; consideration of career and graduate/professional school opportunities.

SOCI 495.name: Social Justice and Community Service
SOCI 495.description: Examines social stratification, inequalities, and social justice. Service learning component offers supervised internships in the community with service agencies and non-profit organizations.

SOCI 497.name: Honors: Independent Study
SOCI 497.description: Advanced independent study within the sociology honors concentration. Students may do readings, research, analysis, writing and presentations related to their areas of interest.

SOCI 431R.name: Applied Sociological Research
SOCI 431R.description: Survey of advanced topics in sociological research, and hands-on application of research methods.

SOCI 433R.name: Participatory Action Research
SOCI 433R.description: Participatory Action Research (PAR) is a collaborative approach to research that brings together researchers and community members to identify, analyze, and act upon community challenges. In this course students will learn about the origins, processes, and epistemological underpinnings of PAR as we work with local community partners to carry out a community-based research project.

SOCI 492N.name: Social Justice and Community Service – Internship
SOCI 492N.description: The course provides junior and senior sociology majors with the opportunity to receive credit for an extended off-campus internship doing work related to their field of study or professional goals. According to the National Association of Colleges and Employers (NACE), an internship "is a form of experiential learning that integrates knowledge and theory learned in the classroom with practical application and skills development in a professional setting. Internships give students the opportunity to gain valuable applied experience and make connections in professional fields they are considering for career paths; and give employers the opportunity to guide and evaluate talent." Through participation in class discussions, course assignments, and the internship, students will apply knowledge and skills learned in previous coursework to real-world issues; develop a professional practice consistent with their sociological imagination; and gain structured exposure to a meaningful work experience.

SOWK 200.name: Introduction to Social Work and Social Justice
SOWK 200.description: This course introduces students to the profession of social work. This course is intended to facilitate prospective social workers' understanding of the vast breadth of professional practice while providing students with comprehensive knowledge of the profession's historical evolution, scope of service, consumers of service, rewards, challenges, and commitment to social justice. Additional topics covered in this course include professional skills, values, ethics, practice settings, career patterns, and practice methods.

SOWK 250.name: Introduction to Social Welfare
SOWK 250.description: This course assists prospective social workers by providing a holistic understanding of the social work profession and its contribution to social welfare. This course examines the development of social welfare policies, programs, and areas of service provision within domestic and international contexts. Students taking this course will study the construct of social welfare as it relates to social justice and wellbeing.

SOWK 312.name: Introduction to Interpersonal Social Work Practice
SOWK 312.description: This course introduces social work students to professional interpersonal practice specific to individuals, families, and small groups. This course integrates the social work code of ethics, theoretical models, and practice techniques with an emphasis on social justice, trauma-informed care, and interprofessional practice. The course assists students with identifying appropriate evidence-based service interventions with consideration to intersecting identities, professional standards, and ethical code.

SOWK 313.name: Interpersonal Social Work Skills Lab
SOWK 313.description: This experiential course will apply the essential skills of social work practice to simulated learning activities. Students taking this course will have the opportunity to model various service provision techniques related to empathy, engagement, assessment, intervention, evaluation, and termination. Students will understand the appropriate use of self in professional practice, and learn strategies to promote self-care. Skills are reinforced through multiple service frameworks integrating trauma-informed care, interprofessional practice, and social justice.

SOWK 314.name: Human Development in Context: Pre-Natal through Adolescence
SOWK 314.description: This course examines biological, psychological, and social theories and frameworks for practice with individuals and families. This course emphasizes the interaction between neurophysiological development and environmental contexts. Students explore topics such as risk and protective factors that influence and shape development while promoting resilience, and the influence of culture, oppressive systems, and dynamic processes critical to risk and resilience for vulnerable populations. Additionally, students examine practice implications for promoting healthy development including early prevention policies, practices, and services.

SOWK 315.name: Introduction to Macro Social Work Practice
SOWK 315.description: This course addresses systems-level macro practice specific to communities, organizations, and professional leadership. Strategies, methods, and skills applicable to a wide range of macro practice settings are examined. Students taking this course will explore issues surrounding inequity, exclusion, and oppression while learning effective strategies to promote social justice and systemic change.

SOWK 316.name: Social Justice and Anti-oppressive Practices
SOWK 316.description: This course is designed to increase students' awareness of the dimensions of human diversity, equity, and inclusion. Students will learn to articulate and apply multicultural and social justice practice frameworks, critical theories, and a human rights perspective to address complex social problems. Students will be prepared to integrate these concepts into future ethical decision-making and practice with historically excluded and underserved populations.

SOWK 317.name: Honors: Human Behavior in the Social Environment
SOWK 317.description: Honors version of SOWK 314. Course is enriched for high-achieving students.

SOWK 318.name: Honors: Social Justice and Anti-oppressive Practices
SOWK 318.description: This honors course is designed to increase students' awareness of the dimensions of human diversity, equity, and inclusion. Students will learn to articulate and apply multicultural and social justice practice frameworks, critical theories, and a human rights perspective to address complex social problems with special consideration to the impact of discrimination, oppression, and historical trauma on client outcomes. Students will be prepared to integrate these concepts into cultural and ethically-sound social work practice with at-risk and underserved populations.

SOWK 323.name: Case Management with Military Personnel and Veterans
SOWK 323.description: Study of social work practice with military veterans. Specific focus on case management with veterans and military personnel involved with the United States Department of Veterans Affairs.

SOWK 324.name: Human Development in Context: Young Adulthood through Older Adulthood
SOWK 324.description: This course examines biological, psychological, and social theories and frameworks for practice with individuals and families. This course emphasizes the interaction between neurophysiological development and environmental contexts. Students explore topics such as risk and protective factors that influence and shape development while promoting resilience, and the influence of culture, oppressive systems, and dynamic processes critical to risk and resilience for vulnerable populations. Additionally, students examine practice implications for working with adults including family and social relationships, behavioral health challenges, chronic illness, and death and dying.

SOWK 325.name: Professional Ethics
SOWK 325.description: Explores professional ethics for entry level generalist practice.

SOWK 335.name: Adverse Childhood Experiences and Trauma-Informed Care
SOWK 335.description: Examines Adverse Childhood Experiences (ACEs) and the potentially detrimental effects that these traumatic events, including maltreatment, neglect, and witnessed violence, can have on the development of children. This course will also examine the effects of traumatic events on the adult population in the context of various types of traumatic events.

SOWK 345.name: Crisis Intervention and Suicidology
SOWK 345.description: Provides the knowledge, values, and skills for entry level generalist practice in a crisis intervention setting.

SOWK 380.name: Field Practicum I
SOWK 380.description: Supervised field experience with practice situations for developing professional skills, values, and attitudes. Concurrent seminar focuses on integration of knowledge with practice experiences.

SOWK 385.name: Field Seminar
SOWK 385.description: The purpose of field seminar is to enhance the academic and supervisory support for social work practicum students.

SOWK 410.name: Foundations of Social Work Research
SOWK 410.description: This course is designed to help students understand and appreciate the role of research in evidence-based practice. Students are introduced to quantitative and qualitative concepts and skills underlying a systematic approach to social work research, including basic research terminology, scientific methods and the value of research in social work. Students will learn about historical and present-day inequities in research and how to apply social work values to engage in ethical research. Students taking this course engage in research techniques such as problem formulation, measurement, design, sampling, data gathering, and use of analytic software.

SOWK 416.name: Social Welfare Policy and Programs
SOWK 416.description: This course explores the policies and programs that shape the welfare system and influence social work practice. The course assesses organizational and legislative systems at the federal, state, local levels and their impact on social services. The course links social welfare policy and social work practice by critically analyzing the historic and contemporary contexts of social welfare practice. The processes of analyzing, influencing, developing, implementing, and advocating for policies and programs through the lens of social work values and ethics are addressed.

SOWK 418.name: Honors: Social Welfare Policy and Programs
SOWK 418.description: This honors course explores the policies that shape the welfare system and influence social work practice. The course will emphasize organizational and legislative systems at the federal, state, local levels and their impact on social services. The course links social welfare policy and social work practice by critically analyzing the historic and contemporary contexts of social welfare practice. The processes of analyzing, influencing, developing, implementing, and advocating for policies and programs through the lens of social work values and ethics are addressed. Students enrolled in this honors course engage in professional lobbying strategies within a simulated legislative environment.

SOWK 425.name: Mental Illness and Generalist Social Work Practice
SOWK 425.description: Examines the generalist social work role in working with individuals and families affected by mental illness.

SOWK 435.name: Forensic Social Work
SOWK 435.description: Provides an introduction to and overview of the field of forensic social work. Course content focuses on practice settings, generalist skills, ethics and trans-system interactions.

SOWK 440.name: General Topics in Social Work
SOWK 440.description: Current topics in theories and practice for social work practice.

SOWK 444.name: Critical Consciousness and Social Change: Social Justice Capstone
SOWK 444.description: Provides a capstone experience designed to assess the skills and knowledge achieved throughout the Social Justice minors interdisciplinary focus.

SOWK 445.name: Introduction to Substance Abuse in Social Work Practice
SOWK 445.description: Provides a generalist social work understanding of substance abuse related to etiology, epidemiology, neurophysiology, and behavioral consequences of specific drugs as well as explore screening, assessment and treatment/referral for substance abuse treatment.

SOWK 455.name: Human Sexuality
SOWK 455.description: Addresses core concepts and contemporary topics about human sexuality. Human sexuality is an integral part of being human and as such, social workers have the responsibility to be knowledgeable about sexuality to treat and provide resources for people in a holistic manner. Social workers can play a key role in helping people heal from sexual trauma, access necessary resources and provide education around healthy sexuality.

SOWK 460.name: Integrative Seminar
SOWK 460.description: This integrative seminar provides a platform for students to reflect and synthesize their awareness, knowledge, and skills across all BSSW program competencies through completion of the Senior Portfolio assignment.

SOWK 461.name: Child Welfare I: History, Programs, and Policies
SOWK 461.description: Study of the child welfare system examining history, policies, and programs, both state and federal, pertinent to child maltreatment and juvenile justice.

SOWK 462.name: Child Welfare II: Skills and Practice Methods
SOWK 462.description: Emphasis on the special challenges, needed skills, and different strategies and interventions in the provision of culturally responsive child welfare services.

SOWK 480.name: Field Practicum II
SOWK 480.description: Supervised agency field practicum for integration of theory and practice and critical examination of oneself as a professional helping person. Concurrent field seminar on integration of knowledge with practice experiences.

SOWK 481.name: Field Practicum III
SOWK 481.description: Supervised agency field practicum for integration of theory and practice and critical examination of oneself as a professional helping person. Concurrent field seminar on integration of knowledge with practice experiences.

SOWK 483.name: Block Field Practicum
SOWK 483.description: Social work field practicum for integration of theory and practice. Concurrent field seminar. Course is equivalent to SOWK 480N and/or SOWK 481N* and intended for students requiring alternate field practicum hours.

SOWK 484.name: Social Work Experience for International Students
SOWK 484.description: Exploration of local social welfare structures and services for international students. Opportunity to engage in non-clinical, community-based learning about social justice and human rights issues affecting professional social work.

SOWK 485.name: Field Seminar II
SOWK 485.description: The second seminar in a sequence of three. The purpose of field seminar is to enhance the academic and supervisory support for social work practicum students.

SOWK 495.name: Field Seminar III
SOWK 495.description: The final seminar in a sequence of three. The purpose of field seminar is to enhance the academic and supervisory support for social work practicum students.

SOWK 496.name: Block Field Seminar
SOWK 496.description: This course must be taken concurrently with SOWK 483N Block Field Practicum. The purpose of field seminar is to enhance the academic and supervisory support for social work practicum students.

SOWK 380N.name: Field Practicum I
SOWK 380N.description: Supervised field experience with practice situations for developing professional skills, values, and attitudes. Concurrent seminar focuses on integration of knowledge with practice experiences.

SOWK 417R.name: Honors: Foundations of Social Work Research
SOWK 417R.description: This honors course is designed to help students gain an understanding of and appreciation for the role of research in evidence-based practice. Students are introduced to methodological concepts and skills underlying a systematic approach to social work research, and the value of research in social work. Students learn about historical and present-day inequities in research and how to apply social work values to engage in ethical research. Students taking this course engage in problem formulation, measurement, design, sampling, data gathering, and use of analytic software. Students participate in each step of the scientific research process by designing and implementing an empirical study relevant to their practice interest.

SOWK 467R.name: Honors: Integrative Seminar
SOWK 467R.description: This integrative honors seminar provides a platform for students to reflect and synthesize their awareness, knowledge, and skills across all BSSW program competencies through completion of the Senior Portfolio assignment.  Students in this seminar further develop their professional competency through the evaluation and dissemination of an original research project.

SOWK 480N.name: Field Practicum II
SOWK 480N.description: Supervised agency field practicum for integration of theory and practice and critical examination of oneself as a professional helping person. Concurrent field seminar on integration of knowledge with practice experiences.

SOWK 481N.name: Field Practicum III
SOWK 481N.description: Supervised agency field practicum for integration of theory and practice and critical examination of oneself as a professional helping person. Concurrent field seminar on integration of knowledge with practice experiences.

SOWK 483N.name: Block Field Practicum
SOWK 483N.description: Social work field practicum for integration of theory and practice. Concurrent field seminar. Course is equivalent to SOWK 480N and/or SOWK 481N* and intended for students requiring alternate field practicum hours.

SPAN 150.name: Transition to Intermediate Spanish
SPAN 150.description: This course is designed to prepare students for enrollment in SPAN 211.

SPAN 217.name: Honors: Intermediate Spanish I
SPAN 217.description: Honors course for students of superior ability in Spanish. Students follow enriched program with continuing emphasis upon speaking ability and with an introduction to reading literary selections.

SPAN 218.name: Honors: Intermediate Spanish II
SPAN 218.description: Honors course for students of superior ability in Spanish. Students follow enriched program with continuing emphasis upon speaking ability and with an introduction to reading literary selections.

SPAN 309.name: Spanish for Bilinguals
SPAN 309.description: This course is designed for students who grew up speaking / hearing Spanish at home and wish to develop their academic skills in the language. In this course, students will engage in reading, writing and speaking practice in formal and academic contexts, including the study of relevant grammar topics.

SPAN 311.name: Language in Context I
SPAN 311.description: This course develops students' written and oral use of Spanish, through language study as well as exposure to authentic media (for example, movies, articles, stories).

SPAN 312.name: Language in Context II
SPAN 312.description: Building on knowledge gained in SPAN 311*, this course continues development of students' written and oral use of Spanish, through language study as well as exposure to authentic media (for example, movies, articles, stories).

SPAN 315.name: Spanish Phonetics and Phonology
SPAN 315.description: Introduction to the sound system of Spanish. Topics include: typical problems in pronunciation for native English speakers, transcription using relevant symbols of the International Phonetic Alphabet, various dialects of Spanish, and the physiological articulation and classification of Spanish sounds.

SPAN 330.name: Textual Analysis
SPAN 330.description: Introduction to the art of reading and interpreting literary texts and the writing of critical essays, with attention to language structures, literary terminology, theory and concepts such as romance, tragedy, comedy, irony, narrative voice, symbol, metaphor, etc. with application to works such as short stories, one-act plays, essays, and letters.

SPAN 331.name: Introduction to Hispanic Culture
SPAN 331.description: Introduction to the fundamental historical, political, and demographic developments that led to the creation, geographic distribution, and distinctive character of Hispanic cultures with attention to those qualities that distinguish Hispanic culture from other cultures, as well as to ethnic and linguistic components of the Hispanic world in the present day.

SPAN 332.name: Survey of Spanish Literature: 1700-Present
SPAN 332.description: Main writers, trends, stylistic periods, and artistic movements in Spain since 1700 set against a broad background of cultural, socio-political and historical developments. Emphasis on neo-classicism, the romantics, the realists of the 19th century, the Generation of '98, the avant-garde of the 1920s and 1930s, social realism, women writers, and contemporary developments.

SPAN 333.name: Survey of Spanish-American Literature: 1700-Present
SPAN 333.description: Main writers, trends, stylistic periods and artistic movements in Spanish America since 1700 set against a broad background of cultural, socio-political and historical developments. Emphasis on neo-classicism, the romantics, modernismo, the avant-garde of the 1920s and 1930s, social realism, magical realism, the Latin American boom, women writers, and contemporary developments.

SPAN 334.name: Survey of Hispanic Literatures: Beginnings-1700
SPAN 334.description: Main writers, trends, stylistic periods and artistic movements in Spain and Spanish America up to 1700 set against a broad background of cultural, socio-political and historical developments.

SPAN 346.name: Language and Culture of the Hispanic Business World
SPAN 346.description: Commercial vocabulary, business letters, import-export, marketing. Hispanic social management culture, and the global significance of economic and political developments in Spanish-speaking countries.

SPAN 401.name: Cultural Plurality and Institutional Changes in Latin America
SPAN 401.description: Value systems, behavioral patterns, political parties, role of the military, the church, educational institutions, dictatorship and nationalism.

SPAN 402.name: Latin American and Caribbean Studies Seminar
SPAN 402.description: Selected topics in Latin American and Caribbean Studies.

SPAN 410.name: Introduction to Hispanic Linguistics
SPAN 410.description: Topics may include first and second language acquisition, phonetics, phonology, syntax, history of the Spanish language, semantics, pragmatics and linguistic variation, among others.

SPAN 420.name: Applied Linguistics
SPAN 420.description: Introduction to applied linguistics, with a special emphasis on the theoretical and practical aspects of the teaching of Spanish as a foreign language. Fundamental concepts in linguistics within the context of Spanish grammar and their use in the study of second language acquisition, foreign language learning and foreign language teaching. Conducted in Spanish with readings in both English and Spanish.

SPAN 422.name: Advanced Grammar and Translation
SPAN 422.description: Structure of the grammatical system of Spanish. In-depth analysis of selected syntactic phenomena with practical illustration/application and exercise in Spanish-English and English-Spanish translation. Emphasis on finer points of grammatical structures.

SPAN 423.name: Advanced Composition and Conversation
SPAN 423.description: Develops writing and speaking skills to the advanced level, covering a wide range of topics and situations and including a variety of in-class and extra-class activities.

SPAN 430.name: Topics in Hispanic Linguistics
SPAN 430.description: Introduction to the study of the Spanish language through different areas of linguistics such as phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, sociolinguistics, dialectology, and second language acquisition.

SPAN 432.name: Multilingualism
SPAN 432.description: This course will offer a panoramic view of bilingualism and multilingualism from a language acquisition perspective. Topics surveyed include myths about bilingualism, early vs. late bilingualism, first vs. second language acquisition, cognitive models of bilingualism, as well as the sociolinguistics and pragmatics of bilingualism, among other topics.

SPAN 433.name: Gender and Sexuality in Hispanic Literature and Culture
SPAN 433.description: Examines literary texts that address issues of gender & sexuality in the Hispanic world, especially with regard to personal and cultural identities. This course may address the role of sexual minorities in society as well as patriarchy, nationhood, masculinity, and feminist theoretical issues.

SPAN 434.name: Film and Visual Culture in the Hispanic World
SPAN 434.description: Analysis of recent film and other visual media concerning life, culture, and artistic traditions in the Hispanic world. These artistic productions provide social, historical, political and ideological frameworks to explore the changes that have taken place in contemporary Latin America. Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 461.name: Special Topics
SPAN 461.description: Focus on some aspect of Hispanic American thought, literature, or culture. Topics vary.

SPAN 465.name: Latin American Film and Culture
SPAN 465.description: Explores Latin American and Latino/a films and videos from 1900s to present as works of art and in light of political, cultural, and social contexts. Taught in English.

SPAN 484.name: Race, Ethnicity, and Nation in Hispanic Literature
SPAN 484.description: Critical approaches to topics about race, ethnicity, and writing that define Spanish-speaking nations and communities across the globe. This course can include all texts and issues that dialogue with appropriate aspects of the diverse (Hispanic-based) racial and ethnic compositions and distinctions in Latin America, Spain, North America, Africa, and beyond. Also, a Latino Studies course.

SPAN 489.name: Topics in Hispanic Civilization
SPAN 489.description: Analysis and discussion of major trends, issues and/or movements in the civilizations of Spain and Spanish America. Political, literary, and cultural perspectives dealing with topics from the Middle Ages to the present day may be explored.

SPAN 490.name: Internship
SPAN 490.description: Career-related experiences in the United States or abroad.

SPAN 494.name: Hispanics in the US and Knoxville: Community Service Practicum
SPAN 494.description: Introduction to U.S. Hispanic culture in general and specifically in Knoxville. Students will read and experience a variety of cultural materials including literature, fine arts, performing arts, and popular culture. Students will read and analyze relevant sociological and Political Texts. Supervised community service with local agencies that assist Hispanic community or supervised activities with local cultural organizations that promote awareness of Hispanic Culture among the general public. Minimum of 30 hours off-campus supervised work and 2 weekly class meetings with faculty.

SPAN 495.name: Understanding Culture Through Service in a Hispanic Country
SPAN 495.description: Students will engage with culture and society via service-learning in a Hispanic country.

SPAN 490N.name: Internship
SPAN 490N.description: Career-related experiences in the United States or abroad.

SPAN 494S.name: Hispanics in the US and Knoxville: Community Service Practicum
SPAN 494S.description: Introduction to U.S. Hispanic culture in general and specifically in Knoxville. Students will read and experience a variety of cultural materials including literature, fine arts, performing arts, and popular culture. Students will read and analyze relevant sociological and Political Texts. Supervised community service with local agencies that assist Hispanic community or supervised activities with local cultural organizations that promote awareness of Hispanic Culture among the general public. Minimum of 30 hours off-campus supervised work and 2 weekly class meetings with faculty.

SPAN 495S.name: Understanding Culture Through Service in a Hispanic Country
SPAN 495S.description: Students will engage with culture and society via service-learning in a Hispanic country.

SPED 303.name: Professional Studies for Special Education and Diverse Learners
SPED 303.description: Professional Studies for Special Education and Diverse Learners. Characteristics and needs of students with disabilities and diverse learners with emphasis on educational implications. Techniques, strategies and resources for teaching and assessing students with diverse learning, behavioral, medical and/or sociocultural characteristics, and the requirements of special education and other relevant laws.

SPED 321.name: Field Experience in Special Education
SPED 321.description: This course is designed to accompany special education methods courses. Teacher candidates enrolled in this course will plan, implement, and evaluate instruction for K-12 students with disabilities in school settings.

SPED 325.name: Applied Research Designs for Diverse Learners
SPED 325.description: Applied Research Designs for Diverse Learners is designed to provide students with knowledge and skills related to research activities in an applied context.

SPED 335.name: Language and Literacy Development and Disorders
SPED 335.description: Emphasizes an understanding of language development, speech and language differences common among children with developmental delays and / or disabilities, and the impact of speech and language impairments on the development of literacy skills. Learners explore methods for increasing K-12 students' speech and language skills, including the use of augmentative communication.

SPED 413.name: Foundations in Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities
SPED 413.description: Provides foundational knowledge of learning needs, service delivery models, and critical issues in the education of students with intellectual and developmental disabilities. Introduction to research-based, evidence-based, and high leverage practices for assessment and instruction of students with moderate to severe intellectual disability, developmental disabilities, and multiple disabilities.

SPED 414.name: Effective Instruction for Students with Moderate to Severe Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities
SPED 414.description: Identifying and implementing best practices in assessment and instruction for students with moderate to severe intellectual disability and developmental disabilities that significantly impact learning. Understanding and applying high-leverage research-based and evidence-based practices including systematic instruction, curricular modifications, and data-based decision making.

SPED 415.name: Foundations in Learning Disabilities and Other Academic Difficulties
SPED 415.description: Provides foundational knowledge of learning needs, service delivery models, and critical issues in the education of students with learning disabilities, including dyslexia, and other academic difficulties. Introduction to research-based, evidence-based, and high leverage practices for assessment and instruction of students with diverse learning needs under a Response to Intervention framework.

SPED 416.name: Effective Instruction for Students with Learning Disabilities and Other Academic Difficulties
SPED 416.description: Determining and implementing best practices in assessment and instruction, both remediation and accommodation strategies, for students with learning disabilities, including dyslexia, and other academic difficulties. Understanding and applying high-leverage evidence-based practices, strategy-based instruction, assessment, and progress monitoring, and databased decision-making.

SPED 430.name: Applied Behavior Analysis in School Settings
SPED 430.description: Emphasizes the application of applied behavior analysis principles including the study of designing, implementing, and evaluating behavior analytic interventions relevant to alleviating significant problem behaviors in the classroom setting. Learners examine topics in the use of applied behavior analysis such as direct instruction, behavior reduction, functional analysis, positive behavioral supports, and ethical issues in the use of various procedures.

SPED 442.name: Methods of Teaching Students with Emotional and Behavioral Disorders
SPED 442.description: Examines educational strategies and techniques for individual and class-wide behavior management as well as curriculum and teaching strategies for promoting the social and emotional development of students with emotional and behavioral disorders. Both reactive and proactive strategies for working with students are addressed.

SPED 452.name: Classroom Management
SPED 452.description: Designed to examine validated methodology of class-wide and individual strategies for successfully managing a classroom across a variety of learning environments and levels. Participants will develop an understanding of motivation and behavior to create a learning environment that encourages positive social interactions, active engagement in learning, and self-motivation.

SPED 453.name: Assessment in Special Education
SPED 453.description: Current issues related to assessment; advanced study of evaluation models for special education; dynamic and other innovative assessment approaches; advanced study of application to educational programming; basic statistics and application in assessment.

SPED 459.name: Physical and Health Impairments: Educational Implications
SPED 459.description: Characteristics of students with neuromotor, orthopedic, and musculoskeletal impairments, degenerative and life-limiting conditions, and health impairments and the impact of these disabilities on student learning. Adaptations and teaching strategies for meeting the needs of students with physical and health impairments in general and special education contexts.

SPED 470.name: Psychology of the Exceptional Child
SPED 470.description: General characteristics and educational needs of exceptional children. Implications of developmental variations for functioning as adults.

SPED 474.name: Application of Special Education Principles and Practices
SPED 474.description: This course is taught in conjunction with practical teaching or internship in field placements settings. In this course, teacher candidates apply principles learned in prior coursework in authentic contexts (e.g., writing IEPs, lesson planning, conducting individual and group instruction, implementing high leverage practices and research-based instructional and behavioral strategies).

SPED 475.name: Internship Teaching Special Ed
SPED 475.description: Intensive teaching and teaching-related experiences with students who have disabilities in public schools.

SPED 479.name: Teaching Practices in Special Education
SPED 479.description: This course will help teacher candidates in special education understand and prepare for teacher assessments.

SPED 490.name: Applications of Assistive Technology
SPED 490.description: Application of assistive and instructional technology for students in all disability categories and across all chronological and functioning age ranges. Adaptive software, hardware for access, and strategies for technology usage, assessment, and instruction.

SPED 493.name: Student Teaching in Special Education
SPED 493.description: Intensive teaching and teaching-related experiences with students who have disabilities in public schools.

SPED 494.name: Special Education Student Teaching Seminar
SPED 494.description: This course is taught in conjunction with student teaching. In this course, student teachers apply principles learned in prior coursework in authentic contexts and develop policies and procedures they can apply in their own classrooms.

SPED 496.name: Professional Issues in Special Education
SPED 496.description: This course is taught in conjunction with practical teaching or internship in field placements settings. In this course, candidates apply principles learned in prior coursework in authentic contexts and develop policies and procedures they can apply in their own classrooms.

SPED 200S.name: Service Learning in Special Education
SPED 200S.description: Introductory course for students interested in pursuing careers in special education. Course is designed to provide students with service learning experiences in conjunction with placements in community or instructional settings. Service learning projects will engage students in the application of new knowledge and skills through projects related to improving educational, recreational, or self-determination outcomes for people with disabilities.

SPED 300N.name: Introduction to Special Education Teaching Principles
SPED 300N.description: Teacher candidates participate in on-campus learning as well as observing and assisting in a field placement setting. Key principles of special education law and introductory principles of special education instruction are reviewed with emphasis on application in classroom settings. Assessments are designed to provide knowledge of special education principles in an authentic context (e.g., processes for eligibility, IEPs, RTI screening processes).

SPED 320N.name: Field Experiences in Special Education: Mild/Moderate Disabilities
SPED 320N.description: This course is designed to provide field experiences in teaching K-12 students with mild to moderate disabilities. Teacher candidates enrolled in the course will plan, implement, and evaluate instruction for K-12 students with mild to moderate disabilities.

SPED 322N.name: Field Experiences in Special Education: Moderate/Severe Disabilities
SPED 322N.description: This course is designed to provide field experiences in teaching K-12 students with moderate to severe disabilities. Teacher candidates enrolled in the course will plan, implement, and evaluate instruction for K-12 students with moderate to severe disabilities.

SPED 420N.name: Practical Teaching in Special Education I
SPED 420N.description: This course is designed to provide an in-depth field experience in teaching K-12 students with disabilities. Teacher candidates will plan, implement, and evaluate instruction under the guidance of a mentoring teacher. This course will include (a) planning, instruction, and assessment based on needs of students with disabilities, (b) implementation of special education high-leverage practices, and (c) use of research-based strategies to engage students and maintain and facilitate appropriate behavior.

SPED 422N.name: Practical Teaching in Special Education II
SPED 422N.description: This course is designed to provide an in-depth field experience in teaching K-12 students with disabilities. Teacher candidates will plan, implement, and evaluate instruction under the guidance of a mentoring teacher. This course will include (a) planning, instruction, and assessment based on needs of students with disabilities, (b) implementation of special education high leverage practices, and (c) use of research-based strategies to engage students and maintain and facilitate appropriate behavior.

SSCE 421.name: Introduction to Teaching Elementary Social Studies
SSCE 421.description: Methods, materials, instruction and assessment procedures for teaching social studies at the elementary school level.

SSCE 432.name: Practicing Collaboration for Teaching Diverse Learners in Secondary Schools
SSCE 432.description: Provides prospective educators authentic models of practice to effectively collaborate as means to meet the needs of diverse learners in secondary classrooms.

SSCE 443.name: Teaching Strategies & Issues in Secondary Social Studies
SSCE 443.description: Activities in this class are intended to promote the professional growth of pre-service social studies teachers through study, design, and implementation of social studies curriculum and instructional strategies. In particular, methods of teaching contemporary social science content in middle and secondary classrooms will be explored.

SSCE 454.name: Teaching Strategies and Issues in Secondary Social Studies Education
SSCE 454.description: Goals, objectives, techniques, materials, and evaluation in secondary social studies. Directed observation in secondary schools. Preparation of teaching plans, instructional material, and assessment material.

SSCE 472.name: Internship I
SSCE 472.description: This course is designed to provide field experiences in teaching secondary social science education courses to 6-12 students. Teacher candidates enrolled in the course will plan, implement, and evaluate instruction for 6-12 students in secondary social science education.

SSCE 485.name: Teaching and Learning with Film
SSCE 485.description: Selected strategies, trends, methods, materials, and legal issues for effectively incorporating film in the K-12 classroom. Selected topics include media literacy, film research, and making movies appropriate to educational settings.

SSCE 493.name: Internship II
SSCE 493.description: Intensive teaching and teaching-related experiences with students in 6-12 secondary social science education.

SSCE 494.name: Secondary Social Science Education Internship II Seminar
SSCE 494.description: This course is taught in conjunction with Internship II (SSCE 493). In this course, candidates will apply principles learned in prior coursework in authentic contexts and develop policies and procedures they can apply in their own classrooms.

SSCE 496.name: Teaching and Learning in a Contemporary Secondary Classroom
SSCE 496.description: Introduces, examines, and models the effective practice of teaching and learning with contemporary tools, resources, and strategies for secondary classrooms (grades 6-12).

STAT 201.name: Introduction to Statistics
STAT 201.description: Graphical and numerical summaries of data. Introduction to probability, simulation, sampling distributions and the normal distribution. Sampling techniques. Inference for a single mean, a single proportion, and difference in independent means using confidence intervals and hypothesis testing. Correlation, simple linear regression, and decision trees. Association between categorical variables. Use of statistical computing and widely used spreadsheet software. Applied course appropriate for a general audience.

STAT 207.name: Honors: Introduction to Statistics
STAT 207.description: Intended as an alternative to STAT 201* for higher GPA students.

STAT 251.name: Probability and Statistics for Scientists and Engineers
STAT 251.description: Data collection and descriptive statistics. Concepts of probability and probability distributions. Discrete and continuous distributions. Estimation of means, confidence intervals, and hypothesis tests for single mean and proportion. Simple regression and correlation. Process improvement, statistical process control, and 2-level experiments. Use of statistical computing software.

THEA 100.name: Introduction to Theatre
THEA 100.description: Understanding theatre thought, philosophy, aesthetics, and production practices.

THEA 107.name: Honors: Introduction to Theatre
THEA 107.description: Honors introduction to understanding theatre thought, philosophy, aesthetics and production practices.

THEA 210.name: Basic Acting Techniques for Majors
THEA 210.description: Exploration and development of acting techniques.

THEA 220.name: Introduction to Acting
THEA 220.description: Exploring and freeing the actor through Stanislavski-based exercises in order to form a solid foundation for playing a scene.

THEA 221.name: Beginning Scene Study
THEA 221.description: Further exploration and development of acting techniques through exercises and beginning scene work.

THEA 230.name: The Black Experience in Theatre Performance
THEA 230.description: Using history, devising techniques, movement, and music; students will learn universal performance practices based in the Black American experience. The class will culminate in a performance piece solely written by the students. This class is open to students of all backgrounds and acting levels: beginner to advanced.

THEA 242.name: Fundamentals of Costume Design and Technology
THEA 242.description: Introduction to the elements of costume design, technology, and the design process. Hands-on and lab-intensive with required participation on a Clarence Brown Theatre production run crew.

THEA 252.name: Fundamentals of Scene Design and Technology
THEA 252.description: Introduction to the elements of scene design, technology, and the design process. Hands-on and lab-intensive with required participation on a Clarence Brown Theatre production run crew.

THEA 262.name: Fundamentals of Lighting Design and Technology
THEA 262.description: Introduction to the elements of lighting design, technology, and the design process. Hands-on and lab-intensive with required participation on a Clarence Brown Theatre production run crew.

THEA 300.name: Play Analysis
THEA 300.description: Study of methods and tools used in script analysis for the purpose of play production.

THEA 320.name: Advanced Acting I
THEA 320.description: Character study and scene study in 20th and 21st century American plays, with a focus on major playwrights.

THEA 321.name: Advanced Acting II
THEA 321.description: Scene study. Analysis and performance of late 19th and early 20th century plays.

THEA 323.name: Stage Movement
THEA 323.description: Introduction to movement/kinesthetic awareness techniques and their application to performance.

THEA 325.name: Fundamentals of Musical Theatre
THEA 325.description: Introduction to musical theatre, including reading music, singing techniques, basic dance, and an overview of musical theatre styles.

THEA 326.name: Voice and Speech for the Stage Actor
THEA 326.description: Breath-centered, body-based voice production. Exploration and control of shaping sound. Text work. Geared toward acting for the stage.

THEA 330.name: Stage Management
THEA 330.description: The role of the stage manager in theatrical production: organization, communication, basic tools and theory.

THEA 340.name: Costume Design I
THEA 340.description: Development of research, rendering, and conceptualization skills.

THEA 345.name: Costume Construction
THEA 345.description: Techniques in the construction of costumes for the theatre.

THEA 355.name: Scenic Design I
THEA 355.description: Designing a set by combining the elements and principles of design composition with dramaturgical research.

THEA 362.name: Lighting Design I
THEA 362.description: In-depth lighting design practice and principals. Project and lab-intensive.

THEA 373.name: Introduction to Sound Design
THEA 373.description: Developing a basic understanding of the properties and perceptions of sound, audio technologies, and the theatrical sound design process.

THEA 410.name: Special Studies in History, Literature, and Criticism
THEA 410.description: Concentrated study in a given period or area of theatre history, literature or criticism. Content varies.

THEA 411.name: Theatre History I
THEA 411.description: Antiquity to 1700. Major historical periods and diverse cultural traditions in world theatre history.

THEA 412.name: Theatre History II
THEA 412.description: 1700 to contemporary theatre. Major historical periods and diverse cultural traditions in world theatre history.

THEA 413.name: Dramaturgy and New Play Development
THEA 413.description: Provides theoretical and practical grounding in current approaches to production dramaturgy and new play development.

THEA 415.name: Theatre for Every Body: Plays by and about underrepresented people
THEA 415.description: Examine plays by and about members of underrepresented groups to understand and articulate the relevance of meaningful representation of all people on stage.

THEA 420.name: Special Studies in Acting
THEA 420.description: Exercises in selected concentrated areas such as styles, techniques, approaches, e.g., Shakespeare, movement, humor. Content varies.

THEA 422.name: Advanced Acting Practices
THEA 422.description: Intensive studio work for students interested in the performance aspect of the major. Content varies.

THEA 424.name: Shakespearean Text for the Actor
THEA 424.description: Tools for the analysis and performance of Shakespearean texts. Acting monologues and scenes required.

THEA 425.name: Advanced Musical Theatre
THEA 425.description: Study and practice of musical theatre material including both dance and vocal work.

THEA 430.name: Directing for the Stage
THEA 430.description: The stage director's craft: principles of staging, textual integrity, conceptualization, visualization, collaboration and process from pre-production to opening.

THEA 446.name: Costume Patterning
THEA 446.description: Techniques in making patterns for theatrical costume.

THEA 450.name: Special Topics in Design and Technology

THEA 460.name: Advanced Lighting Design
THEA 460.description: Lighting design beyond theatre. We will explore lighting for music, opera, industrials, corporate events, and themed entertainment.

THEA 462.name: Dance Concert Lighting
THEA 462.description: Lighting techniques for specific dance styles including Ballet, Modern, Jazz, and Hip Hop.

THEA 463.name: Programming for Lighting Consoles
THEA 463.description: Programming techniques for various lighting control consoles used in theatre and live entertainment.

THEA 464.name: Computer Aided Drafting for the Theatre
THEA 464.description: Introduction to entertainment drafting. Emphasis on 2-D graphical standards, drafting techniques, and drawing layout and presentation.

THEA 473.name: Advanced Sound Design
THEA 473.description: Advanced application of theatrical sound design practice, principles, and technology.

THEA 475.name: Projection and Media Design
THEA 475.description: The creation and execution of digital media for theatrical projection and multimedia/performance integration.

THEA 481.name: Applied Theatre
THEA 481.description: Laboratory in applied theatre techniques for departmental productions.

THEA 490.name: Professional Practices
THEA 490.description: Course will focus on the integration of knowledge and skills acquired in the program, culminating in a Senior Creative Synthesis project. Students will present work that demonstrates preparedness for the profession and/or further professional training.

THEA 497.name: Honors: Senior Project
THEA 497.description: Substantial endeavor in design, performance, directing and/or playwriting representing the capstone of a student’s undergraduate education.

TPTE 110.name: VolsTeach: Inquiry-based Teaching
TPTE 110.description: Introduction to inquiry-based approaches to teaching in mathematics and science.

TPTE 115.name: VolsTeach: Introduction to Teaching
TPTE 115.description: Introduction to inquiry-based approaches to teaching and lesson design.

TPTE 120.name: VolsTeach: Inquiry-based Lesson Design
TPTE 120.description: Introduction to inquiry-based lesson design in mathematics and science.

TPTE 203.name: Field Study in Education
TPTE 203.description: Problems of persons in active service in the field. Includes methods of teaching, curriculum materials, school-community relationships, and school organizations.

TPTE 352.name: Field Experiences in Teaching: Secondary I
TPTE 352.description: Field experiences in tasks related to teaching and teacher roles.

TPTE 355.name: Introduction to Secondary Schools
TPTE 355.description: Aspects of teaching in middle grade and high school classrooms, including curricular program and roles and responsibilities of secondary school teachers and administrators.

TPTE 435.name: Apprentice Teaching Mathematics and Science
TPTE 435.description: Intensive teaching and teaching-related experiences in secondary mathematics or science classrooms in public schools.

TPTE 475.name: Professional Internship in Teaching
TPTE 475.description: Intensive teaching and teaching-related experiences in professional settings in public schools.

TPTE 489.name: Analysis of Teaching
TPTE 489.description: The course is an introduction to the edTPA, the components of the portfolio, and the expectations of candidates in the completion of the process. The course learning outcomes/objectives align with national standards and state licensure requirements. The teacher candidates will hone their skills at writing and analyzing critical aspects of the classroom context, planning, instructing, and assessing.

TPTE 496.name: Clinical Studies
TPTE 496.description: Group and individual seminar activities during full-time internship. Application and evaluation of professional core competencies. Completion and presentation of portfolio and analysis of teaching project.

TRNS 200.name: The Volunteer Connection
TRNS 200.description: This online course is designed for new transfer students at the University of Tennessee. Students will explore ways to quickly get acclimated to the University of Tennessee community through academic engagement, critical reflection, and self-exploration. Students will craft a personal plan for their academic experience at UT and beyond through guided assignments and peer interaction.

TRNS 201.name: Transitioning on Rocky Top
TRNS 201.description: A seamless transition to Rocky Top is critical to the success of our students. This course emphasizes the development a personal plan of study connected with an academic, personal, career exploration, and/or goals. Students enrolled in the course will identify and engage in experiences outside of the classroom to foster connection to the institution and development of personal identity as a student. Open to all transitional and transfer students at the University of Tennessee.

UNHO 101.name: Honors First-Year Seminar
UNHO 101.description: Introductory seminar for students in honors. Topics vary.

UNHO 237.name: Honors: Special Topics in Global Citizenship: US
UNHO 237.description: Examination of a selected issue in the area of global citizenship (U.S. focus) from a multi-disciplinary perspective. Topics vary.

UNHO 257.name: Honors: Special Topics in the Arts and Humanities
UNHO 257.description: Examination of a selected issue in the arts and/or humanities from a multi-disciplinary perspective. Topics vary.

UNHO 258.name: Honors: Special Topics in the Arts and Humanities
UNHO 258.description: Examination of a selected issue in the arts and/or humanities from a multi-disciplinary perspective. Writing-intensive course. Topics vary.

UNHO 267.name: Honors: Special Topics in the Social Sciences
UNHO 267.description: Examination of a selected issue in the social sciences from a multi-disciplinary perspective. Topics vary.

UNHO 268.name: Honors: Special Topics in the Social Sciences
UNHO 268.description: Examination of a selected issue in the social sciences from a multi-disciplinary perspective. Writing-intensive course. Topics vary.

UNHO 277.name: Honors: Special Topics in Global Citizenship - International
UNHO 277.description: Examination of a selected global or cultural issue from a multi-disciplinary perspective. Topics vary.

UNHO 278.name: Honors: Special Topics in Global Citizenship - International
UNHO 278.description: Examination of a selected issue in cultures and civilizations from a multi-disciplinary perspective. Writing-intensive course. Topics vary.

UNHO 337.name: Honors: Concentration in the Humanities
UNHO 337.description: Small group studies of selected topics, issues, or problems with a concentration in the humanistic disciplines. Topics vary.

UNHO 347.name: Honors: Concentration in the Social Sciences
UNHO 347.description: Small group studies of selected topics, issues, or problems with a concentration in the social sciences. Topics vary.

UNHO 357.name: Honors: Concentration in the Natural and Applied Sciences
UNHO 357.description: Small group studies of selected topics, issues, or problems with a concentration in the natural and applied sciences. Topics vary.

UNHO 491.name: Honors: Foreign Study
UNHO 491.description: Open to any undergraduate honors student. Proposals must be approved in advance. Contact the director for information.

UNHO 492.name: Honors: Off-Campus Study
UNHO 492.description: Open to any undergraduate honors student. Proposals must be approved in advance. Contact the director for information.

UNHO 493.name: Honors: Independent Study
UNHO 493.description: Open to any undergraduate honors student. Proposals must be approved in advance by Chancellor's Honors Program.

UNHO 497.name: Honors Capstone Research
UNHO 497.description: Research involving substantial scholarly, scientific, or artistic endeavor representing the culmination of a student's undergraduate education.

UNHO 498.name: Honors Capstone Project
UNHO 498.description: Substantial scholarly, scientific, or artistic endeavor representing the culmination of a student's undergraduate education. Required of all Chancellor's Honors Program students not completing an equivalent senior project for an academic department or program.

UNST 210.name: Special Topics in University Studies
UNST 210.description: Interdisciplinary approaches to selected topics for lower-division students. Small group discussion of varying topics that transcend the boundaries of a single discipline. Writing-intensive and team-taught.

UNST 220.name: Special Topics in University Studies
UNST 220.description: Interdisciplinary approaches to selected topics for lower-division students. Small group discussion of varying topics that transcend the boundaries of a single discipline. Writing-intensive and team-taught.

UNST 227.name: Honors: Topics in University Studies
UNST 227.description: Interdisciplinary approach to a significant scholarly or social issue for lower division students. Small group discussion of varying topics that transcend the boundaries of a single discipline. Writing-intensive.

UNST 310.name: Special Topics in University Studies
UNST 310.description: Interdisciplinary approaches to issues transcending the boundaries of a single discipline. Topics may be initiated by faculty or students through arrangements with the University Studies Program. Taught by faculty from throughout the university (often team-taught). Discussion-based and writing-intensive.

UNST 317.name: Honors: Special Topics in University Studies
UNST 317.description: Honors course utilizing an interdisciplinary approach to a significant scholarly or social issue. Topics change every semester. Consult Timetable for current offering. Discussion-based and writing-intensive.

UNST 320.name: Special Topics in University Studies
UNST 320.description: Interdisciplinary approaches to issues transcending the boundaries of a single discipline. Topics may be initiated by faculty or students through arrangements with the University Studies Program. Taught by faculty from throughout the university (often team-taught). Discussion-based and writing-intensive.

UNST 410.name: Advanced Topics in University Studies
UNST 410.description: Interdisciplinary research approaches to major issues transcending the boundaries of a single discipline. Topics may be initiated by faculty or students through arrangements with the University Studies Program. Taught by faculty from throughout the university (often team-taught).

UNST 413.name: Art and Organism - Integrative Biology of Aesthetic Experience

UNST 417.name: Honors: Advanced Topics in University Studies
UNST 417.description: Honors course utilizing an in-depth interdisciplinary research approach to a significant scholarly or social issue. Topics change every semester. Consult Timetable for current offering. Discussion-based and writing-intensive.

UNST 420.name: Advanced Topics in University Studies
UNST 420.description: Interdisciplinary research approaches to major issues transcending the boundaries of a single discipline. Topics may be initiated by faculty or students through arrangements with the University Studies Program. Taught by faculty from throughout the university (often team-taught). Discussion-based and writing-intensive.

UNST 495.name: Research Experience
UNST 495.description: The course provides pre-professional experience in research, scholarship, and creative activity under the supervision of a faculty member.

WFS 100.name: Introduction to Wildlife and Fisheries Science
WFS 100.description: Introduction to wildlife and fisheries management; review of research and management topics in wildlife and fisheries and current issues.

WFS 101.name: Current Topics in Wildlife Health
WFS 101.description: All aspects of wildlife health, including current topics, emerging diseases, and impact of diseases on wildlife populations, general disease mechanisms, and career opportunities in the wildlife profession.

WFS 295.name: Practicum in Wildlife and Fisheries Sciences
WFS 295.description: Designed to give students practical, hands-on wildlife and/or fisheries experience working with a state, federal, or private natural resources organization. Provides credit for approved employment in natural resources management or research, 1 hour credit for every 160 hours of work. Students may find work on their own or with faculty assistance. Students must submit an approved work plan to their advisor, keep a daily log submitted every 2 weeks and prepare a final written report.

WFS 305.name: Prescribed Fire Management
WFS 305.description: Prescribed fire ecology, use, and management in forest stands.

WFS 324.name: Wildlife Habitat Evaluation
WFS 324.description: This course introduces students to the process of wildlife habitat evaluation, with special emphasis on plant identification, wildlife uses of plants, wildlife species habitat needs, and wildlife habitat evaluation methods.

WFS 340.name: Wetlands Ecology and Management
WFS 340.description: Ecology, restoration, and management of wetland ecosystems, including biotic and abiotic processes, functions, and wildlife considerations.

WFS 350.name: Wildlife Damage Management
WFS 350.description: Principles and methods for wildlife damage management, including biological, regulatory, practical, and social considerations. Weekend field trips (2) required.

WFS 351.name: Wildlife Law Enforcement
WFS 351.description: Introduction to laws and policies related to wildlife and fisheries, wildlife law enforcement principles and practices, and career opportunities.

WFS 401.name: Ecology and Management of Wildlife Health
WFS 401.description: Review of ecological and environmental factors affecting wildlife health, and tools available for effective wildlife disease surveillance and management. Emphasis on the importance of multidisciplinary and interagency collaboration for management of wildlife health problems.

WFS 420.name: Identification and Ecology of Freshwater Mussels
WFS 420.description: This class is devoted to the study of shells of freshwater mussel species found in the lakes, rivers, and streams of North America, with special attention given to the fauna of Tennessee.

WFS 425.name: Tropical Ecology, Conservation, and Field Methods
WFS 425.description: This study abroad course will cover tropical ecology and conservation concepts, issues, principles, and practices. In addition, it will provide experience in the field methods and techniques used by managers and researchers to study terrestrial natural resource ecology and conservation in tropical regions.

WFS 431.name: Wildlife Physiology and Nutrition
WFS 431.description: An introduction and overview of the physiological and nutritional mechanisms important behind the regulation of wild animal populations (primarily wild birds and mammals). Wildlife responses to seasonal changes in habitat are critical for understanding management options. Discussion of use of chemical immobilization options, physiological indicators, and genetic analysis of wild animal population dynamics.

WFS 433.name: Amphibian Ecology and Conservation
WFS 433.description: In-depth examination of amphibian life-history strategies, community interactions, and hypothesized mechanisms of amphibian declines. Also covers amphibian monitoring, conservation and management.

WFS 434.name: Ecology and Conservation of Tropical Mammals
WFS 434.description: This course will examine tropical ecosystems and the taxonomy, diversity, life history, management, and conservation of associated mammal species.

WFS 440.name: Wildlife Techniques
WFS 440.description: Methods in wildlife damage control, forest, farmland, wetland wildlife habitat management, identification of wildlife field sign, wildlife capturing techniques, and management plan preparation. Weekend field trips (2) required.

WFS 441.name: Stream Ecology
WFS 441.description: This course focuses on freshwater riverine ecology. Emphasis is placed on the stream environment and associated fauna, and the interrelationships therein. Upon completion, students should be able to identify habitat features, selected freshwater invertebrates and fishes, and demonstrate ecological knowledge.

WFS 442.name: Fisheries Techniques
WFS 442.description: Active and passive sampling techniques for fish and aquatic organisms. Population estimation methods, fish handling and transport, food habits analysis, and marking and tagging techniques. Age determination and incremental growth analysis. Stream assessment. Equipment and instrumentation usage and maintenance. Safety in sampling methods. Weekend field trip may be required.

WFS 443.name: Fisheries Science
WFS 443.description: Quantification and management of freshwater fisheries, including population estimation, age and growth, biological assessment, and stocking.

WFS 444.name: Ecology and Management of Wild Mammals
WFS 444.description: Biological and ecological characteristics of game mammals and endangered mammals. Current principles and practices of wild mammal management. Weekend field trip required.

WFS 445.name: Ecology and Management of Wild Birds
WFS 445.description: Biological and ecological characteristics of game birds, endangered birds, and bird pests. Current principles and practices of wild bird management. Weekend field trip required.

WFS 450.name: Fish Physiology
WFS 450.description: Mechanisms of gas transfer, circulation, excretion, osmoregulation, locomotion, and neural/hormonal control of these systems in fishes. Comparisons and contrasts with physiology of terrestrial animals. Practical applications of fish physiology to aquaculture, pollution assessment, and fisheries management.

WFS 452.name: Ecology and Management of Fishes
WFS 452.description: This course will cover theoretical and applied conservation and management issues relating to the ecology and regulation of fish populations and assemblages. Topics will include the abiotic (physical, chemical) and biotic (predation, competition) interactions facing fishes and how these interactions may be affected by humans, as well as how humans can manage these interactions to conserve and sustain fish populations and assemblages.

WFS 461.name: Professional Development in Wildlife and Fisheries Science
WFS 461.description: This course is designed to facilitate students' transition from college into a career or post-baccalaureate studies through a combination of lectures, readings, class discussions, and assignments (group and individual).

WFS 493.name: Independent Study in Wildlife and Fisheries Science
WFS 493.description: Special research or individual problem in wildlife and fisheries science.

WFS 496.name: Internship in Wildlife and Fisheries Science
WFS 496.description: Supervised experience at departmental-approved employment location arranged by the student. Internship learning objectives must be pre-approved by the advisor/instructor and the field supervisor. Daily log, supervisor evaluations, and final report required. One credit per two weeks of full-time supervised field experience maximum. Up to 3 credits may be used for science elective.

WGS 200.name: Introduction to Women, Gender, and Sexuality
WGS 200.description: Introduction to key concepts and methods in the study of women, gender, and sexuality, including the fields of gender, feminist, and lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) studies. Students will examine historical movements, theoretical debates, and contemporary issues, especially as they pertain to the intersection of gender, race, class, sexuality, and other dimensions of social inequality. Emphasis will vary according to the interdisciplinary expertise of the instructor.

WGS 314.name: Food, Fiction, and Film in Modern Japan

WGS 340.name: Gender, Politics, and the Law
WGS 340.description: An examination of recent changes in the laws affecting women and a study of the role of women in contemporary American politics.

WGS 370.name: Gender and Globalization
WGS 370.description: This international and intercultural course examines how economic and political processes affect gender, culture, and society across the globe. Emphasis is placed upon women's subjectivity and agency in relation to these processes, and upon diverse forms of women's activism for social change.

WGS 376.name: African American Women's History from Slavery to the Present

WGS 384.name: Gender and Sexuality in Greece and Rome

WGS 400.name: Topics in Women, Gender, and Sexuality
WGS 400.description: Content varies. Thematic focus on particular issues, concepts, theories, or methods in gender, feminist, or lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) studies.

WGS 412.name: Gender, Performance Art, and the Avant Garde

WGS 436.name: History of Gender and Sexuality in the United States

WGS 465.name: Gender and Sexuality in Early Latin America

WGS 469.name: Sexuality and Cinema
WGS 469.description: Explores issues surrounding sexuality, gender and cinema from points of view of feminist film criticism.

WGS 484.name: African American Women in American Society

WGS 490.name: Internship
WGS 490.description: Internship pertaining to women, gender, and/or sexuality.

WGS 491.name: Foreign Study
WGS 491.description: Foreign study pertaining to women, gender, and/or sexuality.

WGS 492.name: Off-Campus Study
WGS 492.description: Off-campus study pertaining to women, gender, and/or sexuality.

WGS 493.name: Independent Study
WGS 493.description: Independent study pertaining to women, gender, and/or sexuality.

WGS 499.name: Capstone Seminar in Women, Gender, and Sexuality
WGS 499.description: Content varies. Specialized study in women, gender, and sexuality. Includes a culminating research project that requires application of key concepts or methods in women, gender, and sexuality to a contemporary or historical problem or issue.

WLEL 445.name: Teaching World Languages: Grades PreK-5
WLEL 445.description: ACTFL standards-based pedagogy, curricula, research and instructional resources focused on the PreK-5 WL classroom.

WLEL 450.name: Second Language Assessment and Standards-Based Instruction
WLEL 450.description: Will focus on how to develop, use, score and interpret a variety of second language assessments, give constructive feedback to students and use the results of the assessments to inform standards-based language instruction.

WLEL 455.name: Teaching of World Languages
WLEL 455.description: ACTFL standards-based instructional methods, resources, integrated technologies, second language theories, research and evaluation for world languages. Required for licensure in World Languages.

WLEL 456.name: Field Study in Education
WLEL 456.description: This course is designed to provide Elementary-education teacher candidates with a school-based field experience to develop and demonstrate content knowledge, skills, and dispositions necessary to design lesson plans and deliver instruction to English Learners (ELs).

WLEL 466.name: ESL Assessment and Evaluation
WLEL 466.description: Highlights the implementation of authentic assessment, specifically, portfolio assessment for ESL students in K-12 settings. Focuses on designing appropriate tools for various assessment purposes. Specific types and different forms of assessment are examined based on their effectiveness and meaningfulness. Required for Tennessee (PreK-12) licensure.

WLEL 470.name: Sociolinguistics for ELL/ESL Teachers
WLEL 470.description: Educational sociolinguistic approaches, research, and theories for teaching English to second language learners. Examines how sociolinguistic variables such as cultural background, ethnicity, urbanization, disability, and socioeconomic status impacts second language learning and teaching English to speakers and signers of other Languages. Required for PreK-12 ESL Licensure.

WLEL 475.name: Grammar for ESL Teachers
WLEL 475.description: Pedagogical approaches, second language acquisition research and resources for teaching English grammar to English language learners. Required for PreK-12 ESL licensure.

WLEL 489.name: Content-Based ESL Methods
WLEL 489.description: This course focuses on designing and implementing content-based ESL instruction to enhance English language learners' academic achievement. Required for Tennessee (PreK-12) licensure.

WLEL 493.name: Student Teaching in World Language and World Language/English as a Second Language
WLEL 493.description: Will focus on how to develop, use, score and interpret a variety of second language assessments, give constructive feedback to students and use the results of the assessments to inform standards-based language instruction.

WLEL 494.name: World Language and World Language/English as a Second Language – Student Teaching Seminar
WLEL 494.description: Will focus on how to develop, use, score and interpret a variety of second language assessments, give constructive feedback to students and use the results of the assessments to inform standards-based language instruction.
